Experimental evidence suggests a role for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> in the progression of diseases that involve the skin or epithelium of internal surfaces, such as, for instance, large intestine, small intestine, pancrease, lung, prostate, uterus, and the like. First, as disclosed herein, zcytorl7 receptors, including both OSM receptor beta and zcytorl7, are expressed in several cell types located in epithelial surfaces including cell lines derived from lung epithelium, lung fibroblast, prostate, colon, breast, liver epithelium, bone and skin epithelium, bone fibroblast, and the like. Moreover, as disclosed herein, examples from each of these cell types also responded to <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> activation of a STAT reporter construct. In addition, several cell lines responded to <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> stimulation by producing increased levels of IL-6, <RTI ID=0.0>IL-8,</RTI> MCP-1 (a chemotactic factor) as described herein. In whole, these data suggest a role for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> in diseases that involve the epithelium such as, for instance, atopic dermatitis ; dermatitis; psoriasis; psoriatic arthritis; eczema; gingivitis; <RTI ID=0.0>peridontal</RTI> disease; inflammatory bowel diseases <RTI ID=0.0>(IBD)</RTI> (e. g. , ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease); reproductive disorders, such as, for instance, cervical dysplasia, cervical cancer; other skin diseases like cancers: sarcomas; canrcinomas; melanoma, etc. i. e, not just inflammatory diseases, since immune system is involved in activating/curing cancers; diseases involving barrier dysfunction, such as, for instance, graft-versus-host disease <RTI ID=0.0>(GVHD)</RTI> and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) ; and diseases that involve lung epithelium, such as asthma, emphysema, and the like. In addition, the release <RTI ID=0.0>of cytokines 1L-6, L-8,</RTI> and MCP-1 by cells exposed to <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> suggests that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> is involved in inflammation. Therefore, regulation of
<Desc/Clms Page number 111>

<RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> can be useful in the treatment of autoimmune, inflammatory, or cancerous diseases associated with the tissues that express receptor. These diseases include, for example, prostatitis, hepatitis, osteoarthritis, and the like. <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> may positively or negatively directly or indirectly regulate these diseases. Therefore, the administration of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> can be used to treat diseases as described herein directly or with molecules that inhibit <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> activity including, for example, both monoclonal antibodies to <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> or monoclonal antibodies to zcytorl7, or monoclonal antibodies that recognize the zcytorl7 and OSM receptor beta complex.

Data also suggests that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> may be involved in the regulation of TH2 T cell mediated diseases. First, <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> is made by the TH2 subset of activated T cells. TH2 cells express more <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> as compared to <RTI ID=0.0>TH1</RTI> cells. In addition, at least two lung epithelial cell lines (SK-LU-1, A549) were stimulated to increase <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> receptor alpha-2 mRNA in response to zcytol7 ligand stimulation as described herein.

There is an association of <RTI ID=0.0>IL-13</RTI> receptor alpha2 chain and tumorigenicity of human breast and pancreatic tumors. This suggests that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> may play a role in regulating tumorigenicity of these types of cancers, as well as other cancers. Therefore, the administration of a <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> antagonist or direct use of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> may be useful in treatment of these types of cancers, benign or malignant and at various grades (grades <RTI ID=0.0>I-IV)</RTI> and stages (e. g. , TNM or AJC staging methods) of tumor development, in mammals, preferably humans.

It is well-known in the art that <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> is involved in the generation of activated TH2 cells and in TH2 mediated diseases, such as asthma, atopic dermatitis, and the like. <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> or <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> antagonists may be useful in the treatment of diseases that involved TH2 T cells. This would include diseases such as, for instance, atopic dermatitis, asthma, as well as other diseases that are exacerbated by activated TH2 cells. The involvement of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> in diseases, such as, for instance, atopic dermatitis, is also supported by the phenotype of the transgenic mice that overexpress <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> and develop symptoms of atopic dermatitis as described herein.

Despite the preferential expression of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> by TH2 cells, there is still some expression of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> in TH1 cells and in CD8+ T cells. Therefore, <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> or its antagonists may be useful in treating diseases that involve immune
<Desc/Clms Page number 112>
modulation of activated T cells including, for example, viral infection, cancers, graft rejection, and the like.

<RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> may also be involved in the development of cancer. There is expression of the zcytorl7 and OSM receptor beta receptors in human bone fibroblast osteosarcomas, human skin fibroblast melanoma, colon epithelial carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, breast epithelial adenocarcinoma, prostate epithelial adenosarcoma, and lung epithelial adenocarcinoma and carcinoma. Therefore, it may be useful to treat tumors of epithelial origin with either <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig,</RTI> fragments thereof, or <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> antagonists which include, but are not limited to, carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, and melanoma. Notwithstanding, <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> or a <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> antagonist may be used to treat a cancer, or reduce one or more symptoms of a cancer, from a cancer including but not limited to, squamous cell or epidermoid carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, papillary carcinoma, cystadenocarcinoma, bronchogenic carcinoma, bronchial adenoma, melanoma, renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, transitional cell carcinoma, choriocarcinoma, seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, malignant mixed tumor of salivary gland origin, Wilms'tumor, immature teratoma, teratocarcinoma, and other tumors comprising at least some cells of epithelial origin.

Generally, the dosage of administered <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> polypeptide (or Zcytorl6 analog or fusion protein) will vary depending upon such factors as the patient's age, weight, height, sex, general medical condition and previous medical history. Typically, it is desirable to provide the recipient with a dosage of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> polypeptide which is in the range of from about 1 pg/kg to 10 mg/kg (amount of <RTI ID=0.0>agent/body</RTI> weight of patient), although a lower or higher dosage also may be administered as circumstances dictate. One skilled in the art can readily determine such dosages, and adjustments thereto, using methods known in the art.

Administration of a zcytorl7 multimeric receptor agonist or antagonist to a subject can be topical, inhalant, intravenous, intraarterial, intraperitoneal, intramuscular, subcutaneous, intrapleural, intrathecal, by perfusion through a regional catheter, or by direct intralesional injection. When administering therapeutic proteins by injection, the administration may be by continuous infusion or by single or multiple boluses.
<Desc/Clms Page number 113>

Additional routes of administration include oral, mucosal-membrane, pulmonary, and transcutaneous. Oral delivery is suitable for polyester microspheres, zein microspheres, proteinoid microspheres, polycyanoacrylate microspheres, and lipid- based systems (see, for example, DiBase and Morrel,"Oral Delivery of Microencapsulated Proteins,"in Protein Delivery : Physical Systems, Sanders and Hendren (eds. ), pages 255-288 (Plenum Press 1997) ). The feasibility of an intranasal delivery is exemplified by such a mode of insulin administration (see, for example, Hinchcliffe and Ilium, Adv. Drug Deliv. Rev. 35 : 199 (1999) ). Dry or liquid particles comprising Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor agonist or antagonist can be prepared and inhaled with the aid of dry-powder dispersers, liquid aerosol generators, or nebulizers (e. g. , Pettit and Gombotz, TIBTECH <RTI ID=0.0>16</RTI> : 343 (1998); Patton et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Adv. Drug Deliv. Rev.

35 : 235 (1999) ). This approach is illustrated by the AERX diabetes management system, which is a hand-held electronic inhaler that delivers aerosolized insulin into the lungs. Studies have shown that proteins as large as 48,000 kDa have been delivered across skin at therapeutic concentrations with the aid of low-frequency ultrasound, which illustrates the feasibility of trascutaneous administration (Mitragotri et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Science 269: 850 (1995) ). Transdermal delivery using electroporation provides another means to administer a molecule having Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor binding activity (Potts <RTI ID=0.0>et al., Pharm. Biotechnol. 10</RTI> : 213 (1997)).

A pharmaceutical composition comprising a protein, polypeptide, or peptide having Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor binding activity can be formulated according to known methods to prepare pharmaceutically useful compositions, whereby the therapeutic proteins are combined in a mixture with a pharmaceutically acceptable vehicle. A composition is said to be in a"pharmaceutically acceptable vehicle"if its administration can be tolerated by a recipient patient. Sterile phosphate-buffered saline is one example of a pharmaceutically acceptable vehicle. Other suitable vehicles are well-known to those in the art. See, for example, Gennaro (ed.), Remington's <RTI ID=0.0>Pharmaceutical Sciences, l9th</RTI> Edition (Mack Publishing Company 1995).

For purposes of therapy, molecules having Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor binding activity and a pharmaceutically acceptable vehicle are administered to a patient in a therapeutically effective amount. A combination of a protein, polypeptide, or
<Desc/Clms Page number 114>

peptide having Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor binding activity and a pharmaceutically acceptable vehicle is said to be administered in a"therapeutically effective amount"or "effective amount"if the amount administered is physiologically significant. An agent is physiologically significant if its presence results in a detectable change in the physiology of a recipient patient. For example, an agent used to treat inflammation is physiologically significant if its presence alleviates at least a portion of the inflammatory response.
A pharmaceutical composition comprising <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> (or <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> analog or fusion protein) can be furnished in liquid form, in an aerosol, or in solid form.

Liquid forms, are illustrated by injectable solutions, aerosols, droplets, topological solutions and oral suspensions. Exemplary solid forms include capsules, tablets, and controlled-release forms. The latter form is illustrated by <RTI ID=0.0>miniosmotic</RTI> pumps and implants (Bremer et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Phare. Biotechnol. 10 : 239 (1997); Ranade, "Implants in Drug Delivery, "in Drug Delivery Systems, Ranade and Hollinger (eds. ), pages 95-123 (CRC Press 1995); Bremer et al.,"Protein Delivery with Infusion Pumps,"in Protein Delivery : Physical Systems, Sanders and Hendren (eds. ), pages 239-254 (Plenum Press 1997); Yewey et al.,"Delivery of Proteins from a Controlled Release Injectable Implant, "in Protein Delivery : Physical Systems, Sanders and Hendren (eds. ), pages 93- 117 (Plenum Press 1997) ). Other solid forms include creams, pastes, other topological applications, and the like.

Liposomes provide one means to deliver therapeutic polypeptides to a subject intravenously, intraperitoneally, intrathecally, intramuscularly, subcutaneously, or via oral administration, inhalation, or intranasal administration. Liposomes are microscopic vesicles that consist of one or more lipid bilayers surrounding aqueous compartments (see, generally, Bakker-Woudenberg et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Eur. J. Clin. <RTI ID=0.0>Microbiol.</RTI>

Infect. Dis. 12 (Suppl. 1) : S61 (1993), Kim, Drugs 46 : 618 (1993), and Ranade,"Site- Specific Drug Delivery Using Liposomes as <RTI ID=0.0>Carriers,"in</RTI> Drug Delivery Systems, Ranade and Hollinger (eds. ), pages 3-24 (CRC Press 1995) ). Liposomes are similar in composition to cellular membranes and as a result, liposomes can be administered safely and are biodegradable. Depending on the method of preparation, liposomes may be unilamellar or multilamellar, and liposomes can vary in size with diameters ranging
<Desc/Clms Page number 115>

from 0.02 <RTI ID=0.0>zm</RTI> to greater than 10 <RTI ID=0.0>um.</RTI> A variety of agents can be encapsulated in liposomes: hydrophobic agents partition in the bilayers and hydrophilic agents partition within the inner aqueous space (s) (see, for example, Machy et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Liposomes In Cell Biology And Pharmacology (John Libbey 1987), and Ostro et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> American J. Hosp.

<RTI ID=0.0>Pharm.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>46</RTI> : 1576 (1989) ). Moreover, it is possible to control the therapeutic availability of the encapsulated agent by varying liposome size, the number of bilayers, lipid composition, as well as the charge and surface characteristics of the liposomes.

Liposomes can adsorb to virtually any type of cell and then slowly release the encapsulated agent. Alternatively, an absorbed liposome may be endocytosed by cells that are phagocytic. Endocytosis is followed by intralysosomal degradation of liposomal lipids and release of the encapsulated agents (Scherphof et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. <RTI ID=0.0>446</RTI> : 368 (1985) ). After intravenous administration, small liposomes (0.1 to 1.0 <RTI ID=0.0>Zm)</RTI> are typically taken up by cells of the reticuloendothelial system, located principally in the liver and spleen, whereas liposomes larger than 3.0 um are deposited in the lung. This preferential uptake of smaller liposomes by the cells of the reticuloendothelial system has been used to deliver chemotherapeutic agents to macrophages and to tumors of the liver.

The reticuloendothelial system can be circumvented by several methods including saturation with large doses of liposome particles, or selective macrophage inactivation by pharmacological means (Claassen et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Biochim. Biophys. Acta <RTI ID=0.0>802</RTI> : 428 (1984) ). In addition, incorporation of glycolipid-or polyethelene glycol- derivatized phospholipids into liposome membranes has been shown to result in a significantly reduced uptake by the reticuloendothelial system (Allen et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Biochim.
Biophys. Acta 1068 : 133 (1991); Allen et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1150 : 9 (1993)).

Liposomes can also be prepared to target particular cells or organs by varying phospholipid composition or by inserting receptors or ligands into the liposomes. For example, liposomes, prepared with a high content of a nonionic surfactant, have been used to target the liver (Hayakawa et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Japanese Patent 04- 244,018 ; Kato et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Biol. <RTI ID=0.0>Pharm.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>Bull. 16</RTI> : 960 (1993) ). These formulations were prepared by mixing soybean phospatidylcholine, <RTI ID=0.0>oc-tocopherol,</RTI> and ethoxylated hydrogenated castor oil <RTI ID=0.0>(HCO-60)</RTI> in methanol, concentrating the mixture under
<Desc/Clms Page number 116>

vacuum, and then reconstituting the mixture with water. A liposomal formulation of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) with a soybean-derived sterylglucoside mixture (SG) and cholesterol (Ch) has also been shown to target the liver (Shimizu et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Biol. <RTI ID=0.0>Pharm.</RTI> Bull. 20: 881 <RTI ID=0.0>(1997)).</RTI>

Alternatively, various targeting ligands can be bound to the surface of the liposome, such as antibodies, antibody fragments, carbohydrates, vitamins, and transport proteins. For example, liposomes can be modified with branched type galactosyllipid derivatives to target asialoglycoprotein (galactose) receptors, which are exclusively expressed on the surface of liver cells (Kato and Sugiyama, Crit. Rev. <RTI ID=0.0>Ther.</RTI>
Drug Carrier Syst. 14 : 287 (1997); Murahashi et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Biol. Pharm. Bull. 20: 259 (1997)).

Similarly, Wu et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Hepatology 27: 772 (1998), have shown that labeling liposomes with asialofetuin led to a shortened liposome plasma half-life and greatly enhanced uptake of asialofetuin-labeled liposome by hepatocytes. On the other hand, hepatic accumulation of liposomes comprising branched type galactosyllipid derivatives can be inhibited by preinjection of asialofetuin (Murahashi et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Biol. <RTI ID=0.0>Pharm. Bull.</RTI> 20: 259 (1997) ). Polyaconitylated human serum albumin liposomes provide another approach for targeting liposomes to liver cells (Kamps et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Proc. <RTI ID=0.0>Nat'l</RTI> Acad. Sci. USA <RTI ID=0.0>94</RTI> : 11681 (1997) ). Moreover, Geho, et al. U. S. Patent No. 4,603, 044, describe a hepatocyte-directed liposome vesicle delivery system, which has specificity for hepatobiliary receptors associated with the specialized metabolic cells of the liver.

In a more general approach to tissue targeting, target cells are prelabeled with biotinylated antibodies specific for a ligand expressed by the target cell (Harasym et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Adv. Drug Deliv. Rev. <RTI ID=0.0>32</RTI> : 99 (1998) ). After plasma elimination of free antibody, streptavidin-conjugated liposomes are administered. In another approach, targeting antibodies are directly attached to liposomes (Harasym et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Adv. Drug Deliv. Rev.

Polypeptides having Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor binding activity can be encapsulated within liposomes using standard techniques of protein microencapsulation (see, for example, Anderson et al., Infect. Immun. 31 : 1099 (1981), Anderson et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Cancer <RTI ID=0.0>Res. 50</RTI> : 1853 (1990), and Cohen et al., Biochim. Biophys. Acta <RTI ID=0.0>1063</RTI> : 95 (1991), Alving et al."Preparation and Use of Liposomes in Immunological

Studies, "in Liposome Technology, 2nd Edition, Vol. <RTI ID=0.0>HI,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>Gregoriadis</RTI> (ed. ), page 317 (CRC Press 1993), Wassef et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Meth. Enzymol. 149 : 124 (1987) ). As noted above, therapeutically useful liposomes may contain a variety of components. For example, liposomes may comprise lipid derivatives of poly (ethylene <RTI ID=0.0>glycol) (Allen et al.,</RTI> Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1150 : 9 (1993)).

Degradable polymer microspheres have been designed to maintain high systemic levels of therapeutic proteins. Microspheres are prepared from degradable polymers such as poly (lactide-co-glycolide) (PLG), polyanhydrides, poly (ortho esters), nonbiodegradable ethylvinyl acetate polymers, in which proteins are entrapped in the polymer (Gombotz and Pettit, Bioconjugate Chem. 6: 332 (1995); Ranade, "Role of Polymers in Drug Delivery,"in Drug Delivery Systems, Ranade and Hollinger (eds. ), pages 51-93 (CRC Press 1995); Roskos and Maskiewicz, "Degradable Controlled Release Systems Useful for Protein Delivery,"in Protein Delivery : Physical Systems, Sanders and Hendren (eds. ), pages 45-92 (Plenum Press 1997); Bartus et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Science <RTI ID=0.0>281</RTI> : 1161 (1998); Putney and Burke, Nature Biotechnology <RTI ID=0.0>16</RTI> : 153 (1998); Putney, <RTI ID=0.0>Curr.</RTI> Opin. Chem. Biol. 2: 548 (1998) ). Polyethylene glycol (PEG) -coated nanospheres can also provide vehicles for intravenous administration of therapeutic proteins (see, for example, Gref et al., Pharm. Biotechnol. 10 : 167 (1997)).

The present invention also contemplates chemically modified polypeptides having binding Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor activity such as zcytorl7 multimeric receptor heterodimeric or multimeric soluble receptors, and Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor antagonists, for example anti-zcytorl7 multimeric receptor antibodies or binding polypeptides, which a polypeptide is linked with a polymer, as discussed above.

Other dosage forms can be devised by those skilled in the art, as shown, for example, by Ansel and Popovich, Pharmaceutical Dosage Forms and Drug Delivery <RTI ID=0.0>Systems, 5 Ih</RTI> Edition (Lea & Febiger 1990), Gennaro (ed.), Remington's Pharmaceutical Sciences, <RTI ID=0.0>19th</RTI> Edition (Mack Publishing Company 1995), and by Ranade and Hollinger, Drug Delivery Systems (CRC Press 1996).
As an illustration, pharmaceutical compositions may be supplied as a kit comprising a container that comprises a polypeptide with a Zcytorl7 multimeric
<Desc/Clms Page number 118>

receptor extracellular domain, e. g., zcytorl7 multimeric receptor heterodimeric or multimeric soluble receptors, or a Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor antagonist (e. g., a neutralizing antibody or antibody fragment that binds a Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor polypeptide). Therapeutic polypeptides can be provided in the form of an injectable solution for single or multiple doses, or as a sterile powder that will be reconstituted before injection. Alternatively, such a kit can include a dry-powder disperser, liquid aerosol generator, or nebulizer for administration of a therapeutic polypeptide. Such a kit may further comprise written information on indications and usage of the pharmaceutical composition. Moreover, such information may include a statement that the Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor composition is contraindicated in patients with known hypersensitivity to Zcytorl7 multimeric receptor.

EXAMPLES Example <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> Construction <RTI ID=0.0>of MPL-zcytorl 7 Polypeptide Chimera</RTI> : MPL Extracellular and TM Domain Fused <RTI ID=0.0>to the zcytorl 7 Intracellular Signaling Domain</RTI> The 5'extracellular domain of the murine MPL receptor was isolated from a plasmid containing the murine MPL receptor <RTI ID=0.0>(PHZ1/MPL</RTI> plasmid) by digestion with EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> generating a 1164 bp fragment. The digestion was run on a 1% agarose gel and the fragment was isolated using the Qiaquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen) as per manufacturer's instructions. The rest of the MPL extracellular domain and transmembrane domain were generated using PCR with primers ZC6, 673 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI>
<Desc/Clms Page number 119>

NO : 13) and ZC29,082 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 14). The reaction conditions were as follows: 15 <RTI ID=0.0> cycles at 94 C for 1 min. , 55 C for 1 min. , 72 C for 2 min.; followed by 72 C for 7</RTI> min.; then a <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> soak. The PCR product was run on a <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> agarose gel and the approximately 400bp MPL receptor fragment was isolated using <RTI ID=0.0>QiaquickTM</RTI> gel extraction kit (Qiagen) as per manufacturer's instructions.

The intracellular domain of human zcytorl7 was isolated from a plasmid containing zcytorl7 receptor cDNA (#23/pCAP) using PCR with primers ZC29,083 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 15) and ZC29,145 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 16). The polynucleotide sequence that corresponds to the zcytorl7 receptor coding sequence is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>5.</RTI> The reaction conditions were as per above. The PCR product was run on a 1% agarose gel and the approximately 320 bp zcytorl7 fragment isolated using Qiaquick gel extraction kit as per manufacturer's instructions.

Each of the isolated PCR fragments described above were mixed at a 1: 1 volumetric ratio and used in a PCR reaction using ZC6673 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 13) and ZC29145 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 16) to create all but the <RTI ID=0.0>5'MPL</RTI> portion of the MPL-zcytorl7 chimera. The reaction conditions were as follows: 15 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 1 min., <RTI ID=0.0>55 C</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0> for 1 min. , 72 C for 2 min.; followed by 72 C for 7 min.; then a 4 C soak. The entire</RTI> PCR product was run on a 1% agarose gel and the approximately 700bp MPL-zcytorl7 chimera fragment isolated using Qiaquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen) as per manufacturer's instructions. The MPL-zcytorl7 chimera fragment was digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> (BRL) and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI</RTI> (Boerhinger Mannheim) as per manufacturer's instructions.

The entire digest was run on a 1% agarose gel and the cleaved MPL-zcytorl7 chimera isolated using <RTI ID=0.0>QiaquickTM</RTI> gel extraction kit (Qiagen) as per manufacturer's instructions. The resultant cleaved <RTI ID=0.0>MPL-zvytorl7</RTI> chimera plus 5'MPL EcoRIBamHI fragment described above were inserted into an expression vector to generate the full MPL-zcytorl7 chimeric receptor as described below.
Recipient expression vector pZP-7 was digested with EcoRI (BRL) and Xbal (BRL) as per manufacturer's instructions, and gel purified as described above.

This vector fragment was combined with the EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI</RTI> cleaved MPL-zcytorl7 PCR chimera isolated above and the EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>5'MPL</RTI> fragment isolated above in a ligation reaction. The ligation was run using T4 Ligase (Epicentre
<Desc/Clms Page number 120>

Technologies), at room temperature for 1 hour as per manufacturer's instructions. A sample of the ligation was electroporated into <RTI ID=0.0>DH10B</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ElectroMAX</RTI> electrocompetent E. coli cells <RTI ID=0.0>(25ZF,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>200Q,</RTI> 1.8V). Transformants were plated on LB+Ampicillin plates and single colonies screened by miniprep (Qiagen) and digestion with EcoRI to check for the MPL-zcytorl7 chimera. EcoRI digestion of correct clones yield about a 2kb fragment. Confirmation of the MPL-zcytorl7 chimera sequence was made by sequence analyses. The insert was approximately 3.1 kb, and was full-length.

Construction <RTI ID=0.0>of BaF3 Cells Expressing MPL-zcytorl 7 chimera</RTI> BaF3, an interleukin-3 <RTI ID=0.0>(IL-3)</RTI> dependent pre-lymphoid cell line derived from murine bone marrow (Palacios and Steinmetz, Cell 41 : 727-734,1985 ; MatheyPrevot et al., Mol. Cell. Biol. 6: 4133-4135,1986), was maintained in complete media (RPMI medium (JRH <RTI ID=0.0>Bioscience</RTI> Inc. , Lenexa, KS) supplemented with 10% heatinactivated fetal calf serum, 1-2 ng/ml murine <RTI ID=0.0>IL-3</RTI> (mIL-3) (R & D, Minneapolis, MN), 2mM <RTI ID=0.0>L-glutaMax-1TM</RTI> (Gibco BRL), <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> mM Sodium Pyruvate (Gibco BRL), and PSN antibiotics <RTI ID=0.0>(GIBCO</RTI> BRL) ). BaF3 cells for electroporation were washed twice in RPMI media and then resuspended in RPMI media at a cell density of <RTI ID=0.0>107</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>cells/ml.</RTI> One ml of resuspended BaF3 cells was mixed with 30 <RTI ID=0.0>ug</RTI> of the pZP-7/MPL-zcytorl7 plasmid DNA and transferred to separate disposable electroporation chambers (GIBCO BRL).

At room temperature cells were given <RTI ID=0.0>5x.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>lmsec</RTI> shocks at 800 volts followed by <RTI ID=0.0>5x2ms</RTI> shocks at 600 volts delivered by an electroporation apparatus (Cyto-Pulse).

The electroporated cells were transferred to 50 ml of complete media and placed in an incubator for 15-24 hours <RTI ID=0.0>(37 C,</RTI> 5% C02). Then Geneticin (Gibco) selection (lmg/ml G418) was added to the cells in a T-162 flask to isolate the G418-resistant pool. Pools of the transfected BaF3 cells, hereinafter called
<Desc/Clms Page number 121>
BaF3/MPL-zcytorl7 cells, were assayed for signaling capability as described below.

B. <RTI ID=0.0>Testing the signaling capability of the BaF3/MPL-zcytorl7 cells using</RTI> an Alamar Blue Proliferation Assay BaF3/MPL-zcytorl7 cells were spun down and washed in the complete media, described above, but without mIL-3 (hereinafter referred to <RTI ID=0.0>as"mIL-3</RTI> free media"). The cells were spun and washed 3 times to ensure the removal of the <RTI ID=0.0>mIL-3.</RTI> Cells were then counted in a hemacytometer. Cells were plated in a 96-well format at 5000 cells per well in a volume of 100 <RTI ID=0.0>Zl</RTI> per well using the <RTI ID=0.0>mIL-3</RTI> free media.

Proliferation of the BaF3/MPL-zcytorl7 cells was assessed using murine thrombopoietin (mTPO) diluted with mIL-3 free media to 200 ng/ml, <RTI ID=0.0>100ng/ml,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>50ng/ml,</RTI> 25ng/ml, <RTI ID=0.0>12.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>5ng/ml,</RTI> 6.25ng/ml, 3. <RTI ID=0.0>lng/ml,</RTI> 1.5 <RTI ID=0.0>ng/ml</RTI> concentrations. One hundred microliters of the diluted <RTI ID=0.0>mTPO</RTI> was added to the <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/MPL-zcytorl7</RTI> cells.

The total assay volume was 200 <RTI ID=0.0>il.</RTI> Negative controls were run in parallel using <RTI ID=0.0>mIL-3</RTI> free media only, without the addition of <RTI ID=0.0>mTPO.</RTI> The assay plates were incubated at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C,</RTI> 5% C02 for 3 days at which time Alamar Blue (Accumed, Chicago, IL) was added at <RTI ID=0.0>20, u1/well.</RTI> Alamar Blue gives a fluorometric readout based on the metabolic activity of cells, and is thus a direct measurement of cell proliferation in comparison to a negative control. Plates were again incubated at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C,</RTI> 5% <RTI ID=0.0>CO2</RTI> for 24 hours. Plates were read on the <RTI ID=0.0>FmaxTM</RTI> plate reader (Molecular Devices Sunnyvale, CA) using the <RTI ID=0.0>SoftMaxTM</RTI> Pro program, at wavelengths 544 (Excitation) and 590 (Emission), or a Wallac Victor 2 plate reader <RTI ID=0.0>(PerkinElmer</RTI> Life Sciences, Boston, MA).

Results confirmed the signaling capability of the intracellular portion of the zcytorl7 receptor, as the thrombopoietin induced proliferation at approximately 9- 13 fold over background at <RTI ID=0.0>mTPO</RTI> concentrations of 50ng/ml and greater.

Example 3 Construction of Expression Vector <RTI ID=0.0>Expressing Full-length zcytorl 7 : pZp7pX/zcytorl 7</RTI> A. Cloning <RTI ID=0.0>offull length zcytorl 7 cDNA for expression :</RTI> To obtain a full-length zcytorl7 <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA,</RTI> 5'and 3'PCR products were isolated and joined using an internal PstI site. The PCR primers were designed using
<Desc/Clms Page number 122>
the nucleotide sequence SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 4 and include BamHI and Xho I restriction sites for cloning purposes.

A 5'PCR product was generated using a WI-38 cDNA library as a template and oligonucleotides ZC29,359 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 18) and ZC27, 899 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 19) as primers. WI-38 is an in-house cDNA library generated from a human embryonic lung cell line (ATCC CRL-2221). This 5'PCR reaction was run as follows: 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 1 minute, <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 2 minutes, then <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>10 C</RTI> soak. The PCR reaction used approximately <RTI ID=0.0>3</RTI> ug of plasmid prepared from the cDNA library, 20 pmoles of each oligonucleotide, and five units of PWO DNA polymerase (Roche). About 90% of the 5'PCR product was ethanol precipitated, digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> and PstI and gel purified on a 1.0% agarose gel. The approximately 600 bp band was excised and used for ligation to the cloning vector <RTI ID=0.0>pUC18</RTI> digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> and PstI. The resulting transformants were sequenced to confirm the zcytorl7 cDNA sequence. For one of these transformants, plasmid DNA was prepared and digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> and PstI. The resulting approximately 600 bp band was gel purified and used for a ligation below to form a full-length <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA.</RTI>

A 3'PCR product was generated using a human testes in-house cDNA library as a template and oligonucleotides ZC27, 895 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 20) and ZC29, 122 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 21) as primers. This 3'PCR reaction was run as follows: 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 </RTI> C for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 2 minutes, then <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes; 10 <RTI ID=0.0> C</RTI> soak. The entire 3'PCR reaction was gel purified on a 1.0% agarose gel and the major 1500 bp band excised. This band was cloned into the PCR Blunt <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> TOPO vector using the Zeroblunt TOPO kit (Invitrogen). The resulting transformants were sequenced to confirm the zcytorl7 cDNA sequence. For one of these transformants, plasmid DNA was prepared and digested with PstI and Xhol. The resulting approximately 1500 bp band was gel purified. A three-part ligation was performed with the <RTI ID=0.0>5'BamHI</RTI> to Pst I fragment above, the 3'PstI to Xhol fragment, and the expression vector pZp7pX digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> and Xhol. This generated a pZp7pX plasmid containing a full-length cDNA for zcytorl7 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 4), designated pZp7p/zcytorl7. The full length zcytorl7 cDNA in pZp7p/zcytorl7 has a silent mutation that changes the T to G at position 1888 of SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 4 (encoding a Gly
<Desc/Clms Page number 123>

residue at residue 464 of SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>5).</RTI> As this mutation is silent, the zcytorl7 cDNA in pZp7p/zcytorl7 encodes the polypeptide as shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>5.</RTI> Plasmid pZp7pX is a mammalian expression vector containing an expression cassette having the CMV promoter, intron A, multiple restriction sites for insertion of coding sequences, and a human growth hormone terminator. The plasmid also has an E. coli origin of replication, a mammalian selectable marker expression unit having an SV40 promoter, enhancer and origin of replication, a puromycin resistance gene and the SV40 terminator.

B. Construction of Expression Vector Expressing Full-Length WSX-1 The entire <RTI ID=0.0>WSX-1</RTI> receptor (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 9) was isolated from a plasmid containing the WSX-1 receptor cDNA (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 8) (United States Patent No.

5,925, 735). <RTI ID=0.0>hWSX-1/pBluescript</RTI> SK (+) plasmid DNA (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) was digested with EcoRI and Xhol to generate a 1075 bp fragment, and also digested with Xhol and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI</RTI> to generate a 900 bp fragment. Both digests were run on a <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> agarose gel and the cleaved <RTI ID=0.0>WSX-1</RTI> fragments isolated.

Recipient expression vector pZp7Z was digested with EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI</RTI> and gel purified as described above. This vector fragment was combined with the two cleaved zcytorl7 fragments isolated above in a ligation reaction using T4 Ligase (BRL).

The ligation was incubated at room temperature overnight. A sample of the ligation was electroporated in to <RTI ID=0.0>DH10B</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>electroMAX</RTI> electrocompetent E. coli cells (25uF, <RTI ID=0.0>200Q,</RTI> 2.3V). Six colonies were grown in culture and miniprepped DNA was prepared and digested to confirm the correct WSX-1 full-length insert of 2.0 kb. The resulting plasmid is pZPZ7Z/WSX-l.

response, as measured, was approximately 10-fold over background at the 25% concentration. The untransfected BaF3 cells did not proliferate in response to this factor, nor did BaF3 cells transfected with zcytorl7 and WSX-1 <RTI ID=0.0>(BaF3/zcytorl7/WXS-</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cells), showing that this factor was specific for <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl7/OSMRbeta</RTI> or <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/OSMRbeta/WSX-1</RTI> receptors. Similar results are expected in <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/zcytorl7/OSMRbeta</RTI> cells.
C. Human <RTI ID=0.0>Primary Source used to isolate zcytorl7lig</RTI> One hundred milliliters blood draws were taken from each of six donors.

The blood was drawn using 10X 10 ml vacutainer tubes containing heparin. Blood was pooled from six donors <RTI ID=0.0>(600ml),</RTI> diluted 1: 1 in PBS, and separated using a Ficoll- Paquet PLUS (Pharmacia Biotech). The isolated primary human cell yield after separation on the ficoll gradient was 1. <RTI ID=0.0>2X109</RTI> cells.

Cells were suspended in 9.6 ml MACS buffer (PBS, 0.5% EDTA, <RTI ID=0.0>2mM</RTI> EDTA). 1.6 ml of cell suspension was removed and 0.4 ml CD3 microbeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Auburn, CA) added. The mixture was incubated for 15 min. at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI> These cells labeled with CD3 beads were washed with 30 ml MACS buffer, and then resuspended in 2 ml MACS buffer.

A VS+ column (Miltenyi) was prepared according to the manufacturer's instructions. The VS+ column was then placed in a <RTI ID=0.0>VarioMACSTM</RTI> magnetic field (Miltenyi). The column was equilibrated with 5 ml MACS buffer. The isolated primary human cells were then applied to the column. The CD3 negative cells were allowed to pass through. The column was rinsed with 9 ml (3 X 3 ml) MACS buffer. The column was then removed from the magnet and placed over a 15 ml falcon tube. CD3+ cells were eluted by adding 5 ml MACS buffer to the column and bound cells flushed out using the plunger provided by the manufacturer. The incubation of the cells with the CD3 magnetic beads, washes, and VS+ column steps (incubation through elution) above were repeated five more times. The resulting CD3+ fractions from the six column separations were pooled. The yield of CD3+ selected human cells were <RTI ID=0.0>3X108</RTI>
<Desc/Clms Page number 128>
total cells.
A sample of the pooled CD3+ selected human cells was removed for staining and sorting on a fluorescent antibody cell sorter (FACS) to assess their purity.
The human CD3+ selected cells were <RTI ID=0.0>91%</RTI> CD3+ cells.
The human CD3+ selected cells were activated by incubating in RPMI + 5% FBS + PMA 10 ng/ml and Ionomycin 0.5 <RTI ID=0.0>Zg/ml</RTI> (Calbiochem) for 13 hours <RTI ID=0.0>37 C.</RTI>

The supernatant from these activated CD3+ selected human cells was tested for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> activity as described below. Moreover, the activated CD3+ selected human cells were used to prepare a cDNA library, as described in Example 6, below.

Example 6 <RTI ID=0.0>Cloning of human zcytorl7lig from a human</RTI> CD3+ selected cell Library Screening of a primary human activated CD3+ selected cell cDNA library revealed an isolated cDNA that is a novel member of the four-helix bundle cytokine family. This cDNA encoded the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig.</RTI> The cDNA was identified by screening for activity of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> using the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/WSX-l/OSM</RTI> receptors.

A. The vector for CD3+ selected library construction The vector for CD3+ selected library construction was pZP7NX. The pZP7NX vector was constructed as follows: The coding region for the DHFR selective marker in vector pZP7 was removed by DNA digestion with NcoI and PstI restriction enzymes (Boehringer Mannheim). The digested DNA was run on <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> agarose gel, cut out and gel purified using the Qiagen Gel Extraction Kit (Qiagen) as per manufacturer's instructions. A DNA fragment representing the coding region of Zeocin selective marker was amplified by PCR method with primers ZC13,946 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 28) and ZC13,945 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 29), and pZeoSV2 (+) as a template. There are additional PstI and Bell restriction sites in primer <RTI ID=0.0>ZC13,</RTI> 946 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 28), and additional NcoI and SfuI sites in primer ZC13, 945 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 29). The PCR fragment was cut with PstI and NcoI restriction enzymes and cloned into pZP7 vector prepared by cleaving with the same two enzymes and subsequent gel purification. This vector was named pZP7Z. Then the Zeocin coding region was removed by DNA digestion of vector pZP7Z with Bell and SfuI restriction enzymes. The digested DNA was run on <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> agarose gel, cut out and gel purified, and then ligated with a DNA fragment of Neomycin coding region cut from pZem228 vector (deposited at the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC), Manassas, VA; ATCC Deposit No. 69446) with the same restriction enzymes (Bell and SfuI).

This new vector was named pZP7N, in which the coding region for <RTI ID=0.0>DHFR</RTI> selective marker was replaced by the coding region for a Neomycin selective marker from vector pZem228. A stuffer fragment including an Xhol site was added to
<Desc/Clms Page number 130>

pZP7N to create a vector suitable for high efficiency directional cloning of cDNA ; this new vector was called pZP7NX. To prepare the vector for <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>20zig</RTI> of pZP7NX was digested with 20 units of EcoRl (Life Technologies Gaithersberg, MD) and 20 units of Xhol (Boehringer Mannheim Indianapolis, IN) for 5 hours at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C,</RTI> then <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> for 15 minutes. The digest was then run on a 0.8% low melt agarose <RTI ID=0.0>1XTAE</RTI> gel to separate the stuffer from the vector. The vector band was excised and digested with "beta-Agarase" (New England Biolabs, Beverly, <RTI ID=0.0>MA)</RTI> following the manufacturer's recommendations. After ethanol precipitation the digested vector was resuspended in water to 45ng/ml in preparation for ligation of CD3+ selected cDNA library described below.

Example 7 Expression Cloning of <RTI ID=0.0>human zcytorl7lig</RTI> The glycerol stocks from the activated human CD3+ selected cell library (Example 6) were added to Super Broth <RTI ID=0.0>IITM</RTI> (Becton Dickinson, Cockeysville, MD) + 0.1 mg/ml ampicillin (amp) at a concentration of 250 cells per 800 microliters. The E. coli were allowed to equilibrate for 24 hours at room temperature. At the time of inoculation, 400 microliters was plated on LB + amp plates to determine the actual titer of the inoculation. After 24 hours the plates were counted and then the final concentration of the SuperBroth + E. coli was adjusted so that the final concentration was 250 cells per 1.2 ml. Three times 2 liters were inoculated for a total of 6 liters. The media were then plated into <RTI ID=0.0>96-well</RTI> deep well blocks (Qiagen). Plating was done on the <RTI ID=0.0>8-channel Q-Fill2TM</RTI> dispenser (Genetix, Christchurch, Dorset, UK).

The E. coli were grown overnight at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C</RTI> shaking at 250 rotations/min. on a New Brunswick Scientific Innova 4900 multi-tier environment shaker. The E. coli were spun out of solution at 3000 rpm, using a Beckman GS-6KR centrifuge. These E. coli pellets were frozen <RTI ID=0.0>at-20 C</RTI> or used fresh before miniprepping the plasmid DNA. Each pellet contains approximately 250 cDNA clones from the human CD3+ selected cell library.

These pools of 250 cDNA clones were then mini-prepped using <RTI ID=0.0>QIAprepTM</RTI> 96 Turbo Miniprep kit (Qiagen). Plasmid DNA was eluted using 125 RI of TE (10 mM Tris pH 8,1 mM EDTA). This plasmid DNA was then used to transfect BHK cells.

BHK transfection BHK cells were plated in <RTI ID=0.0>96-well</RTI> tissue culture plates at a density of 12,000 cells per well in a volume of 100 l. per well. Culture media was DMEM (GibcoBRL), 5% <RTI ID=0.0>heat-inactivated fetal</RTI> bovine serum, 2 mM L-glutamine (GibcoBRL), <RTI ID=0.0>1X</RTI> PSN (GibcoBRL), <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> mM NaPyruvate (GibcoBRL).

The following day, BHK cells were washed once with 100 <RTI ID=0.0>ZI</RTI> SFA. SFA is serum-free media which is <RTI ID=0.0>DMEM/F12</RTI> or DMEM <RTI ID=0.0>(Gibco/BRL),</RTI> 2 mM <RTI ID=0.0>GlutaMaxTM</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>(Gibco/BRL),</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> mM NaPyruvate, 10 g/ml transferrin, 5 g/ml insulin, 10 g/ml fetuin, <RTI ID=0.0>2</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ug/ml</RTI> selenium, 25mM HEPES (Gibco/BRL), 100 <RTI ID=0.0>FM</RTI> non-essential amino acids <RTI ID=0.0>(Gibco/BRL).</RTI>

A <RTI ID=0.0>DNA/LipofectamineTM</RTI> mix was made as follows: 2. <RTI ID=0.0>2</RTI> l Lipofectamine reagent (Gibco/BRL) was combined with 102. <RTI ID=0.0>8</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ul</RTI> SFA at room temperature; approximately <RTI ID=0.0>5</RTI> RI of the plasmid DNA (200 ng/ l) was then added to the <RTI ID=0.0>LipofectamineTM/SFA</RTI> to form the <RTI ID=0.0>DNA/LipofectamineTM</RTI> mixture, which was incubated at room temperature for 30 minutes. The SFA was removed from the BHK cells and the cells were incubated with 50 <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> of the <RTI ID=0.0>DNA/lipofectamineTM</RTI> mix for 5 hours at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C</RTI> with <RTI ID=0.0>5%</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>C02.</RTI> Fifty <RTI ID=0.0>Zl</RTI> of the <RTI ID=0.0>DNA/LipofectamineTM</RTI> mixture was added to each of two wells of the BHK cells, so that transfections were done in duplicate.

After BHK cells were incubated with <RTI ID=0.0>DNA/LipofectamineTM</RTI> mix for <RTI ID=0.0>5</RTI> hours, the <RTI ID=0.0>DNA/LipofectamineTM</RTI> mix was removed and <RTI ID=0.0>100</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ul</RTI> culture media was added. Cells were incubated overnight, the media was removed and replaced with 100 <RTI ID=0.0>1.</RTI> culture media. After culturing cells for 48-72 hours, conditioned media was removed, frozen <RTI ID=0.0>at-80 C</RTI> for a minimum of 20 minutes, thawed, and then <RTI ID=0.0>50 gui</RTI> was assayed in the Baf3 proliferation assay, described in Example 5, to identify pools of 250 clones with ligand activity.

Twenty 96-well plates were screened in a single assay. This represented approximately 250 cDNAs/well or 480,000 cDNAs total. Of these, conditioned media from approximately 60 wells (representing 250 cDNAs per well) tested positive in the proliferation assay. One of these positive pools was chosen to break down and isolate a single cDNA that would encode the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig.</RTI> This was pool <RTI ID=0.0>62A12.</RTI>
<Desc/Clms Page number 136>

For <RTI ID=0.0>pool 62A12, 1 1ll.</RTI> of DNA was used to transform <RTI ID=0.0>ElectroMaxTM</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>DHIOB</RTI> cells (Gibco/BRL) by electroporation. The transformants were plated on LB + amp <RTI ID=0.0>(100</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ug/ml)</RTI> plates to give single colonies. From the electroporated pool, 672 individual colonies were selected by toothpick into seven 96-well plates containing 1.2 mi of <RTI ID=0.0>SuperBrothII</RTI> per well. These plates were numbered #62. 1 through #62. 7.

These were cultured overnight and the plasmid DNA miniprepped as above. For all seven plates, plasmid DNA from the breakdown plates was transfected into BHK cells and assayed by proliferation as above, except that transfections were not done in duplicate.

Two positive clones 62.6C7 and 62.6E9 were identified by activity from a total of 672 clones. Plasmid DNA miniprepped from clone 62.6E9 was sequenced and a tentative identification was obtained, but a mixed sequence was obtained from this positive clones. To further isolate the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> cDNA to a single clone, <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>all</RTI> of DNA from pool 62.6E9 was used to electroporate <RTI ID=0.0>DH10B</RTI> cells and the transformants plated on LB + amp (100 <RTI ID=0.0>Fg/ml)</RTI> plates to give single colonies. Plasmid DNA miniprepped from several colonies was sequenced to give the exact DNA sequence.

The polynucleotide sequence of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> was full-length (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>1)</RTI> and its corresponding amino acid sequence is shown (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 2).

Example <RTI ID=0.0>8</RTI> Construction of Mammalian <RTI ID=0.0>Expression Vectors That Express zcytorl 7 Soluble</RTI> Receptors : <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 7CEE, zcytorl 7CFLG, zcytorl 7CHIS and zcytorl 7-Fc4</RTI> A. <RTI ID=0.0>Construction of zcytorl 7 Mammalian Expression Vector containing zcytorl 7CEE,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 7CFLG and zcytorl 7CHIS</RTI> An expression vector was prepared for the expression of the soluble, extracellular domain of the zcytorl7 polypeptide, pZp9zcytorl7CEE, where the construct is designed to express a zcytorl7 polypeptide comprised of the predicted initiating methionine and truncated adjacent to the predicted transmembrane domain, and with a C-terminal Glu-Glu tag (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 32).
An approximately 1500 bp PCR product was generated using ZC29, 451 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 33) and ZC29, 124 (SEQ ID NO : 34) as PCR primers to add EcoRI and
<Desc/Clms Page number 137>

<RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> restriction sites. A human <RTI ID=0.0>HPVS</RTI> in-house cDNA library was used as a template and PCR amplification was performed as follows : 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute, <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 1.5 minutes, then <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>10 C</RTI> soak.

The PCR reaction was ethanol precipitated and digested with EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> restriction enzymes. The digested PCR product was gel purified on a 1.0% agarose gel and the approximately 1500 bp band excised. This band was then re-amplified using identical primers with the following cycling: 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 1 minute, <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 3 minutes, then <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>10 C</RTI> soak. The PCR reaction was ethanol precipitated and digested with EcoRI and BamHI restriction enzymes. The digested PCR product was gel purified on a 1.0% agarose gel and the approximately 1500 bp band excised. The excised DNA was subcloned into plasmid CEEpZp9 that had been cut with EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI,</RTI> to generate plasmid with a GLU-GLU <RTI ID=0.0>C-</RTI> terminally tagged soluble receptor for zcytorl7, zcytorl7CEEpZp9. The extracellular domain in the zcytorl7CEE cDNA in zcytorl7CEEpZp9 has a silent mutation that changes the T to C at position 1705 of SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 4 (encoding a Pro residue at residue 403 of SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 5). As this mutation is silent, the zcytorl7 cDNA in zcytorl7CEEpZp9 encodes the polypeptide as shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>5.</RTI> Moreover, because of the construct used, a Gly-Ser residue pair is inserted C-terminal to the end of the soluble, extracellular domain of zcytorl7 and prior to the C-terminal Glu-Glu Tag (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 32). As such, the tag at the C-terminus of the zcytorl7 extracellular domain, was a Glu-Glu tag as shown in (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 17). Plasmid CEEpZp9 is a mammalian expression vector containing an expression cassette having the mouse metallothionein-1 promoter, multiple restriction sites for insertion of coding sequences, and a human growth hormone terminator. The plasmid also has an E. coli origin of replication, a mammalian selectable marker expression unit having an SV40 promoter, enhancer and origin of replication, a <RTI ID=0.0>DHFR</RTI> gene and the SV40 terminator. Using standard molecular biological techniques zcytorl7CEEpZp9 was electroporated into <RTI ID=0.0>DH10B</RTI> competent cells <RTI ID=0.0>(GIBCO</RTI> BRL, Gaithersburg, MD) according to manufacturer's direction and plated onto LB plates containing 100 <RTI ID=0.0>Zg/ml</RTI> ampicillin, and incubated overnight. Colonies were screened by restriction analysis, or PCR from DNA prepared from individual colonies. The insert sequence of positive clones was verified by
<Desc/Clms Page number 138>
sequence analysis. A large scale plasmid preparation was done using a <RTI ID=0.0>QIAGENO</RTI> Maxi prep kit (Qiagen) according to manufacturer's instructions.

The same process is used to prepare the zcytorl7 soluble receptors with a C-terminal his tag, composed of 6 His residues in a row; and a <RTI ID=0.0>C-terminal FLAG@</RTI> tag (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 36), zcytorl7CFLAG. To construct these constructs, the aforementioned vector has either the HIS or the <RTI ID=0.0>FLAG@ </RTI> tag in place of the glu-glu tag (e. g. , SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 17; SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 32 or SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 35).

B. Mammalian <RTI ID=0.0>Expression Construction of Soluble human zcytorl 7 receptor :</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 7-Fc4</RTI> An expression vector, pEZE-2 hzcytorl7/Fc4, was prepared to express a C-terminally Fc4 tagged soluble version of hzcytorl7 (human zcytorl7-Fc4) in PF CHO cells. PF CHO cells are an in house CHO cell line adapted for growth in protein- free medium (ExCell 325 PF medium; JRH Biosciences). The in house CHO cell line was originally derived from CHO DG44 cells (G. Urlaub, J. Mitchell, E. Kas, L. A.

Chasin, V. L. Funanage, T. T. Myoda and J. L. Hamlin, "The Effect Of Gamma Rays at the Dihydrofolate Reductase Locus : Deletions and Inversions, "Somatic Cell and Molec. Genet., 12 : 555-566 (1986). A fragment of zcytorl7 cDNA that includes the polynucleotide sequence from extracellular domain of the zcytorl7 receptor was fused in frame to the Fc4 polynucleotide sequence (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 37) to generate a zcytorl7- Fc4 fusion (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 38 and SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 39). The pEZE-2 vector is a mammalian expression vector that contains the Fc4 polynucleotide sequence and a cloning site that allows rapid construction of C-terminal Fc4 fusions using standard molecular biology techniques.

A 1566 base pair fragment was generated by PCR, containing the extracellular domain of human zcytorl7 and the first two amino acids of Fc4 (Glu and Pro) with FseI and <RTI ID=0.0>BglII</RTI> sites coded on the 5'and 3'ends, respectively. This PCR fragment was generated using primers ZC29, 157 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 40) and ZC29, 150 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 41) by amplification from a plasmid containing the extracellular domain of human zcytorl7 (pZp9zcytorl7CEE) (Example 8). The PCR reaction conditions were as follows: 25 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 1 minute, <RTI ID=0.0>60 C</RTI> for 1 minute, and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 2 minutes;
<Desc/Clms Page number 139>

<RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 10 minutes; followed by a <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> soak. The fragment was digested with FseI and <RTI ID=0.0>BglII</RTI> restriction endonucleases and subsequently purified by 1% gel electrophoresis and band purification using QiaQuick gel extraction kit (Qiagen). The resulting purified DNA was ligated for 5 hours at room temperature into a pEZE-2 vector previously digested with FseI and <RTI ID=0.0>BglII</RTI> containing Fc4 3'of the FseI and <RTI ID=0.0>BglII</RTI> sites.

Two ul of the ligation mix was electroporated in <RTI ID=0.0>37, ul DH1OB</RTI> electrocompetent E. coli (Gibco) according to the manufacturer's directions. The transformed cells were diluted in <RTI ID=0.0>400</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>gl</RTI> of LB media and plated onto LB plates containing 100 <RTI ID=0.0>Zg/ml</RTI> ampicillin. Clones were analyzed by restriction digests and positive clones were sent for DNA sequencing to confirm the sequence of the fusion construct. 1 RI of a positive clone was transformed into 37 Ri <RTI ID=0.0>of DH1OB</RTI> electrocompetent E. coli and streaked on a LB/amp plate. A single colony was picked from this streaked plate to start a 250 ml LB/amp culture that was then grown overnight at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C</RTI> with shaking at 250 rpm. This culture was used to generate 750 <RTI ID=0.0>Rg</RTI> of purified DNA using a Qiagen plasmid Maxi kit (Qiagen).

Example <RTI ID=0.0>10</RTI> Purification of zcytorl 7 soluble receptors from BHK 570 and CHO cells A. <RTI ID=0.0>Transient mammalian expression and purification of soluble human zcytorl 7-Fc4</RTI> receptor <RTI ID=0.0>pEZE-2hzcytorl7Fc4</RTI> plasmid DNA (Example <RTI ID=0.0>11B)</RTI> was introduced into 40 maxi plates of BHK cells using Lipofectamine (Gibco BRL) as described herein and in manufacturer's instructions. Cells were allowed to recover overnight, then were rinsed and refed with serum-free medium (SL7V4, made in-house). After 72 hours, the media was collected and filtered, and cells were refed with serum-free medium. After 72 hours, the media was again collected and filtered.

The serum-free conditioned media (2 x 1.5 L batches) from transiently transfected BHK cells was pumped over a 1.5 ml Protein A-agarose column in 20 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 0.5 M NaCI. The column was washed extensively with this buffer and then the bound protein was eluted with 1 ml of 0.2 M glycine, pH 2.5, 0.5 M <RTI ID=0.0>NaCI.</RTI>
The eluted protein was collected into 0.1 ml of 2 M Tris, pH 8.5.

Aliquots were collected for SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and the bulk zcytorl7-Fc was dialyzed overnight against PBS. The soluble receptor was sterile filtered and placed in aliquots <RTI ID=0.0>at-80 C.</RTI>

B. <RTI ID=0.0>Purification of zcytorl 7-Fc4</RTI> Recombinant carboxyl terminal Fc4 tagged zcytorl7 (Example 8 and Example 9) was produced from transfected CHO cells. The CHO transfection was performed using methods known in the art. Approximately five-liters of conditioned media were harvested and sterile filtered using Nalgene 0. <RTI ID=0.0>2jnm</RTI> filters.
Protein was purified from the filtered media by a combination of Poros
<Desc/Clms Page number 143>

50 protein A affinity chromatography (PerSeptive Biosystems, <RTI ID=0.0>1-5559-01,</RTI> Framingham, MA) and Superdex 200 gel exclusion chromatography column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, Piscataway, NJ). Culture medium was directly loaded onto a <RTI ID=0.0>10x70mm</RTI> (5.5- ml bed volume) protein A affinity column at a flow of about 3-10 ml/minute.

Following column washing for ten column volumes of PBS, bound protein was eluted by five column volumes of 0.1 M glycine, pH 3.0 at 10 ml/minute). Fractions of 2 ml each were collected into tubes containing <RTI ID=0.0>100, ut</RTI> of 2.0 M Tris, pH 8.0, in order to neutralize the eluted proteins. Samples from the affinity column were analyzed by SDS-PAGE with coomassie staining and Western blotting for the presence of zcytorl7- Fc4 using human <RTI ID=0.0>Ig-HRP.</RTI> Zcytorl7-Fc4-containing fractions were pooled and concentrated to 1-2 ml using Biomax-30 concentrator (Millipore), and loaded onto a <RTI ID=0.0>20x580</RTI> mm Superdex 200 gel filtration column. The fractions containing purified zcytorl7-Fc4 were pooled, filtered through 0.2 <RTI ID=0.0>ym</RTI> filter, aliquoted into 100 <RTI ID=0.0>lil</RTI> each, and frozen <RTI ID=0.0>at-80 C.</RTI> The concentration of the final purified protein was determined by BCA assay (Pierce, Rockford, <RTI ID=0.0>IL).</RTI>

C. SDS-PAGE and Western blotting analysis of zcytorl 7/Fc4 Recombinant zcytorl7-Fc4 was analyzed by SDS-PAGE (Nupage 4- 12%, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) with coomassie staining method and Western blotting using human <RTI ID=0.0>Ig-HRP.</RTI> Either the conditioned media or purified protein was electrophoresed using an Invitrogen Novex's Xcell <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> mini-cell, and transferred to nitrocellulose (0.2 mm; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) at room temperature using Novex's <RTI ID=0.0>Xcell II</RTI> blot module with stirring according to directions provided in the instrument manual. The transfer was run at 500 mA for one hour in a buffer containing 25 mM Tris base, 200 mM glycine, and 20% methanol. The filters were then blocked with 10% non-fat dry milk in PBS for 10 minutes at room temperature. The nitrocellulose was quickly rinsed, then the human <RTI ID=0.0>Ig-HRP</RTI> antibody (1: 2000) was added in PBS containing 2.5% non-fat dry milk. The blots were incubated for two hours at room temperature, or overnight at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C,</RTI> with gentle shaking. Following the incubation, the blots were washed three times for 10 minutes each in PBS, then quickly rinsed in <RTI ID=0.0>H20.</RTI>
The blots were developed using commercially available chemiluminescent substrate
<Desc/Clms Page number 144>

reagents <RTI ID=0.0>(SuperSignal0</RTI> ULTRA reagents <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> and 2 mixed 1: 1; reagents obtained from Pierce, Rockford, <RTI ID=0.0>IL),</RTI> and the signal was captured using Lumi-Imager's Lumi Analyst 3.0 software (Boehringer Mannheim GmbH, Germany) for exposure times ranging from 10 second to 5 minutes or as necessary.

The purified zcytorl7-Fc4 appeared as a single band with either the coomassie or silver staining at about 220 kDa under non-reducing conditions, and at about 120 kDa under reducing conditions, suggesting the dimeric form of zcytorl7-Fc4 under non-reducing conditions as expected.

Example <RTI ID=0.0>11</RTI> Assay using <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 7 soluble receptor zcytorl 7-Fc4 Soluble receptor in competitive</RTI> inhibition assay <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/zcytorl7/WSX-1/OSMRbeta</RTI> cells or <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/zcytorl7/OSMRbeta</RTI> cells were spun down and washed in mIL-3 free media. The cells were spun and washed 3 times to ensure the removal of the mIL-3. Cells were then counted in a hemacytometer. Cells were plated in a 96-well format at 5000 cells per well in a volume of 100 <RTI ID=0.0>u,</RTI> per well using the <RTI ID=0.0>mIL-3</RTI> free media.

Both conditioned media from the CCRF-CEM and CCRF-HSB2 cell activation and the human CD3+ selected cells, described in Example 5, were added in separate experiments at 25%, 12.5%, 6.25%, 3.125%, 1. <RTI ID=0.0>5%,</RTI> 0. <RTI ID=0.0>75%,</RTI> 0.375%, and 0.187 % concentrations, with or without zcytorl7 soluble receptors (Zcytorl7-Fc4; See, Example 9 and Example 10) at 1-10 <RTI ID=0.0>, g/ml.</RTI> The total assay volume was 200 <RTI ID=0.0>1.</RTI>

The assay plates were incubated at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C,</RTI> 5% C02 for 3-5 days at which time Alamar Blue (Accumed) was added at 20 <RTI ID=0.0>RI/well.</RTI> Plates were again incubated at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C,</RTI> 5% C02 for 16-24 hours. Plates were read on the <RTI ID=0.0>FmaxTM</RTI> plate reader (Molecular Devices) as described in Example 2. Results demonstrated partial inhibition of cell growth with zcytorl7-Fc4 soluble receptor at <RTI ID=0.0>10</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>g/ml,</RTI> confirming that the factor in each sample was specific for the zcytorl7 receptor.

Titration curves, diluting out the soluble receptor, or soluble receptor heterodimers and trimers comprising zcytorl7 receptor (e. g., <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/OSMR,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/WSX-1,</RTI> or <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/OSMR/WSX-1,</RTI> or other Class I cytokine receptor

subunits) are also run using the above stated assay to determine whether zcytorl7 receptors are able to completely inhibit growth, for example, at low or physiologic concentrations.

COS Cell Transfections The COS cell transfection is performed as follows: Mix about 800 ng of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> cDNA and <RTI ID=0.0>5p1 Lipofectamine in 92 u1</RTI> serum free DMEM media (55mg sodium pyruvate, 146mg L-glutamine, 5mg transferrin, 2. 5mg insulin, lug selenium and 5mg fetuin in 500ml DMEM), incubate at room temperature for 30 minutes and then add 400 <RTI ID=0.0>pI</RTI> serum free DMEM media. B. Secretion Trap Assay The secretion trap is performed as follows: Media is rinsed off cells with PBS and then fixed for 15 minutes with 1.8% Formaldehyde in PBS. Cells are then washed with TNT (0. IM Tris-HCL, <RTI ID=0.0>0.</RTI> 15M NaCI, and 0. <RTI ID=0.0>05%</RTI> Tween-20 in H2O), and permeated with 0. <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> Triton-X in PBS for 15 minutes, and again washed with TNT.

*Cells are blocked for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> hour with TNB (0. IM <RTI ID=0.0>Tris-HCL,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>0.</RTI> 15M NaCI and 0.5% Blocking Reagent (NEN Renaissance TSA-Direct Kit) in H2O), and washed again with
<Desc/Clms Page number 146>
TNT. If using the biotinylated receptor protein, the cells are blocked for 15 minute incubations with Avidin and then Biotin (Vector Labs) washing in-between with TNT.

Depending on which soluble receptor is used, the cells are incubated for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> hour in TNB with: (A) 1-3 <RTI ID=0.0>tg/mi</RTI> zcytorl7 soluble receptor zcytorl7-Fc4 fusion protein (Example 10); (B) 1-3 <RTI ID=0.0>Zg/ml</RTI> zcytorl7/OSMRbeta soluble receptor protein; (C) 1-3 <RTI ID=0.0>Fg/ml</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/WSX-1</RTI> soluble receptor protein; or (D) <RTI ID=0.0>1-3</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ug/ml zcytorl7/OSMR/WSX-l</RTI> soluble receptor protein. Cells are then washed with TNT. Depending on which soluble receptor is used (e. g. , if labeled with an Fc4 tag (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 37), C-terminal FLAG tag (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 36), or CEE tag (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 32; SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 35) ), cells are incubated for another hour with: (A) 1: 200 diluted goat-anti-human Ig-HRP (Fc specific); (B) 1: 1000 diluted <RTI ID=0.0>M2-HRP</RTI> ; (C) 1: 1000 diluted anti-GluGlu antibody-HRP ; or (D) 1: 300 diluted streptavidin-HRP (NEN kit) in TNB, for example. Again cells are washed with TNT.

Example <RTI ID=0.0>13</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>Chromosomal Assignment and Placement of the gene sequence for the zcytorl7lig</RTI> The <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> gene sequence was mapped to human chromosome 12 using the commercially available version of the"Stanford G3 Radiation Hybrid Mapping Panel" (Research Genetics, Inc. , Huntsville, AL). The"Stanford G3 RH Panel"contains DNA from each of 83 radiation hybrid clones of the whole human genome, plus two control DNAs (the RM donor and the A3 recipient). A publicly available WWW server (e. g. , Standford University) allows chromosomal localization of markers and genes.

For the mapping of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> gene sequence with the"Stanford G3 RH Panel", 20 <RTI ID=0.0>lil</RTI> reactions were set up in a 96-well microtiter plate compatible for PCR (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) and used in a"RoboCycler Gradient 96"thermal cycler (Stratagene). Foster City, CA), <RTI ID=0.0>1/ll</RTI> sense primer, ZC41,458 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 42), <RTI ID=0.0>1 nul</RTI> antisense primer, ZC41, 457 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 43), 2 <RTI ID=0.0>lil"RediLoad"</RTI> (Research Genetics, Inc., Huntsville, AL), 0. <RTI ID=0.0>1, ul</RTI> Qiagen HotStarTaq DNA Polymerase (5 <RTI ID=0.0>units/yl),</RTI> 25 ng of DNA from an individual hybrid clone or control and distilled water for a total volume of <RTI ID=0.0>20 ill.</RTI> The reactions were overlaid with an equal amount of mineral oil and sealed. Example <RTI ID=0.0>14</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0> Identification and cloning of murine zcytorl7lig</RTI> A. Identification of full length murine zcytor17lig Using the human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> peptide sequence (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 2) to query an in house DNA database, a murine <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA,</RTI> Genbank Accession No. AK005939, was identified as a potential partial sequence for the murine <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig.</RTI> The AK005939 cDNA sequence was used to query a database containing murine genomic fragments. A genomic contig of the murine zcytor17lig was assembled (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 76). Prediction of coding potential on this genomic fragment with the program Genscan revealed a likely cDNA sequence, with the same gene structure as the human zcytorl71ig. A murine cDNA sequence is represented in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 10, and corresponding polypeptide sequence is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>11.</RTI>

<RTI ID=0.0>B. Cloning of mouse zcytorl7lig from a mouse testis cDNA library by PCR</RTI> Based on the genomic sequence (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 76), two PCR primers were designed and used to identify a cDNA source of mouse zcytor17lig by PCR.
<Desc/Clms Page number 148>

These Primers ZC41498 (SEQ ID NO : 86) and ZC41496 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 87) were designed to the putative 5'and 3'untranslated regions of the mouse sequences (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 76 and SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 10). Several cDNA sources were screened by PCR, including Marathon-ready cDNAs (Clontech) and aliquots of locally made cDNA libraries.

Products were visualized on <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> agarose gels. Bands of the expected size were observed in reactions utilizing a mouse testis cDNA library template. These PCR reactions were successfully performed in approximately <RTI ID=0.0>50</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ul</RTI> volumes with or without 10% DMSO, using pfu turbo polymerase (Stratagene) according to the manufacturer's recommendations; with an additional application of a wax hot-start employing hot start <RTI ID=0.0>50s</RTI> (Molecular Bioproducts, Inc. San Diego, CA). PCR thermocycling was performed with a single cycle of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 4 min; followed by 40 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> : 30 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>48 C</RTI> : 30 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> : 50 seconds; with additional final <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> extension for <RTI ID=0.0>7</RTI> minutes. The two PCR reactions were pooled and purified using low melt agarose and Gelase agarose digesting enzyme (Epicenter, Inc. Madison, WI) according to the manufacturer's recommendations.

DNA sequence determination of these PCR products revealed a murine zcytorl7 cDNA sequence (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 90) which comprised an ORF identical to SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 10, confirming that SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 10 encoded the mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> polypeptide.

PCR primers, ZC41583 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 88) and ZC41584 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 89), were then used to add FseI and AscI restriction sites and a partial Kozak sequence to the <RTI ID=0.0>mcytorl7lig</RTI> open reading frame and termination codon (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 92). A Robocycler 40 thermocycler (Stratagene) was used to run a temperature gradient of annealing temperatures and cycling as follows. Pfu turbo polymerase (Stratagene) was applied as described above, but only in 10% DMSO. Cycling was performed with a single cycle of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 4 min; followed by 20 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> : 30 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> to <RTI ID=0.0>51 C</RTI> gradient: 30 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> : <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute; and a single <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> extension for 7 minutes.

The template for this second thermocycling reaction was <RTI ID=0.0>1, ul</RTI> of the initial gel-purified <RTI ID=0.0>mcytorl7lig</RTI> PCR product, above. Resulting PCR product from the three lowest temperature reactions were pooled and gel purified using the Gelase (Epicenter) method described above. This purified <RTI ID=0.0>mzcytorl71ig</RTI> was digested with FseI and AscI and ligated into a pZP7X vector modified to have FseI and AscI sites in its cloning site.
<Desc/Clms Page number 149>

Plasmid pZP7X is a mammalian expression vector containing an expression cassette having the mouse <RTI ID=0.0>metallothionein-1</RTI> (MT-1) promoter, multiple restriction sites for insertion of coding sequences, and a human growth hormone terminator. The plasmid also has an E. coli origin of replication, a mammalian selective marker expression unit having an SV40 promoter, enhancer and origin of replication, a <RTI ID=0.0>DHFR</RTI> gene, and the SV40 terminator. The cloned murine cDNA sequence is represented in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 90, and corresponding polypeptide sequence is shown in SEQ ID NO : 91 (which is identical to SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO: 11).

Example <RTI ID=0.0>15</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0> Isolation of mouse zcytorl lig cDNA clone from an activated mouse spleen library</RTI> A. Murine <RTI ID=0.0>Primary Source used to isolate mouse zcytorl7lig</RTI> Mouse spleens from Balb/C mice, are collected and mashed between frosted-end slides to create a cell suspension. The isolated primary mouse cell yield is expected to be about 6. <RTI ID=0.0>4X108</RTI> cells prior to selection described below.

The spleen cells are suspended in 9.6 ml MACS buffer (PBS, 0.5% EDTA, 2mM EDTA). 1.6 ml of cell suspension is removed and 0.4 ml CD90 <RTI ID=0.0>(Thyl.</RTI> 2) microbeads (Miltenyi Biotec) added. The mixture is incubated for 15 min. at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI>
These cells labeled with CD90 beads are washed with 30 ml MACS buffer, and then resuspended in 2 ml MACS buffer.

A VS+ column (Miltenyi) is prepared according to the manufacturer's instructions. The VS+ column is then placed in a <RTI ID=0.0>VarioMACSTM</RTI> magnetic field (Miltenyi). The column is equilibrated with 5 ml MACS buffer. The isolated primary mouse cells are then applied to the column. The CD90 negative cells are allowed to pass through. The column is rinsed with 9 ml (3 X 3 ml) MACS buffer. The column is then removed from the magnet and placed over a 15 ml falcon tube. CD90+ cells are eluted by adding 5 ml MACS buffer to the column and bound cells flushed out using the plunger provided by the manufacturer. The incubation of the cells with the CD90 magnetic beads, washes, and VS+ column steps (incubation through elution) above are repeated once more. The resulting CD90+ fractions from the 2 column separations are pooled. The yield of CD90+ selected mouse spleen cells are expected to be about
<Desc/Clms Page number 150>
<RTI ID=0.0>lux108</RTI> total cells.
A sample of the pooled CD90+ selected mouse cells is removed for staining and sorting on a fluorescent antibody cell sorter (FACS) to assess their purity.

A PE-conjugated hamster anti-mouse CD3E antibody (PharMingen) is used for staining and sorting the CD90+ selected cells. The mouse CD90+ selected cells should be about 93% CD3+ cells, suggesting the cells are 93% T-cells.

The murine CD90+ selected cells are activated by incubating <RTI ID=0.0>3X106</RTI> cells/ml in RPMI + <RTI ID=0.0>5%</RTI> FBS + PMA 10 ng/ml and Ionomycin 0. 5 <RTI ID=0.0>g/ml</RTI> (Calbiochem) for overnight at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C.</RTI> The supernatant from these activated CD90+ selected mouse cells is tested for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> activity as described below. Moreover, the activated CD90+ selected mouse cells are used to prepare a cDNA library, as described in Example 16, below.

1995). Example <RTI ID=0.0>21</RTI> Mouse zcytorl lig is active in mouse bone marrow assay A. Isolation of Non-adherent Low Density Marrow Cells :
<Desc/Clms Page number 156>

Fresh mouse femur aspirate (marrow) is obtained from 6-10 week old male <RTI ID=0.0>Balb/C</RTI> or C57BL/6 mice. The marrow is then washed with <RTI ID=0.0>RPMI+10%</RTI> FBS (JRH, Lenexa KS; Hyclone, Logan UT) and suspended in <RTI ID=0.0>RPMI+10%</RTI> FBS as a whole marrow cell suspension. The whole marrow cell suspension is then subjected to a density gradient (Nycoprep, 1.077, Animal ; Gibco BRL) to enrich for low density, mostly mononuclear, cells as follows: The whole marrow cell suspension (About 8 ml) is carefully pipeted on top of about 5 mi Nycoprep gradient solution in a 15 ml conical tube, and then centrifuged at <RTI ID=0.0>600X</RTI> g for 20 minutes. The interface layer, containing the low density mononuclear cells, is then removed, washed with excess <RTI ID=0.0>RPMI+10%</RTI> FBS, and pelleted by centrifugation at <RTI ID=0.0>400X</RTI> g for 5-10 minutes. This pellet is resuspended in RPMI <RTI ID=0.0>+10%</RTI> FBS and plated in a T-75 flask at approximately 106 cells/ml, and incubated at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C</RTI> 5% C02 for approximately 2 hours. The resulting cells in suspension are Non- Adherent Low Density (NA LD) Marrow Cells.

<RTI ID=0.0>B. 96-Well Assay</RTI> NA LD Mouse Marrow Cells are plated at 25,000 to 45,000 cells/well in 96 well tissue culture plates in RPMI +10% FBS + <RTI ID=0.0>lng/mL</RTI> mouse Stem Cell Factor <RTI ID=0.0>(mSCF)</RTI> (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, <RTI ID=0.0>MN),</RTI> plus 5% conditioned medium from one of the following: (1) BHK 570 cells expressing mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> (Example 18), (2) BHK 570 cells expressing human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> (Example 7), or (3) control BHK 570 cells containing vector and not expressing either Ligand. These cells are then subjected to a variety of cytokine treatments to test for expansion or differentiation of hematopoietic cells from the marrow. For testing, the plated NA LD mouse marrow cells are subjected to human <RTI ID=0.0>Interleukin-15</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>(hIL-15)</RTI> (R & D Systems), or one of a panel of other cytokines (R & D Systems). Serial dilution of <RTI ID=0.0>hIl-15,</RTI> or the other cytokines, are tested, with 2-fold serial dilution from about 50 ng/ml down to about 0.5 ng/ml concentration. After 8 to 12 days the <RTI ID=0.0>96-well</RTI> assays are scored for cell proliferation by Alamar blue assay as described in Example 5B.
C. Results from the 96-well NA LD Mouse Marrow assay Conditioned media from the BHK cells expressing both mouse and
<Desc/Clms Page number 157>

human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> can promote the expansion of a population of hematopoietic cells either alone or in synergy with other cytokines in the NA LD mouse marrow in comparison to control BHK conditioned medium. The population hematopoietic cells expanded by the mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> with or without other cytokines, and those hematopoietic cells expanded by the human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> with or without other cytokines, are further propagated in cell culture. These hematopoietic cells are stained with a Phycoerythrin labeled anti-Pan NK cell antibody (PharMingen) and subjected to flow cytometry analysis, which demonstrated that the expanded cells stained positively for this natural killer (NK) cell marker. Similarly, other specific hematopoietic cell markers can be used to determine expansion of, for example, CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, other T-cell populations, B-cells, and other immune cell markers.

The same 96-well assay is run, using fresh human marrow cells bought from Poietic Technologies, Gaithersburg, MD. Again, a positive result shows that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> alone or in synergy with other cytokines, the mouse and human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> can expand a hematopoietic cell population that is stained positively for specific cell markers as disclosed above.
