Construct for <RTI ID=0.0>expressing human zcytorl7lig from the MT-1 promoter</RTI> Oligonucleotides are designed to generate a PCR fragment containing a consensus Kozak sequence and the human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> coding region. These oligonucleotides are designed with an FseI site at the 5'end and an AscI site at the 3'end to facilitate cloning into (a) <RTI ID=0.0>pMT12-8,</RTI> our standard transgenic vector, or (b) <RTI ID=0.0>pKF051,</RTI> a lymphoid- specific transgenic vector (Example 22B).

PCR reactions are carried out with about 200 ng human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> template (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>1)</RTI> and oligonucleotides designed to amplify the full-length or active portion of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig.</RTI> PCR reaction conditions are determined using methods known in the art. PCR products are separated by agarose gel electrophoresis and purified using a QiaQuick (Qiagen) gel extraction kit. The isolated, correct sized DNA fragment is digested with FseI and AscI (Boerhinger-Mannheim), ethanol
<Desc/Clms Page number 158>

precipitated and ligated into <RTI ID=0.0>pMT12-8</RTI> previously digested with FseI and AscI. The <RTI ID=0.0>pMT12-8</RTI> plasmid, designed for expressing a gene of interest in liver and other tissues in transgenic mice, contains an expression cassette flanked by 10 kb of MT-1 5'DNA and 7 kb of MT-1 3'DNA. The expression cassette comprises the MT-1 promoter, the rat insulin <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> intron, a polylinker for the insertion of the desired clone, and the human growth hormone (hGH) poly A sequence.

About one microliter of each ligation reaction is electroporated into <RTI ID=0.0>DH10B</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ElectroMax</RTI> competent cells <RTI ID=0.0>(GIBCO</RTI> BRL, Gaithersburg, MD) according to manufacturer's direction and plated onto LB plates containing <RTI ID=0.0>100, ug/ml</RTI> ampicillin, and incubated overnight. Colonies are picked and grown in LB media containing 100 <RTI ID=0.0>F</RTI> g/ml ampicillin. Miniprep DNA is prepared from the picked clones and screened for the human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> insert by restriction digestion with EcoRI alone, or FseI and AscI combined, and subsequent agarose gel electrophoresis. Maxipreps of the correct pMThuman <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> are performed. A SalI fragment containing with 5'and 3'flanking sequences, the MT-1 promoter, the rat insulin <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> intron, human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> cDNA and the hGH poly A sequence is prepared to be used for microinjection into fertilized murine oocytes. Microinjection and production of transgenic mice are produced as described in Hogan, B. et al. Manipulating the Mouse Embryo, <RTI ID=0.0>2nd</RTI> ed. , Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, NY, 1994.

San Diego, CA). zCytorl7Lig-CEE.

PCR reactions were run as follows: To a 100 l final volume was added: <RTI ID=0.0>IOAI</RTI> of lOx Taq Polymerase Reaction Buffer with 15mM <RTI ID=0.0>MgCI</RTI> (Gibco), <RTI ID=0.0>11</RTI> of Taq DNA Polymerase (5 <RTI ID=0.0>units/, 1,</RTI> Gibco), <RTI ID=0.0>3AI</RTI> of <RTI ID=0.0>10mM</RTI> dNTPs, <RTI ID=0.0>78, u1</RTI> dH20, 3 l of a 20 <RTI ID=0.0>pmol/jul</RTI> stock of primer ZC41607 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>97) 31tl</RTI> of a 20 <RTI ID=0.0>pmol/Al</RTI> stock of primer ZC41605 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 98), and <RTI ID=0.0>2/. ti</RTI> of a 0. 13 g/ l stock of <RTI ID=0.0>zCytorl71ig</RTI> template DNA.

A volume equal to 50 ti of mineral oil was added to the mixture. The reaction was heated to <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 5 minutes, followed by 35 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute; <RTI ID=0.0>55 C</RTI> for 2 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 3 minutes; followed by a 10 minute extension at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> and held at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> until the reaction was collected.

The plasmid <RTI ID=0.0>pZMP21</RTI> was restriction digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BglII</RTI> enzyme, cleaned with a QiaQuick PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen) using a microcentrifuge protocol, and used for recombination with the PCR fragment. Plasmid pZMP21 was constructed from pZMP20 which was constructed from pZP9 (deposited at the American Type Culture Collection, 10801 University Boulevard, Manassas, VA 20110- 2209, and is designated No. 98668) with the yeast genetic elements taken from pRS316 (deposited at the American Type Culture Collection, 10801 University Boulevard, Manassas, VA 20110-2209, and designated No. 77145), an IRES element from poliovirus, and the extracellular domain of CD8, truncated at the carboxyl terminal end of the transmembrane domain. PZMP21 is a mammalian expression vector containing an expression cassette having the MPSV promoter, immunoglobulin signal peptide intron, multiple restriction sites for insertion of coding sequences, a stop codon and a human growth hormone terminator. The plasmid also has an E. coli origin of replication, a mammalian selectable marker expression unit having an SV40 promoter, enhancer and origin of replication, a <RTI ID=0.0>DHFR</RTI> gene, the SV40 terminator, as well as the URA3 and CEN-ARS sequences required for selection and replication in <RTI ID=0.0>S.</RTI> cerevisiae.

(SL7V4). The plasmid <RTI ID=0.0>(161lu)</RTI> was diluted into 1.5 ml tubes to a total final volume of <RTI ID=0.0>640 tel</RTI> with SF media. Example <RTI ID=0.0>24</RTI> Expression of zcytor17 Soluble Receptor in E. coli A. Construction of expression vector <RTI ID=0.0>pCMH0I</RTI> that <RTI ID=0.0>expresses huzcytorl 7/MBP-6H</RTI> fusion polypeptide An expression plasmid containing a polynucleotide encoding a zcytorl7 soluble receptor fused C-terminally to maltose binding protein <RTI ID=0.0>(MBP)</RTI> was constructed via homologous recombination. Two <RTI ID=0.0>itl</RTI> of the <RTI ID=0.0>100 i-ti</RTI> PCR reaction was run on a 1.0% agarose gel with <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> x TBE buffer for analysis, and the expected approximately fragment was seen. The remaining PCR reaction was combined with the second PCR tube and precipitated with <RTI ID=0.0>400, ut</RTI> of absolute ethanol. The precipitated DNA used for recombining into the Smal
<Desc/Clms Page number 165>
cut recipient vector pTAP170 to produce the construct encoding the <RTI ID=0.0>MBP-zcytorl7</RTI> fusion, as described below.

One hundred microliters of competent yeast cells <RTI ID=0.0>(S.</RTI> cerevisiae) were combined with <RTI ID=0.0>10 jus</RTI> of a mixture containing approximately <RTI ID=0.0>1, ug</RTI> of the human zcytorl7 insert, and 100 ng of Smal digested pTAP170 vector, and transferred to a 0.2 cm electroporation cuvette. 100 mM Tris pH7.0, 10% glycerol, 2mM EDTA, 5% SDS). The cells were electropulsed at 2.0 kV, 25 <RTI ID=0.0>ZF</RTI> and 400 ohms. Following electroporation, 0.6 ml MM/CA with 25 <RTI ID=0.0>u. g/L</RTI> Kanomyacin. B. <RTI ID=0.0>Purification of huzcytorl /MBP-6H soluble receptorfrom E. coli fermentation</RTI> Unless otherwise noted, all operations were carried out at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI> The following procedure was used for the purification of recombinant <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H</RTI> soluble receptor polypeptide. E. coli cells containing the <RTI ID=0.0>pCMH01</RTI> construct and expressing <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H</RTI> soluble receptor polypeptide were constructed using standard molecular biology methods and cultured in SuperBroth <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> (12 g/L Casien, 24 g/L Yeast Extract, 11.4 g/L di-potassium phosphate, 1.7 g/L Mono-potassium phosphate; Becton Dickenson, Cockeysville, <RTI ID=0.0>MD).</RTI> The resulting cells were harvested and frozen in 0.5% glycerol. Twenty grams of the frozen cells were used for protein purification.

Thawed cells were resuspended in 500mL Amylose Equilibration buffer (20mM Tris, <RTI ID=0.0>100mM</RTI> NaCI, pH 8.0). A French Press cell breaking system (Constant Systems Ltd. , Warwick, UK) with a temperature setting <RTI ID=0.0>of-7 C</RTI> to-10 C and 30K PSI was used to lyse the cells. The resuspended cells were checked for breakage by A600 readings before and after cycling through the French Press. The <RTI ID=0.0>lysed</RTI> cell suspension was pelleted at 10, <RTI ID=0.0>000G</RTI> for 30 minutes. Supernatant was harvested from the debris pellet for protein purification.

Twenty-five milliliters of Amylose resin (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA) was poured into a Bio-Rad, 2.5 cm D x 10 cm H glass column. The column was packed and equilibrated by gravity with 10 column volumes (CVs) of
<Desc/Clms Page number 167>

Amylose Equilibration buffer. The harvested cell supernatant was batch loaded to the Amylose resin, overnight with rocking. The loaded resin was returned to the glass column, washed with 10 CVs Amylose Equilibration buffer, and eluted by gravity with - 2 CVs Amylose Elution buffer (Amylose Equilibration buffer, 10 mM Maltose, Fluka Biochemical, Switzerland). Ten 5 ml fractions were collected over the elution profile and assayed for absorbance at 280 and 320 nM. The Amylose resin was regenerated with <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> CV of distilled <RTI ID=0.0>H20,</RTI> 5 CVs of 0. 1% (w/v) SDS (Sigma), 5 CVs of distilled <RTI ID=0.0>H20,</RTI> 5 CVs of Amylose Equilibration buffer, and finally <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> CV of Amylose Storage buffer (Amylose Equilibration buffer, 0.02% (w/v) Sodium Azide). The regenerated resin was stored at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI>

Elution profile fractions of interest were pooled and dialyzed in a <RTI ID=0.0>1 OK</RTI> dialysis chamber (Slide-A-Lyzer, Pierce <RTI ID=0.0>Immunochemical)</RTI> against 4 changes of 4L PBS pH 7.4 (Sigma) over an 8 hour time period. Following dialysis, the material harvested represented the purified huzcytorl7/MBP-6H polypeptide. The purified huzcytorl7/MBP-6H polypeptide was filter sterilized and analyzed via SDS-PAGE Coomassie staining for an appropriate molecular weight product. The concentration of the <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H</RTI> polypeptide was determined by BCA analysis to be 0.76 mg/ml.

Purified <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H</RTI> polypeptide was appropriately formulated for the immunizaton of rabbits and sent to R & R Research and Development (Stanwood, WA) for polyclonal antibody production (Example 25, below).

Example <RTI ID=0.0>25</RTI> Human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 7 Receptor Polyclonal Antibody</RTI> A. Preparation and Purification Polyclonal antibodies were prepared by immunizing 2 female New Zealand white rabbits with the purified recombinant protein <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H</RTI> (Example 24). The rabbits were each given an initial intraperitoneal (IP) injection of <RTI ID=0.0>200</RTI> Ag of purified protein in Complete Freund's Adjuvant followed by booster IP injections of 100 <RTI ID=0.0>jig</RTI> protein in Incomplete Freund's Adjuvant every three weeks.
Seven to ten days after the administration of the second booster injection (3 total
<Desc/Clms Page number 168>
injections), the animals were bled and the serum was collected. The animals were then boosted and bled every three weeks.

The huzcytorl7/MBP-6H specific rabbit serum was pre-adsorbed of anti-MBP antibodies using a <RTI ID=0.0>CNBr-SEPHAROSE</RTI> 4B protein column (Pharmacia LKB) that was prepared using 10 mg of non-specific purified recombinant MBP-fusion protein per gram of <RTI ID=0.0>CNBr-SEPHAROSE.</RTI> The huzcytorl7/MBP-6H-specific polyclonal antibodies were affinity purified from the pre-adsorbed rabbit serum using a <RTI ID=0.0>CNBr-SEPHAROSE</RTI> 4B protein column (Pharmacia LKB) that was prepared using 10 mg of the specific antigen purified recombinant protein <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H.</RTI>

Following purification, the polyclonal antibodies were dialyzed with 4 changes of 20 times the antibody volume of PBS over a time period of at least 8 hours. Human zcytorl7-specific antibodies were characterized by ELISA using 500 ng/ml of the purified recombinant protein <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H</RTI> as antibody target. The lower limit of detection <RTI ID=0.0>(LID)</RTI> of the rabbit <RTI ID=0.0>anti-huzcytorl7/MBP-6H</RTI> affinity purified antibody is 500 pg/ml on its specific purified recombinant antigen <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7/MBP-6H.</RTI>

B. SDS-PAGE and Western <RTI ID=0.0>blotting analysis of Rabbit Anti-human ZcytoRl7 MBP-6H</RTI> antibody Rabbit anti-human ZcytoR17 <RTI ID=0.0>MBP-6H</RTI> antibody was tested by SDS- PAGE (NuPage 4-12%, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) with coomassie staining method and Western blotting using goat anti-rabbit IgG-HRP. Either purified protein (200-25 ng) or conditioned media containing zcytorl7 was electrophoresed using an Invitrogen Novex's Xcell <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> mini-cell, and transferred to nitrocellulose (0.2 mm; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) at room temperature using Novex's Xcell blot module with stirring according to directions provided in the instrument manual. The transfer was run at 300 mA for one hour in a buffer containing 25 mM Tris base, 200 mM glycine, and <RTI ID=0.0>20%</RTI> methanol. The filter was then blocked with Western A buffer (in house, 50 mM Tris, pH 7.4, 5 mM EDTA, pH 8.0, 0.05% Igepal CA-630,150 mM <RTI ID=0.0>NaCI,</RTI> and 0.25% gelatin) overnight with gentle rocking at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI> The nitrocellulose was quickly rinsed, then the rabbit anti-human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytoR17 MBP-6H</RTI> (1: 1000) was added in Western A buffer.
The blot was incubated for 1.5 hours at room temperature with gentle rocking. The blot
<Desc/Clms Page number 169>

was rinsed 3 times for 5 minutes each in Western A, then goat anti-rabbit IgG HRP antibody (1: 1000) was added in Western A buffer. The blot was incubated for 1.25 hours at room temperature with gentle rocking. The blot was rinsed 3 times for 5 minutes each in Western A, then quickly rinsed in H20. The blot was developed using commercially available chemiluminescent substrate reagents <RTI ID=0.0>(ECLWestern</RTI> blotting detection reagents <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> and 2 mixed <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> : <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> ; reagents obtained from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, Buckinghamshire, England) and the blot was exposed to X-ray film for up <RTI ID=0.0>tol5</RTI> minutes.

The rabbit anti-human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytoR17</RTI> MBP-6H was able to detect human zcytorl7 present in conditioned media as well as zcytoR17 purified protein as a band at 120 kDa under reducing conditions.

Example 26 Tissue <RTI ID=0.0>Distribution of Mouse zcytorl 7 in Tissue Panels Using PCR</RTI> A panel of cDNAs from murine tissues was screened for mouse zcytorl7 expression using PCR. The panel was made in-house and contained 94 marathon cDNA and cDNA samples from various normal and cancerous murine tissues and cell lines are shown in Table 6, below. The cDNAs came from in-house libraries or marathon cDNAs from in-house RNA preps, Clontech RNA, or Invitrogen RNA. The mouse marathon cDNAs were made using the marathon-Ready kit (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) and QC tested with mouse transferrin receptor primers ZC10, 651 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 46) and ZC10, 565 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 47) and then diluted based on the intensity of the transferrin band. To assure quality of the amplified library samples in the panel, three tests for quality control (QC) were run: (1) To assess the RNA quality used for the libraries, the in-house cDNAs were tested for average insert size by PCR with vector oligos that were specific for the vector sequences for an individual cDNA library; (2) Standardization of the concentration of the cDNA in panel samples was achieved using standard PCR methods to amplify full length alpha tubulin or G3PDH cDNA using a 5' vector oligo: ZC14, 063 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 48) and 3'alpha tubulin specific oligo primer ZC17, 574 (SEQ ID NO : 49) or 3'G3PDH specific oligo primer ZC17, 600 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 50); and (3) a sample was sent to sequencing to check for possible ribosomal or
<Desc/Clms Page number 170>
mitochondrial DNA contamination. The panel was set up in a 96-well format that included a mouse genomic DNA (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) positive control sample.

Each well contained approximately 0.2-100 <RTI ID=0.0>pg/, ul</RTI> of <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA.</RTI> The PCR was set up using oligos ZC38,065 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 51) and ZC38,068 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 52), TaKaRa Ex Taq (TAKARA Shuzo Co LTD, Biomedicals Group, Japan), and Rediload dye (Research Genetics, Inc. , Huntsville, AL). The amplification was carried out as follows: <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 5 minutes; 5 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 30 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> for 30 seconds; 35 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 30 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>56 C</RTI> for 30 seconds and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 30 seconds, followed by <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 5 minutes. About 10 <RTI ID=0.0>l</RTI> of the PCR reaction product was subjected to standard Agarose gel electrophoresis using a 4% agarose gel. The correct predicted DNA fragment size was observed in brain, CD90+ cells, dendritic, embryo, MEWt#2, Tuvak-prostate cell line, salivary gland, skin and testis.
The DNA fragment for skin and testis were excised and purified using a Gel Extraction Kit (Qiagen, Chatsworth, CA) according to manufacturer's instructions.
Fragments were confirmed by sequencing to show that they were indeed mouse zcytorl7.

Example 27 : Human Zcytor17 Expression in Various Tissues Using Real-Time Quantitative RT/PCR A. Primers and Probes for Human Zcytor17, OSMRbeta and Zcytor17lig for Conventional and <RTI ID=0.0>Quantitative RT-PCR</RTI> Real-time quantitative RT-PCR using the ABI PRISM 7900 Sequence Detection System (PE Applied Biosystems, Inc. , Foster City, CA) has been previously
<Desc/Clms Page number 172>

described (See, Heid, C. A. et al., Genome Research 6: 986-994,1996 ; Gibson, U. E. M. et <RTI ID=0.0>al., Genome Research 6</RTI> : 995-1001,1996 ; Sundaresan, S. et al., Endocrinology <RTI ID=0.0>139</RTI> : 4756-4764,1998). This method incorporates use of a gene specific probe containing both reporter and quencher fluorescent dyes. When the probe is intact the reporter dye emission is negated due to the close proximity of the quencher dye.

During PCR extension using additional gene-specific forward and reverse primers, the probe is cleaved by 5'nuclease activity of Taq polymerase which releases the reporter dye from the probe resulting in an increase in fluorescent emission.

The primers and probes used for real-time quantitative RT-PCR analyses of human Zcytorl7, OSMRbeta and <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression were designed using the primer design software Primer Express (PE Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).

Primers for human Zcytorl7 were designed spanning an intron-exon junction to eliminate possible amplification of genomic DNA. The forward primer, ZC37,877 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 53) and the reverse primer, ZC37, 876 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 54) were used in a PCR reaction at a 200 nM concentration to synthesize a 73 bp product. The corresponding Zcytorl7 <RTI ID=0.0>TaqManS)</RTI> probe, designated ZC37, 776 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 55) was synthesized and labeled by PE Applied Biosystems and used in each PCR reaction at a concentration of 200nM. The ZC37, 776 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 55) probe was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye (6-carboxy-fluorescein) (FAM) (PE Applied Biosystems) and at the 3'end with a fluorescent quencher dye (6-carboxy-tetramethyl- rhodamine) (TAMRA) (Epoch Biosciences, Bothell, WA).

Primers for human OSMRbeta were designed spanning an intron-exon junction to eliminate possible amplification of genomic DNA. The forward primer, ZC43, 891 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 137) and the reverse primer, ZC43, 900 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>138)</RTI> were used in a PCR reaction (below) at a 200 nM concentration. The corresponding OSMRbeta <RTI ID=0.0>TaqManS)</RTI> probe, designated ZC43, 896 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 139) was synthesized and labeled by PE Applied Biosystems and used in each PCR reaction at a concentration of 200nM. The ZC43, 896 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 139) probe was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye (6-carboxy-fluorescein) (FAM) (PE Applied Biosystems) and at the 3'end with a non-fluorescent quencher dye (ECLIPSE) (Epoch Biosciences).
<Desc/Clms Page number 173>

Primers for human <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> were designed spanning an intron- exon junction to eliminate possible amplification of genomic DNA. The forward primer, ZC43,280 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 140) and the reverse primer, ZC43, 281 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 141) were used in a PCR reaction (below) at about 200 nM concentration. The corresponding <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>TaqMan (E)</RTI> probe, designated ZC43,275 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 142) was synthesized and labeled by PE Applied Biosystems and used in each PCR reaction at a concentration of 200nM. The ZC43, 275 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 142) probe was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye (6-carboxy-fluorescein) (FAM) (PE Applied Biosystems) and at the 3'end with a non-fluorescent quencher dye (ECLIPSE) (Epoch Biosciences).

As a control to test the integrity and quality of RNA samples tested, all RNA samples were screened for either rRNA or GUS using primer and probe sets either ordered from PE Applied Biosystems (rRNA kit) or designed in-house (GUS).

The rRNA kit contained the forward primer (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 56), the rRNA reverse primer (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 57), and the rRNA <RTI ID=0.0>TaqMan (E)</RTI> probe (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 58). The rRNA probe was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye VIC (PE Applied Biosystems) and at the 3'end with the quencher fluorescent dye TAMRA (PE Applied Biosystems).

The GUS primers and probe were generated in-house and used in each PCR reaction at 200nM and 100nM, respectively. The forward primer was ZC40, 574 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 143) and the reverse primer was ZC40, 575 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 144). The GUS probe ZC43, 017 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 145) was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye (Yakima-Yellow) (Epoch Biosciences) and at the 3'end with a non-fluorescent quencher dye (ECLIPSE) (Epoch Biosciences). The rRNA and GUS results also serve as an endogenous control and allow for the normalization of the Zcytorl7 mRNA expression results seen in the test samples.

For conventional non-quantitative RT-PCR, primers were designed using the primer design software Primer Express (PE Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA). The human zcytorl7 primers generate an approximately 1000 base pair product and are as follows: forward primer ZC28,917 (SEQ ID NO : 83), and reverse primer ZC28, 480 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 146). The human OSMRbeta primers generate a 202 base pair product and are as follows: forward primer ZC41,653 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 147) and
<Desc/Clms Page number 174>

reverse primer ZC41,655 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 148). The human <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> primers generate a 305 base pair product and are as follows: forward primer ZC41,703 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 149) and reverse primer ZC41,704 (SEQ ID NO : 150).

ZC43,045 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 157) and the reverse primer, ZC43,046 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 158) were used in the PCR reactions at a 300 nM concentration. The corresponding OSMRbeta <RTI ID=0.0>TaqMan)</RTI> probe, designated ZC43,141 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 159) was synthesized and labeled by Epoch Biosciences. The ZC43, 141 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 159) probe was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye (6-carboxy-fluorescein) (FAM) (PE Applied Biosystems) and at the 3'end with a non-fluorescent quencher dye (ECLIPSE) (Epoch Biosciences). The ZC43,141 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 159) probe was used in the PCR reactions (below) at a concentration of 100nM.

As a control to test the integrity and quality of RNA samples tested, all RNA samples were screened for either murine GUS or transferrin receptor using primers and probes designed using the primer design program Primer Express (PE Applied Biosystems Inc. , Foster City, CA). The murine GUS primers are as follows: forward primer, ZC43, 004 (SEQ ID NO : 160), reverse primer, ZC43, 005 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 161), and <RTI ID=0.0>TaqMan)</RTI> probe ZC43, 018 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 162). The murine GUS probe ZC43, 018 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 162) was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye <RTI ID=0.0>Yakima-Yellow</RTI> (Epoch Biosciences) and at the 3'end with the non-fluorescent quencher dye ECLIPSE (Epoch Biosciences). The murine GUS primers were used in the PCR reactions at 300 nM and the probe, ZC43, 018 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 162), was used at <RTI ID=0.0>100nM.</RTI> In some cases murine Transferrin Receptor was used instead of GUS as the endogenous control. The transferrin receptor forward primer, ZC40,269 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 163) and the reverse primer, ZC40, 268 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 164) were used at 300nM.

The transferrin receptor probe, ZC40, 298 (SEQ ID NO : 165) was used in PCR at <RTI ID=0.0>100nM</RTI> and was labeled at the 5'end with a reporter fluorescent dye VIC (PE Applied Biosystems) and at the 3'end with a fluorescent quencher dye (TAMRA) (PE Applied Biosystems). The murine GUS and transferrin receptor results also serve as an endogenous control and allow for the normalization of the Zcytorl7, OSMRbeta and <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> mRNA expression results seen in the test samples.

For conventional semi-quantitative RT-PCR, primers were designed using the primer design software Primer Express (PE Applied Biosystems). The murine Zcytorl7 primers generate a 276 base pair product and are as follows: forward primer ZC43, 140 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 166), and reverse primer ZC43,139 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 167).
<Desc/Clms Page number 176>

The murine OSMRbeta primers generate a 575 base pair product and are as follows: forward primer ZC41, 608 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 168) and reverse primer ZC41,609 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 169). The murine <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl7ligand</RTI> primers generate a 657bp product and are as follows: forward primer ZC41,502 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 170) and reverse primer ZC41,500 (SEQ ID NO: <RTI ID=0.0>171).</RTI>

C. <RTI ID=0.0>Protocolsfor Realtime Quantitative RT-PCR and Conventional Semi-quantitative</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>RT-PCR</RTI> Relative levels of Zcytorl7, OSMRbeta and <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand mRNA</RTI> were determined by analyzing total RNA samples using the one-step RT-PCR method (PE Applied Biosystems). Total RNA from Zcytorl7-and OSMRbeta-transfected BAF cells (human) or BHK cells (murine) was isolated by standard methods and used to generate a standard curve used for quantitation of Zcytorl7 and OSMRbeta. The curve consisted of 10-fold serial dilutions ranging from <RTI ID=0.0>100-O.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>01ng/1ll</RTI> with each standard curve point analyzed in triplicate. Similarly, for <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand,</RTI> activated CD4+ T cell RNA (previously shown to make <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand)</RTI> was used to generate a standard curve in the same <RTI ID=0.0>100-0.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>Olng/, ul</RTI> range. Total RNA from human or murine cells was analyzed in triplicate for either human or murine Zcytorl7, OSMRbeta and <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> transcript levels and for one of the following endogenous control genes: <RTI ID=0.0>rRNA,</RTI> GUS or transferrin receptor. In a total volume of 10 <RTI ID=0.0>gel,</RTI> each RNA sample was subjected to a One-Step RT-PCR reaction containing: approximately <RTI ID=0.0>50-100ng</RTI> of total RNA in a preformulated 2X master mix containing an internal control dye (ROX) (carboxy-xrhodamine) and <RTI ID=0.0>Thermo-Start@ </RTI> DNA Polymerase (Abgene, Surrey, UK) ; appropriate primers for the gene of interest (see parts A and B of current example); the appropriate probe (see parts A and B for concentration); <RTI ID=0.0>Superscript@ </RTI> reverse transcriptase (50 <RTI ID=0.0>U/l)</RTI> (PE Applied Biosystems), and an appropriate volume of RNase-free water. PCR thermal cycling conditions were as follows: an initial reverse transcription (RT) step of one cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>48 C</RTI> for 30 minutes; followed by a <RTI ID=0.0>Thermo-Start@ </RTI> enzyme activation step of one cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 10 minutes; followed by 40 cycles of amplification at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 15 seconds and <RTI ID=0.0>60 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute. Relative Zcytorl7, OSMRbeta and <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> RNA levels were determined by using the Standard Curve Method as described by the
<Desc/Clms Page number 177>

manufacturer, PE Biosystems (User Bulletin #2 : ABI Prism 7700 Sequence Detection System, Relative Quantitation of Gene Expression, December 11,1997). The <RTI ID=0.0>rRNA,</RTI> GUS or Transferrin Receptor measurements were used to normalize the levels of the gene of interest.

The semi-quantitative RT-PCR reactions used <RTI ID=0.0>the'Superscript</RTI> One-Step RT-PCR System with Platinum Taq' (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA). Each <RTI ID=0.0>25/il</RTI> reaction consisted of the following: 12. <RTI ID=0.0>5111</RTI> of 2X Reaction Buffer, 0. 5 l (20pmol/ l) of forward primer, 0. <RTI ID=0.0>5/tl (20pmol/ltl)</RTI> of reverse primer, 0. <RTI ID=0.0>4y1</RTI> RT/Taq polymerase mix, 5. <RTI ID=0.0>0y1</RTI> of Rediload Gel Loading Buffer (Invitrogen), <RTI ID=0.0>5.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>1jnl RNase-free</RTI> water, and <RTI ID=0.0>1.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>Oltl</RTI> total RNA (100ng/ l). The amplification was carried out as follows: one cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>45 C</RTI> for 30 minutes followed by 35-38 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C,</RTI> 20 seconds; Variable annealing temp (See Table 7 below), 20 seconds; <RTI ID=0.0>72 C,</RTI> 45 seconds; then ended with a final extension at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 5 minutes. Eight to ten microliters of the PCR reaction product was subjected to standard agarose gel electrophoresis using a 2% agarose gel.

Isolation of RNA from Human and Murine PBMC Subsets and Cell Lines Blood was drawn from several anonymous donors and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) isolated using standard Ficoll gradient methodology.

Monocytes were then isolated using the Monocyte Isolation Kit and the Magnetic Cell Separation System (Miltenyi Biotec, Auburn, CA). The monocytes were then plated onto ultra-low adherence 24-well plates in endotoxin-free media. They were either unstimulated or treated with recombinant human <RTI ID=0.0>IFNg</RTI> (R & D Systems Inc. ) at <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/ml.</RTI>
Cells were collected at 24 and 48 hours. In similar manner, CD4+ and CD8+ T cells were isolated from PBMC's using the anti-CD4 or anti-CD8 magnetic beads from
<Desc/Clms Page number 178>

Miltenyi Biotec. Cells were then activated for 4 or 16 hours in tissue culture plates coated with <RTI ID=0.0>0.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>5 gel</RTI> anti-CD3 antibodies in media containing <RTI ID=0.0>5, ug/ml</RTI> anti-CD28 antibodies. NK cells were also isolated from PBMC's using Miltenyi's anti-CD56 coated magnetic beads. Some of the NK cells were collected at time zero for RNA and the others were plated in media containing Phorbol Myristate Acetate (PMA) <RTI ID=0.0>(Sng/ml)</RTI> and ionomycin <RTI ID=0.0>(0.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>5yg/ml)</RTI> for 24 hours. Additionally, several human monocyte-like cell lines, U937, <RTI ID=0.0>THP-1</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>HL-60,</RTI> were collected in either their resting or activated states. U937 cells were activated overnight with PMA <RTI ID=0.0>(lOng/ml).</RTI> HL-60's were activated overnight with PMA <RTI ID=0.0>(lOng/ml)</RTI> or for 72 and 96 hours with <RTI ID=0.0>IFNg</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>(lOng/ml)</RTI> to drive them down a monocytic pathway. THP-1 cells were activated overnight with a combination of LPS <RTI ID=0.0>(lOng/ml)</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>IFNg</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>(lOng/ml).</RTI> RNA was prepared from all primary cells using the RNeasy <RTI ID=0.0>Midiprep Kit</RTI> (Qiagen, Valencia, CA) as per manufacturer's instructions. Carryover DNA was removed using the DNA-Free kit (Ambion, Inc. , Austin, TX). RNA concentration was determined using standard spectrophotometry and RNA quality determined using the Bioanalyzer 2100 (Agilent Technologies, Palo Alto, CA).

Murine T Cell RNA was collected using a variety of methods well- known in the art. Primary splenic CD4+ and CD8+ T cells were isolated from the spleens of <RTI ID=0.0>C57B1/6</RTI> mice using antibody-coated magnetic beads and the Magnetic Cell Separation System from Miltenyi Biotec. The CD4+ and CD8+ T cells were then activated by culturing the cells in 24-well plates coated with anti-CD3 antibodies <RTI ID=0.0>(SOOng/ml)</RTI> in media containing anti-CD28 antibodies at <RTI ID=0.0>5yg/ml.</RTI> Cells were harvested for RNA at 0,4 and 16 hours. Similarly, CD4+ T cells were isolated and then skewed towards a Thl or Th2 phenotype using the following protocol. Since <RTI ID=0.0>C57B1/6</RTI> T cells are already skewed in the Thl direction, all that was required was to activate for 6 hours with <RTI ID=0.0>0.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>5, ug/ml</RTI> PMA and <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/ml</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ionomycin.'Th2'skewing</RTI> was obtained by plating naive CD4+ T cells with 2. <RTI ID=0.0>5, ug/ml</RTI> anti-CD28, <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/ml</RTI> mIL-2 (R & D Systems Inc. ) and 25ng/ml <RTI ID=0.0>mIL-4</RTI> (R & D Systems) into plates coated with <RTI ID=0.0>0.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>5, ug/ml</RTI> anti-CD3. After 2 days in culture, cells were resuspended in media containing <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/ml</RTI> mIL-2 (R & D Systems) and 25ng/ml <RTI ID=0.0>mIL-4.</RTI> Cells were cultured for an additional three days then activated with PMA and ionomycin for 6 hours.
<Desc/Clms Page number 179>

One additional set of <RTI ID=0.0>Th I</RTI> and Th2 skewed T cells was derived using the T Cell Receptor Transgenic <RTI ID=0.0>DO11.</RTI> 10 T cell line. All cells were plated into anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 coated plates. <RTI ID=0.0>The Th 1'cells</RTI> were plated in media containing mIL-12 <RTI ID=0.0>(lng/ml)</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>anti-L-4 (10yg/ml). The'Th2'cells</RTI> were plated in media containing mIL-4 <RTI ID=0.0>(lOng/ml)</RTI> and anti-IFNg <RTI ID=0.0>(10, ug/ml).</RTI> After 24 hours, all cultures were given <RTI ID=0.0>mIL-2 (lOng/ml).</RTI> After two more days, the media on the cells was changed and new media containing the aforementioned cytokines was added and cells were cultured an additional 4 days before being harvested.
All of the murine T cell RNA was prepared using the RNeasy <RTI ID=0.0>MidiprepT Kit</RTI> (Qiagen) and contaminating DNA was removed using the DNA-free kit from Ambion.

E. Isolation of RNA from the Murine Models of Pancreatitis and Irritable Bowel Disease To induce a condition similar to human Irritable Bowel Disease (IBD), the hybrid mouse strain <RTI ID=0.0>C57B16/129S6F1</RTI> was used. Mice were divided into 4 groups with an average size of six mice per group. Group <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> was given no Dextran Sulfate Sodium (DSS) and was sacrificed on day 14. Group 2 received 2% DSS for two days prior to being sacrificed. Group 3 received 2% DSS for seven days prior to sacrifice. Group 4 received 2% DSS for seven days then allowed to recover for seven days and was sacrificed on day 14. On the day of sacrifice, the distal colon sections were removed and placed in <RTI ID=0.0>RNAIater</RTI> (Ambion). The colon sections were homogenized using standard techniques and RNA was isolated using the RNeasy <RTI ID=0.0>Midiprep Kit</RTI> (Qiagen). Contaminating DNA was removed by Da-free (Ambion) treatment as per manufacturer's instructions.

In a different study, acute pancreatitis was induced in male CD-1 mice by caerulein injection. Mice were divided into three groups (n= 8 mice/group). Group <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> animals were given seven i. p. injections (1 injection per hour) with Vehicle (saline), and then sacrificed at 12 and 24 hours following the first injection. Groups 2 and 3 were given seven i. p. injections of caerulein (Sigma) (Catalog#C-9026) at a dose of <RTI ID=0.0>50g/kg/hr</RTI> for six hours (1 injection per hour). Group 2 was sacrificed at 12 hrs after
<Desc/Clms Page number 180>
the first injection and Group 3 was sacrificed at 24 hrs following the first injection.
Pancreases were removed at the time of sacrifice and snap frozen for RNA isolation.
Tissues were homogenized and RNA was isolated using the Qiagen RNeasy <RTI ID=0.0>Midiprep</RTI> Kit.

In yet another study, murine <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> transgenic mice were generated and observed for phenotypic changes (see Example 41). Piloerection and hair loss was observed in many of the transgenic mice. Four transgenic mice were sacrificed and skin samples from both normal and hairless areas were removed and snap frozen for later RNA isolation. Skin sections from two non-transgenic control mice were collected as well. Skin samples were homogenized and then digested with Proteinase K (Qiagen) (Catalog# 19133) for 20 minutes at <RTI ID=0.0>60 C.</RTI> RNA was then isolated using the Qiagen RNeasy <RTI ID=0.0>Midiprep</RTI> Kit following manufacturer's instructions. Carryover DNA was removed using DNA kit from Ambion.

F. <RTI ID=0.0>Results of Quantitative and Semi-Quantitative RT-PCR for Human Zcytorl 7,</RTI> OSMRbeta and Zcytorl 7ligand Zcytorl7 and OSMRbeta expression was examined by quantitative RTPCR in four sets of primary human monocytes that were either in their resting state or activated with <RTI ID=0.0>IFNg</RTI> for 24 or 48 hours. Zcytorl7 expression was below detection in the unstimulated cells but increased dramatically after the 24-hour activation with <RTI ID=0.0>IFNg,</RTI> and was the highest after 48 hours of activation. In all cases OSMRbeta was below detection. <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> was not tested in these samples.

In the primary T cells, Zcytorl7 was below detection in both the resting CD4+ and CD8+ subsets. After a four-hour activation, however, expression of Zcytorl7 went up in both subsets and then decreased to a slightly lower level at the 16 hour time point. OSMRbeta was below detection in these samples. <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression was examined using semi-quantitative RT-PCR. No expression was detected in the unstimulated CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. However, after the four hour activation, high levels of <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> were detected. This level dropped somewhat at the 16 hour time point.
Expression of Zcytorl7 was not examined in NK cells. <RTI ID=0.0>OSMRb</RTI> was
<Desc/Clms Page number 181>

below detection in these samples. <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression was below detection in the resting NK cells, however there was a faint signal generated by the activated NK cells suggesting that these cells may make <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl7ligand</RTI> under certain conditions.

In the human monocyte-like cell lines, U937, THP-1 and HL-60, OSMRbeta expression was below detection in all of the resting and activated samples except for activated THP-1 samples where a faint signal was detected. Zcytorl7 expression was high in both the U937 and <RTI ID=0.0>THP-1</RTI> resting cell lines and showed a strong upregulation following activation. Expression in U937's was the highest of any cell type. In the <RTI ID=0.0>HL-60's,</RTI> Zcytorl7 was expressed at moderate levels in the unstimulated cells and decreased upon stimulation with PMA. However, the expression of Zcytorl7 was dramatically upregulated in the <RTI ID=0.0>HL-60's</RTI> when stimulated with <RTI ID=0.0>IFNg</RTI> for 72 and 96 hours. All of the human expression data is summarized in Table 8 below.

Results <RTI ID=0.0>of Quantitative and Semi-Quantitative RT-PCR for Murine Zcytorl 7,</RTI> OSMRbeta and Zcytorl 7ligand
<Desc/Clms Page number 182>

Murine Zcytorl7, OSMRbeta and <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression levels were examined in several murine T cells populations and the results are summarized in Table 9 below. Murine Zcytorl7 expression was tested by semi-quantitative RT-PCR and shown to be at low levels on both resting and activated primary CD4+ T cells.

Expression of Zcytorl7 was detected on resting CD8+ T cells and then seemed to drop upon activation with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 antibodies at both the 4-and 16-hour time points. OSMRbeta expression was measured by quantitative RT-PCR and shown to be expressed in resting and activated CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. The expression of OSMRbeta went up after a 4-hour activation and then returned to the unstimulated levels by 16 hours in both the CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> was detected by quantitative RT-PCR and shown to be expressed at very low levels in unstimulated CD4+ T cells. However, following a 4-hour activation, <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression was dramatically upregulated and then dropped slightly by the 16-hour time point. In CD8+ T cells, no <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> was detected in the unstimulated cells. There was some <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression at the 4-hour time point, but by 16 hours expression levels had dropped back below detection.

In the <RTI ID=0.0>DO11.</RTI> 10 T cells, Zcytorl7 expression was detected in the naive and Th2 skewed cells, but not in the <RTI ID=0.0>Thl</RTI> skewed cells. OSMRbeta expression was at low levels in the naive DO11. 10 cells. There was a dramatic increase in OSMRbeta expression levels in the <RTI ID=0.0>Thl</RTI> skewed cells and a moderate increase of expression in the Th2-skewed cells. The <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression in these cells was shown to be predominantly by the Th2 skewed subset. Low levels were detected in the Thl subset and no expression was detected in the naive cells. These results are summarized in the Table 9 below.

In the primary CD4+ T cells that were skewed in either the <RTI ID=0.0>Thl</RTI> or Th2 direction, Zcytol7 wasn't examined. OSMRbeta expression was detected in all three samples with the highest levels found in the Th2 sample. Similar to the DO11. 10 results, Zcytorl71igand expression was detected at high levels in the Th2 skewed subset, with a small amount detected in the <RTI ID=0.0>Thl</RTI> subset and levels were below detection in the unstimulated cells. These results are summarized in the Table 9 below.

In the <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> transgenic skin samples, Zcytorl7, OSMRbeta and <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71igand</RTI> expression levels were determined using quantitative RT-PCR.

Zcytorl7 was shown to be present in all samples at roughly equivalent levels. There were dramatically higher levels of OSMRbeta expression in the non-transgenic control animals than the transgenic samples. Zcytor17ligand expression was below detection in the non-transgenic control animals with moderate to high levels of expression in the transgenic animals. Example <RTI ID=0.0>28</RTI> Human <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl lig Tissue Distribution Expression based on RT-PCR Analysis of</RTI> Multiple Tissue First-Strand cDNAs Gene expression of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> was examined using commercially
<Desc/Clms Page number 185>

available normalized multiple tissue first-strand cDNA panels (OriGene Technologies, Inc. Rockville, MD ; BD Biosciences Clontech, Palo Alto, CA). These included the OriGene"Human Tissue Rapid-Scan Panel" (Cat. #CHSCA-101, containing 22 different tissues, bone marrow, and plasma blood leucocytes) and the BD Biosciences Clontech"Human Blood Fractions MTCTM Panel" (Cat. <RTI ID=0.0>#K1428-1,</RTI> containing 9 different blood fractions).

PCR reactions were set up using the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> specific oligo primers ZC41, 458 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 60), and ZC41, 457 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 61), which yield a 139 bp product, and ZC41, 459 (SEQ ID NO : 62), and ZC41, 460 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 63), which yield a 92 bp product, Qiagen HotStarTaq DNA polymerase and buffer (Qiagen, Inc., Valencia, CA), <RTI ID=0.0>dH20,</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>RediLoadTM</RTI> dye (Research Genetics, Inc., <RTI ID=0.0>Huntville,</RTI> AL).

The PCR cycler conditions were as follows: an initial 1 cycle 15 minute denaturation at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C,</RTI> 35 cycles of a 45 second denaturation at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute annealing at <RTI ID=0.0>53 C</RTI> or <RTI ID=0.0>56 C</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute and 15 seconds extension at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C,</RTI> followed by a final 1 cycle extension of 7 minutes at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C.</RTI> The reactions were separated by electrophoresis on a 2% agarose gel (EM Science, Gibbstown, NJ) and visualized by staining with ethidium bromide.
A DNA fragment of the correct size was observed in the following human adult tissues using the OriGene"Human Tissue Rapid-Scan Panel" : testis, plasma blood leucocytes (PBL), and bone marrow.

A DNA fragment of the correct size was observed in the following human blood fractions using the BD Biosciences Clontech"Human Blood Fractions <RTI ID=0.0>MTC</RTI> Panel" : activated mononuclear cells (B- & T-cells and monocytes), activated CD8+ cells (T-suppressor/cytotoxic), activated CD4+ cells (T-helper/inducer) and faintly in resting CD8+ cells.

Example 29 Cloning the human Oncostatin M receptor The OncostatinM beta receptor (OSMRbeta) is a type I cytokine receptor with structural similarity to IL12R-B2. ZcytoR17 has structural similarity to IL12R- <RTI ID=0.0>Bl.</RTI> The OSMRbeta and zcytorl7 were tested to see whether they could interact as
<Desc/Clms Page number 186>
subunits in a cytokine signaling complex, and whether together they could act as a signaling receptor, or soluble receptor antagonist, for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig.</RTI>

To isolate OSMRbeta, oligonucleotide PCR primers ZC39982 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 64) and ZC39983 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 65) were designed to amplify the full length coding region of the human OncostatinM beta cDNA sequence (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 6) (Genbank Accession No. U60805; Mosley B, <RTI ID=0.0>JBC</RTI> Volume 271, Number 50, Issue of December 20,1996 pp. 32635-32643).

PCR reactions were run on an array of cDNA library templates using a robust polymerase, Advantage <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> (Clonetech, PaloAlto, CA), in order to identify a source of the <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA.</RTI> The template DNA used was from amplified cDNA plasmid libraries each containing 5 million independent cDNA clones. Reactions were assembled as per manufacturer's instructions using 400 <RTI ID=0.0>fmol/l</RTI> of each oligonucleotide and 2-20 gel purified plasmid library DNA as template. The cDNA libraries were derived from the following human tissues and cell lines: fetal brain, prostate smooth muscle, bone marrow, <RTI ID=0.0>RPMI1588,</RTI> thyroid, WI-38, testis, stimulated peripheral blood mononuclear cells, stimulated CD3+ cells, THP-1, activated tonsil, HACAT and fetal liver. Reactions were performed on a thermocycler machine using the following conditions: 30 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 20 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> for 3 minutes. At the conclusion of 30 cycles an additional single extension cycle of 8 minutes at <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> was run. PCR products were visualized by TAE agarose, gel electrophoresis in the presence of ethidium bromide followed by UV illumination. The most abundant product was found to be from a prostate smooth muscle cDNA library. The PCR reaction using prostate smooth muscle template and oligonucleotides ZC39982 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 64) and ZC39983 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 65) was repeated using a less robust but higher fidelity thermostable DNA polymerase"turboPFu", (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). Thirty amplification cycles were run with the following conditions: denaturing at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C,</RTI> 30 seconds, annealing at <RTI ID=0.0>63 C</RTI> 45 seconds, extension at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> 3.5 minutes. A single band product was gel purified on a 0.8% TAE, agarose gel.

This DNA was then amplified again using primers ZC39980 (SEQ ID NO : 66) and ZC39981 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 67) designed to include restriction enzyme recognition sequences to allow the cloning of this cDNA into a mammalian expression
<Desc/Clms Page number 187>
vector.

The PCR reaction was performed using"TurboPfu"and the purified PCR product for 15 cycles of: <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute, <RTI ID=0.0>64 C</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute 20 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> 4.5 minutes. The PCR reaction was then digested with EcoRl and Xhol (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) and gel purified as described above. A mammalian expression vector, pZ7NX, was prepared by digesting with EcoRl and Xhol and the PCR product was ligated to this vector and electroporated into E. <RTI ID=0.0>coli DHlOb</RTI> cells. Several bacterial colonies were isolated and sequenced. One clone was correct with the exception of a single non-conservative mutation. In order to change this base to match the expected sequence, an oligonucleotide spanning mutation and a neighboring Pstl restriction site was used in a PCR reaction with"TurboPfu"using the pZP7Nx-h. OncostatinM R plasmid previously sequenced as a template. The PCR amplified DNA was digested with Pstl and Xhol and cloned back into the pZP7Nx-h OncostatinM R plasmid in place of the Pstl/Xhol fragment containing the offending mutation. This new plasmid was sequenced over the recently amplified Pstl to Xhol region to confirm the correction and make sure no other errors were created in the amplification process.

This analysis confirmed sequence that matched the expected sequence over the coding region. The sequence is shown in SEQ ID NO : 6, and corresponding amino acid sequence shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 7.

Example 30 Constructs for Generating a Human Zcytorl 7/OncostatinM receptor (OSMRbeta) Heterodimer A system for construction, expression and purification of such soluble heterodimeric receptors is known in the art, and has been adapted to the receptor pair, human oncostatin M receptor (OSMRbeta) and human zcytorl7. For this construct, the polynucleotide for the soluble receptor for OSMRbeta is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 68 and corresponding polypeptide is shown in SEQ ID NO : 69; and the polynucleotide for the soluble receptor for human zcytorl7 is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 70 and corresponding polypeptide is shown in SEQ ID NO : 71.
To construct a cell line expressing a secreted soluble hzcytorl7/human
<Desc/Clms Page number 188>

OSMRbeta heterodimer, a construct was made so that the resulting heterodimeric soluble receptor comprises the extracellular domain of human OSMRbeta fused to the heavy chain of IgG gammal (Fc4) (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 37) with a Glu-Glu tag (SEQ ID NO : 35) at the C-terminus; while the extracellular domain of zcytoR17 is fused to Fc4 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 37) with a His tag (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 72) at the C-terminus. For both of the hzcytorl7 and human OSMRbeta arms of the heterodimer a Gly-Ser spacer of 12 amino acids (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 73) was engineered between the extracellular portion of the receptor and the N-terminus of Fc4.

A. Construction <RTI ID=0.0>of human soluble OSMRbetalFc4-CEE</RTI> For construction of the human soluble <RTI ID=0.0>OSMRbeta/Fc4-CEE</RTI> portion of the heterodimer the extracellular portion of human OSMRbeta was isolated using PCR with oligos ZC14063 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 48) and ZC41557 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 74) under PCR reaction conditions as follows: 30 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 60 sec., <RTI ID=0.0>57 C</RTI> for 30 sec. , and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 100 sec.; and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 min. PCR products were purified using QIAquick PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen), digested with EcoRl and <RTI ID=0.0>BglII</RTI> (Boerhinger- Mannheim), separated by gel electrophoresis and purified using a QIAquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen).

The expression cassette, plasmid backbone and <RTI ID=0.0>Fc4-GluGlu</RTI> tag portion of the chimera were contained within a previously made in house plasmid vector. The plasmid vector was digested with EcoRl and <RTI ID=0.0>BamHl</RTI> (Boerhinger-Mannheim), separated by gel electrophoresis and purified using a QIAquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen). The digested and purified fragments of human OSMRbeta and Fc4-cEE containing plasmid were ligated together using T4 DNA Ligase (Life Technologies, Bethesda, <RTI ID=0.0>MD)</RTI> using standard ligation methods. Minipreps of the resulting ligation were screened for an EcoRI/Smal insert of the correct size (772bp) for the soluble OSMRbeta and positive minipreps were sequenced to confirm accuracy of the PCR reaction. This new plasmid construction is termed <RTI ID=0.0>pZP9-ONCOMR-Fc4CEE.</RTI>
B. <RTI ID=0.0>Construction of human soluble Zcytorl 7/Fc4-CHIS</RTI> For construction of the <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7/Fc4-CHIS</RTI> portion of the heterodimer,
<Desc/Clms Page number 189>

the extracellular portion of human zcytorl7 was isolated by digestion of a plasmid previously containing Zcytorl7-Fc4 soluble receptor. The plasmid was first digested with Sall (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA) after which the reaction was serially phenol chloroform extracted and ethanol precipitated. The digested DNA was then treated with T4 DNA Polymerase (Boerhinger-Mannheim), to fill in the 5'overhangs created by the Sall digestion, leaving the DNA ends blunt, after which the reaction was serially phenol chloroform extracted and ethanol precipitated. The blunted DNA was then further <RTI ID=0.0>digested with BglII</RTI> to cut at the 3'end. ), separated by gel electrophoresis and purified using a QIAquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen) as per manufacturer's instruction. The resulting DNA fragment containing the sequence coding for the extracellular domain of zcytoR17 was ligated into an <RTI ID=0.0>Fc4-CHIS</RTI> tag containing mammalian expression vector prepared as follows.

The expression cassette, plasmid backbone and <RTI ID=0.0>Fc4-CHIS</RTI> tag portion of the chimera were contained within a previously made in house plasmid vector. This plasmid vector was digested with EcoRl (Boerhinger-Mannheim) after which the reaction was serially phenol chloroform extracted and ethanol precipitated. The digested DNA was then treated with T4 DNA Polymerase (Boerhinger-Mannheim), to fill in the 5'overhangs created by the EcoRl digestion, leaving the DNA ends blunt, after which the reaction was serially phenol chloroform extracted and ethanol precipitated. The blunted DNA was then further digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BamHl</RTI> (Boerhinger- Mannheim) to cut at the 3'end, separated by gel electrophoresis and purified using a QIAquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen). The digested and purified fragments of human zcytorl7 and <RTI ID=0.0>Fc4-CHIS</RTI> containing plasmid were ligated together using T4 DNA Ligase (Life Technologies, Bethesda, MD) using standard ligation methods.

Minipreps of the resulting ligation were screened by PCR using the zcytorl7 specific sense primer ZC29180 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 22) and the Fc4 specific antisense primer ZC29232 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 75) with the following PCR reaction conditions: 30 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 60 sec., <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> for 150 sec; and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 min. An expected product size of 848 bp confirmed the correct assembly of the plasmid termed pZEM228 <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7/Fc4HIS.</RTI>
A second zcytorl7-Fc4 construction was created for use in generating
<Desc/Clms Page number 190>

homodimer protein from COS cells. Briefly the coding region for the full fusion protein was isolated by digestion of a plasmid previously containing <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl7-Fc4</RTI> soluble receptor with Sall (Boerhinger-Mannheim). The reaction was serially phenol chloroform extracted and ethanol precipitated. The digested DNA was then treated with T4 DNA Polymerase (Boerhinger-Mannheim), to fill in the 5'overhangs created by the EcoRl digestion, leaving the DNA ends blunt, after which the reaction was serially phenol chloroform extracted and ethanol precipitated. The blunted DNA was then further digested with Notl (Boerhinger-Mannheim) to cut at the 3'end, separated by gel electrophoresis and purified using a QIAquick gel extraction kit (Qiagen). A mammalian expression vector containing a CMV driven expression cassette was digested to generate compatible ends and the 2 fragments were ligated together.

Minipreps of the resulting ligation were screened by PCR using the vector specific sense primer ZC14063 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 48) and the zcytorl7 specific antisense primer ZC27899 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 19) with the following PCR reaction conditions: 30 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 30 sec., <RTI ID=0.0>64 C</RTI> for 30 sec; <RTI ID=0.0>70 C</RTI> for 90 sec; and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 min. An expected product size of approximately 1000 bp confirmed the correct assembly of the plasmid termed pZP7NX-hzcytorl7-Fc4. This plasmid was subsequently transfected into COS cells using Lipofectamine (Gibco/BRL), as per manufacturer's instructions. The cells were conditioned for 60 hours in DMEM + 5% FBS (Gibco/BRL) after which the protein was purified over a protein G-sepharose 4B chromatography column and made available for in vitro bioassays, for example, such as those described herein.

C. Generating a Human Zcytorl 7/OncostatinM receptor (OSMRbeta) About <RTI ID=0.0>16, ug</RTI> each of the <RTI ID=0.0>pZP9-ONCOMR-Fc4CEE</RTI> and pZEM228 <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7/Fc4HIS</RTI> were co-transfected into BHK-570 (ATCC No. CRL-10314) cells using lipofectamine (Gibco/BRL), as per manufacturer's instructions. The transfected cells were selected for 10 days in DMEM + <RTI ID=0.0>5% FBS (Gibco/BRL)</RTI> containing 0.5 mg/ml G418 (Gibco/BRL) and 250 nM methyltrexate <RTI ID=0.0>(MTX)</RTI> (Sigma, St. Louis, MO) for 10 days.
The resulting pool of doubly-selected cells was used to generate the heterodimeric protein. Three cell Factories (Nunc, Denmark) of this pool were used to
<Desc/Clms Page number 191>

generate 10 L of serum free conditioned medium. This conditioned media was passed over <RTI ID=0.0>a 1 ml</RTI> protein-A column and eluted in (10) 750 microliter fractions. Four of these fractions found to have the highest concentration were pooled and dialyzed (10 kD MW cutoff) against PBS. The desired heterodimeric soluble <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/OSMRbeta</RTI> protein complex was isolated from other media components by passing the pool over a Nickel column and washing the column with various concentrations of Imidazole. The soluble zcytorl7/OSMRbeta protein eluted at intermediate concentrations of Imidazole, while <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7/Fc4HIS</RTI> homodimer eluted at higher concentrations of Imidazole.

Example 31 <RTI ID=0.0> Tissue Distribution of Human zcytorl 7 in Tissue Panels Using Northern Blot and PCR</RTI> A. Human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 7 Tissue Distribution using Northern Blot</RTI> Human Multiple Tissue Northern Blots (Human 12-lane MTN Blot I and <RTI ID=0.0>II,</RTI> and Human Immune System MTN Blot <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> ; Human Endocrine MTN, Human Fetal MTN Blot <RTI ID=0.0>II,</RTI> Human Multiple Tissue Array) (Clontech) as well as in house blots containing various tissues were probed to determine the tissue distribution of human zcytorl7 expression. The in-house prepared blots included the following tissue and cell line mRNA : <RTI ID=0.0>SK-Hep-1</RTI> cells, <RTI ID=0.0>THP1</RTI> cells, Adrenal gland (Clontech); Kidney (Clontech), Liver (Clontech and Invitrogen); Spinal cord (Clontech), Testis (Clontech), Human CD4+ T-cells, Human CD8+ T-cells, Human CD19+ T-cells, human mixed lymphocyte reaction (MLR), <RTI ID=0.0>THP1</RTI> cell line (ATCC No. <RTI ID=0.0>TIB-202),</RTI> U937 cell line, <RTI ID=0.0>p388D1</RTI> mouse <RTI ID=0.0>lymphoblast</RTI> cell line (ATCC No. CCL-46) with or without stimulation by Ionomycin ; and WI-38 human embryonic lung cell line (ATCC No. CRL-2221) with or without stimulation by Ionomycin.

An approximately 500 bp PCR derived probe for zcytorl7 (SE <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 4) was amplified using oligonucleotides ZC28, 575 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 77) and ZC27, 899 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 19) as primers. The PCR amplification was carried out as follows: 30 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 1 minute, <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> for 1 minute, and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute; followed by <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes. The PCR product was visualized by agarose gel electrophoresis and the approximately 500 bp PCR product was gel purified as described herein. The probe was radioactively labeled using the PRIME IT <RTI ID=0.0>UTm</RTI> Random Primer Labeling Kit
<Desc/Clms Page number 192>

(Stratagene) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The probe was purified using a <RTI ID=0.0>NUCTRAPTM</RTI> push column (Stratagene). <RTI ID=0.0>EXPRESSHYBTM</RTI> (Clontech) solution was used for the prehybridization and as a hybridizing solution for the Northern blots.

Prehybridization was carried out at <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> for 2 hours. Hybridization took place overnight at <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> with about <RTI ID=0.0>1.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>5X106 cpm/ml of</RTI> labeled probe. The blots were washed three times at room temperature in 2X SSC, 0. <RTI ID=0.0>05%</RTI> SDS, followed by <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> wash for 10 minutes in 2X SSC, 0.1% SDS at <RTI ID=0.0>50 C.</RTI> Several faint bands were seen after several days exposure. An approximately 9 kb transcript was seen in trachea, skeletal muscle and thymus; an approximately 2 kb transcript was seen in PBL, HPV, U937 and <RTI ID=0.0>THP-1</RTI> cells; and about a 1.2 kb transcript was seen in placenta, bone marrow and thyroid, and HPV and U937 cells. In all the tissues listed above, the signal intensity was faint.
There appeared to be little expression in most normal tissues, suggesting that zcytorl7 expression may be dependent on activation of the cell or tissues in which it is expressed.

B. Tissue Distribution in tissue panels using PCR A panel of cDNAs from human tissues was screened for zcytorl7 expression using PCR. The panel was made in-house and contained 94 marathon cDNA and cDNA samples from various normal and cancerous human tissues and cell lines as shown below in Table 13. The cDNAs came from in-house libraries or marathon cDNAs from in-house RNA preps, Clontech RNA, or Invitrogen RNA. The marathon cDNAs were made using the marathon-Ready kit (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) and QC tested with clathrin primers ZC21195 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 78) and ZC21196 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 79) and then diluted based on the intensity of the clathrin band. To assure quality of the panel samples, three tests for quality control (QC) were run: (1) To assess the RNA quality used for the libraries, the in-house cDNAs were tested for average insert size by PCR with vector oligos that were specific for the vector sequences for an individual cDNA library; (2) Standardization of the concentration of the cDNA in panel samples was achieved using standard PCR methods to amplify full length alpha tubulin or G3PDH cDNA using a 5'vector <RTI ID=0.0>oligo ZC14,</RTI> 063 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 48) and 3'alpha tubulin specific oligo primer ZC17, 574 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 49) or 3'
<Desc/Clms Page number 193>

G3PDH specific oligo primer ZC17,600 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 50); and (3) a sample was sent to sequencing to check for possible <RTI ID=0.0>ribosomal</RTI> or mitochondrial DNA contamination. The panel was set up in a 96-well format that included a human genomic DNA (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) positive control sample. Each well contained approximately 0.2-100 <RTI ID=0.0>pg/u. 1</RTI> of <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA.</RTI> The PCR reactions were set up using oligos ZC26,358 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 80) and ZC26,359 (SEQ ID NO : 81), TaKaRa Ex <RTI ID=0.0>Taq</RTI> (TAKARA Shuzo Co LTD, Biomedicals Group, Japan), and Rediload dye (Research Genetics, Inc., Huntsville, AL). The amplification was carried out as follows: <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 2 minutes, 35 cycles of <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 30 seconds, 66. <RTI ID=0.0>3 C</RTI> for 30 seconds and <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 30 seconds, followed by 1 cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>5</RTI> minutes. About <RTI ID=0.0>10</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ul</RTI> of the PCR reaction product was subjected to standard agarose gel electrophoresis using a 4% agarose gel.

The correct predicted DNA fragment size was observed in lymph node, prostate, thyroid, HPV (prostate epithelia), <RTI ID=0.0>HPVS</RTI> (prostate epithelia, selected), lung tumor, uterus tumor reactions, along with the genomic DNA reaction.

The DNA fragment for prostate tissue (2 samples), HPV (prostate epithelia), <RTI ID=0.0>HPVS</RTI> (prostate epithelia, selected), and genomic were excised and purified using a Gel Extraction Kit (Qiagen, Chatsworth, CA) according to manufacturer's instructions. Fragments were confirmed by sequencing to show that they were indeed zcytorl7.

Of the strong positive PCR signals, two were from the human monocyte cell lines U937 and <RTI ID=0.0>THP1.</RTI>

These two cell lines along with a prostate epithelia line were selected for further analysis by Northern blot. Previous attempts at visualizing a transcript by northern analysis using mRNA from various tissues yielded weak and diffuse signals in the surprisingly large size range of <RTI ID=0.0>7-lOkb</RTI> making this data difficult to interpret. A denaturing formaldehyde/MOPS/0.8% agarose gel was prepared (RNA Methodologies, Farrell, RE Academic Press) and <RTI ID=0.0>2</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>g</RTI> of polyA+ mRNA was run for each sample along side an RNA ladder (Life Technologies, Bethesda, MD). The gel was then transferred to Hybond nylon (Amersham, Buckinghamshire, UK), UV crosslinked, and hybridized in ExpressHyb solution (Clontech, LaJolla, CA) at <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> overnight using a probe to human zcytoRl7 generated by PCR with the oligos ZC28, 575 (SEQ ID NO : 77), and ZC27, 899 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>19)</RTI> and labeled with a Megaprime <RTI ID=0.0>32P</RTI> kit (Amersham). The northern blot was subsequently washed with 0. 2xSSC+0. <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> SDS at 65C for 15 minutes and exposed to film for 7 days with intensifying screens. A prominent 8kb band was seen in both the prostate epithelia and U937 lanes while a fainter band was present in the <RTI ID=0.0>THP1</RTI> lane.

To optimize the cDNA used as a hybridization probe, four different regions of the full-length human zcytoR17 sequence were amplified by PCR, labeled and hybridized as described above to southern blots containing genomic and amplified cDNA library DNA. The four probes, herein designated probes A-D, were amplified using the following primer pairs: (A) ZC28, 575 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 77), ZC27, 899 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 19); (B) ZC27, 895 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 20), ZC28, 917 (SEQ ID NO : 83); (C) ZC28, 916 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 84), ZC28, 918 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 85); and (D) ZC28, 916 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 84), ZC29, 122 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 21). Human genomic DNA along with amplified cDNA libraries demonstrated to contain zcytorl7 by PCR were digested with EcoRl and Xhol to liberate inserts and run out on duplicate TAE/0.8% agarose gels, denatured with <RTI ID=0.0>0.</RTI> 5M <RTI ID=0.0>NaOH,</RTI> 1.5 M <RTI ID=0.0>NaCI,</RTI> blotted to Hybond, UV crosslinked and each hybridized with a distinct probe. Probe B was found to have the least nonspecific binding and strongest signal. Thus, Probe B was used for all subsequent hybridizations.
<Desc/Clms Page number 198>

Given that the THP1 cells are an excellent model of circulating monocytes and expressed zcytorl7 at low levels we treated them with a variety of compounds in an effort to increase expression of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytoR17.</RTI> The cells were grown to a density of <RTI ID=0.0>2e5/ml,</RTI> washed and resuspended in various stimulating media, grown for four or thirty hours, and harvested for RNA preparations. Each media was supplemented with one of the following drugs or pairs of cytokines: LPS 2ug/ml (Sigma Chemicals, St. Louis, MO), <RTI ID=0.0>hTNFa</RTI> 2 ng/ml (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, <RTI ID=0.0>MN),</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>hGM-CSF</RTI> 2ng/ml (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, MN), hIFNy 50 ng/ml (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, MN), <RTI ID=0.0>hMCSF</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>lng/ml</RTI> (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, <RTI ID=0.0>MN),</RTI> hIL6 lng/ml (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, <RTI ID=0.0>MN),</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>hILl (3</RTI> 2ng/ml (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, MN), <RTI ID=0.0>hIFNy 50ng/ml+hILA 0. 5ng/ml</RTI> (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, <RTI ID=0.0>MN),</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>hIFNy</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>50ng/ml+hILlO lng/ml</RTI> (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, <RTI ID=0.0>MN),</RTI> PMA <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/ml</RTI> (Calbiochem, San Diego, CA) and an untreated control. At the end of the culture period Total RNA was prepared using an RNAeasy Midi-kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA).

Poly A+ RNA was selected from the total RNA using an MPG kit (CPG, Lincoln Park, NJ). Two micrograms of polyA+ RNA from each condition was run on <RTI ID=0.0>formaldehyde/MOPS/agarose</RTI> gels, transferred to nylon and <RTI ID=0.0>UV</RTI> crosslinked as described above. These northern blots were then hybridized, as above, to probe B at <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> overnight, washed at high stringency with 0.2XSSC, 0. <RTI ID=0.0>1%</RTI> SDS at 65C, exposed to film overnight then exposed to phosphor screens for signal quantitation. A dominant 8 kb mRNA as well a relatively weaker 2.8 kb band were seen in all lanes. A 20-fold increase in zcytorl7 mRNA was seen in RNA from cells treated with <RTI ID=0.0>hIFNy</RTI> for 30 hours, this effect was slightly muted with simultaneous treatment with <RTI ID=0.0>IL4.</RTI> Minor 3 fold increases in mRNA were seen in RNA from cells treated with LPS, TNFa and GM-CSF while MCSF, <RTI ID=0.0>IL6,</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>IL1 (3</RTI> had no effect on zcytorl7 mRNA levels. Taken together this data suggests a role for the zcytorl7 receptor and its ligand in monocyte macrophage biology and by extension any number of disease processes in which these cells participate.

Non-specific radioactive counts were washed off using. <RTI ID=0.0>1SSC/.</RTI> 5% SDS at <RTI ID=0.0>55 C.</RTI> The positive blots included the human 12 lane MTN (Clontech). Of the 12 tissues examined, only placenta was positive for an approximately 1.2 KB transcript.

Example <RTI ID=0.0>33</RTI> Construction of mammalian <RTI ID=0.0>expression vectors that express human zcytorl7lig-CEE</RTI> A. Construction <RTI ID=0.0>of zCytorl 7Lig-CEE/pZMP21</RTI> An expression plasmid containing all or part of a polynucleotide encoding zCytorl7Lig-CEE (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 95) was constructed via homologous recombination. The plasmid was called <RTI ID=0.0>zCytorl7Lig-CEE/pZMP21.</RTI>

The construction of <RTI ID=0.0>zCytorl7Lig-CEE/pZMP21</RTI> was accomplished by generating a zCytorl7Lig-CEE fragment using PCR amplification. The DNA template used for the production of the zCytorl7Lig-CEE fragment was zCytorl7Lig/pZP7nx.

The primers used for the production of the zCytorl7Lig-CEE fragment were: (1) ZC41,607 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 97) (sense sequence), which includes from the 5'to the 3'end: 28bp of the vector flanking sequence (5'of the insert) and 21 bp corresponding to the 5'sequence of zCytorl7Lig; and (2) ZC41, 605 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 98) (anti-sense sequence), which includes from the <RTI ID=0.0>5'to</RTI> the 3'end: 37 bp of the vector flanking sequence (3'of the insert), 3 bp of the stop codon, 21 bp encoding a C-terminal EE tag, and 21 bp corresponding to the 3'end of zCytorl7Lig sequence. The fragment resulting from the above PCR amplification is a copy of the template zCytorl7Lig with the addition of a
<Desc/Clms Page number 200>
C-terminal EE tag, yielding a final product zCytorl7Lig-CEE.

PCR reactions were run as follows: To a <RTI ID=0.0>1001il final</RTI> volume was added: 10 l of lOx Taq Polymerase Reaction Buffer with 15mM MgCI (Gibco), <RTI ID=0.0>1, ltl</RTI> of Taq DNA Polymerase (5 <RTI ID=0.0>units/yl,</RTI> Gibco), 3 l of 10mM dNTPs, <RTI ID=0.0>78, u1 dH2O, 3y1</RTI> of a 20 <RTI ID=0.0>pmol/Al</RTI> stock of primer ZC41, 607 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 97) <RTI ID=0.0>3AI</RTI> of a 20 <RTI ID=0.0>pmol/1</RTI> stock of primer ZC41,605 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 98), and <RTI ID=0.0>2y1</RTI> of a 0. <RTI ID=0.0>13g/jnl</RTI> stock of <RTI ID=0.0>zCytorl71ig</RTI> template DNA. A volume equal to 50 of mineral oil was added to the mixture. The reaction was heated to <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 5 minutes, followed by 35 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute; <RTI ID=0.0>55 C</RTI> for 2 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 3 minutes; followed by a 10 minute extension at <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> and held at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> until the reaction was collected.

The plasmid pZMP21 was restriction digested with <RTI ID=0.0>BglII</RTI> enzyme, cleaned with a QiaQuick PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen) using a microcentrifuge protocol, and used for recombination with the PCR fragment. Plasmid pZMP21 was constructed from <RTI ID=0.0>pZMP20</RTI> which was constructed from pZP9 (deposited at the American Type Culture Collection, 10801 University Boulevard, Manassas, VA 20110- 2209, and is designated No. 98668) with the yeast genetic elements from pRS316 (deposited at the American Type Culture Collection, 10801 University Boulevard, Manassas, VA 20110-2209, and designated No. 77145), an IRES element from poliovirus, and the extracellular domain of CD8, truncated at the carboxyl terminal end of the transmembrane domain. PZMP21 is a mammalian expression vector containing an expression cassette having the MPSV promoter, immunoglobulin signal peptide intron, multiple restriction sites for insertion of coding sequences, a stop codon and a human growth hormone terminator. The plasmid also has an E. coli origin of replication, a mammalian selectable marker expression unit having an SV40 promoter, enhancer and origin of replication, a <RTI ID=0.0>DHFR</RTI> gene, the SV40 terminator, as well as the URA3 and CEN-ARS sequences required for selection and replication in <RTI ID=0.0>S.</RTI> cerevisiae.

Fifty microliters of competent yeast cells <RTI ID=0.0>(S.</RTI> cerevisiae) were independently combined with 100 ng of cut plasmid, <RTI ID=0.0>5</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ul</RTI> of previously described PCR mixture, and transferred to a 0.2 cm electroporation cuvette. The yeast/DNA mixture was electropulsed at 0.75 kV (5 kV/cm), <RTI ID=0.0>oo</RTI> ohms, 25 F. Each cuvette had 600 <RTI ID=0.0>y1</RTI> of 1.2 M sorbitol added, and the yeast was plated in one 100 <RTI ID=0.0>jul</RTI> aliquot and one <RTI ID=0.0>300 Al</RTI>

aliquot onto two URA-D plates and incubated at <RTI ID=0.0>30 C.</RTI> After about 72 hours, the Ura+ yeast transformants from a single plate were resuspended in <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> ml H2O and spun briefly to pellet the yeast cells. The cell pellet was resuspended in 500 <RTI ID=0.0>ttl</RTI> of lysis buffer (2% Triton X-100, 1% SDS, 100 mM NaCI, 10 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA). The 500 <RTI ID=0.0>Al</RTI> of the lysis mixture was added to an Eppendorf tube containing 300 Ill acid washed <RTI ID=0.0>60OIAm</RTI> glass beads and <RTI ID=0.0>300</RTI> l phenol-chloroform, vortexed for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute intervals two or three times, followed by a 5 minute spin in a Eppendorf centrifuge at maximum speed.
