Following electroporation, 600 l SOC (2% <RTI ID=0.0>Bacto'Tryptone</RTI> (Difco, Detroit, <RTI ID=0.0>MI),</RTI> 0.5% yeast extract (Difco), 10 mM <RTI ID=0.0>NaCI,</RTI> 2.5 mM KCI, 10 mM <RTI ID=0.0>MgCI2,</RTI> 10 mM <RTI ID=0.0>MgS04,</RTI> 20 mM glucose) was added. The electroporated E. coli cells were plated in a <RTI ID=0.0>200AI</RTI> and a 50 l aliquot on two LB AMP plates (LB broth (Lennox), 1.8% Bacto Agar (Difco), 100 mg/L Ampicillin). The plates were incubated upside down for about 24 hours at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C.</RTI> Three Ampicillin-resistant colonies were selected at random and submitted for sequence analysis of the insert.
Large-scale plasmid DNA was isolated from a sequence-confirmed clone using the Qiagen Maxi kit (Qiagen) according to manufacturer's instructions.

B. <RTI ID=0.0>Construction of mouse zCytorl 7Lig (m)-CEE/pZMP21</RTI> An expression plasmid containing the entire polynucleotide encoding murine <RTI ID=0.0>zCytorl7Lig-CEE</RTI> (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 104 and SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : <RTI ID=0.0>105)</RTI> was also constructed via homologous recombination using the method described in Example 33A above.

The primers used were: (1) ZC41643 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 106) (forward, 5'to 3'sense) having a 28bp vector overlap 5'of the insertion point; 21 bp of the 5'end of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> (m) and (2) ZC41641 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 107) (reverse, 5'to 3'anti-sense) having a 37bp vector
<Desc/Clms Page number 202>

overlap 3'of the insertion point; 3 bp stop codon; 21 bp C-terminal EE tag; 24 bp of the 3'end of <RTI ID=0.0>zCytorl7Lig</RTI> (m) -CEE. The plasmid was called <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>(m)-CEE/pZMP21.</RTI>
The polynucleotide sequence of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> (m) -CEE is shown in SEQ ID NO : 104, and corresponding polypeptide sequence is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>m</RTI> NO : 105.

Example 34 <RTI ID=0.0> Transfection And Expression Of zcytorl lig-CEE Polypeptides</RTI> A. Expression <RTI ID=0.0>of human zCytorl 7Lig-CEE/pZMP21 in 293Tcells</RTI> ZCytorl7Lig-CEE was expressed transiently in 293T cells (Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA; ATCC No. SD-3515) to generate initial purified protein. The day before the transfection, 293T cells were seeded at 6. <RTI ID=0.0>5x104</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>cells/cm2</RTI> in 30 T162 culture flasks with a total volume of 30ml of culture media (SL7V4 +5% FBS <RTI ID=0.0>+1%</RTI> Pen/Strep) per flask. The cells were allowed to incubate for 24 hours at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C.</RTI>

A DNA/Liposome mixture was prepared as follows: Two 50 ml conical tubes were filled with 25 mLs of transfection media (SL7V4 <RTI ID=0.0>+1%</RTI> Pen/Strep) and 1.13 mg of <RTI ID=0.0>zCytorl7Lig-CEE/pZMP21</RTI> (Example 33) was added to each. A separate set of two 50 ml conical tubes were filled with 22 ml of transfection media (above) and 3 ml of liposomes (Lipofectamine, Gibco) was added to each. For each set of tubes, one tube of DNA was added to one tube of liposomes and the DNA/liposome mix was incubated for 30 minutes. The two 50 ml conical tubes containing the DNA/liposome mixtures were pooled (about 100 <RTI ID=0.0>ml)</RTI> and 300 ml of transfection media was added.

The 30 flasks of the 293T cells were decanted, washed lx with about 15 ml of PBS, and 12.5 ml of the diluted DNA/liposome mixture was added to each flask. The flasks were incubated for 3 hours at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C.</RTI> After the incubation period, 25 ml of culture media (above) were added to each T162 flask. The transfection media was harvested after approximately 96 hours and was used for protein purification (Example 35).

B. <RTI ID=0.0>Expression of mouse zCytorl7Lig-CEE (m) lpZMP21 in 293T cells</RTI> Mouse zCytorl7Lig (m) -CEE was expressed transiently in 293T cells as described in Example 34A and cultured media was used for protein purification (Example 35).
<Desc/Clms Page number 203>

<RTI ID=0.0> Example 35</RTI> Purification <RTI ID=0.0>of Zcytorl7lig-CEE from 293T cells</RTI> Unless otherwise noted, all operations were carried out at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI> The following procedure was used for purifying both mouse and human <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> containing C-terminal Glu-Glu (EE) tags (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 103). Conditioned media from 293T cells expressing <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig-CEE</RTI> (Example 34) was purified. Total target protein concentrations of the conditioned media were determined via SDS-PAGE and Western blot analysis with the anti-EE antibody.

A 5.5 ml column of anti-EE Poros 50 A (PE BioSystems, Framingham, MA) (prepared as described below) was poured in a Waters AP-1, <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cm x 7cm glass column (Waters, Milord, MA). The column was flow packed and equilibrated on a BioCad Sprint (PE BioSystems, Framingham, MA) with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) pH 7.4. The conditioned media was adjusted with NaCI to 0.3 M and the pH adjusted to 7.2. The conditioned media was then loaded on the column overnight with about 3 ml/minute flow rate. The column was washed with 10 column volumes (CVs) of PBS pH 7.4, and again washed with 3CVs <RTI ID=0.0>5X</RTI> Sigma PBS pH 7.4. It was step eluted with 0.5 M Acetate, 0.5 M <RTI ID=0.0>NaCI,</RTI> pH 2.5 at 3 ml/minute. The fraction tubes contained <RTI ID=0.0>lml</RTI> Tris base (no pH adjustment) to neutralize the elution immediately. The column was again washed for 2CVs with <RTI ID=0.0>5X</RTI> Sigma PBS, pH 7.4 to neutralize the column and then equilibrated in PBS (pH 7.4). Two ml fractions were collected over the entire elution chromatography and absorbance at 280 and 215 nM were monitored; the pass through and wash pools were also saved and analyzed. The 5X PBS and the acid elution peak fractions were analyzed for the target protein via SDS-PAGE Silver staining and Western Blotting with the primary antibody anti-EE and secondary antibody, anti mouse-HRP conjugated. The acid elution fractions of interest were pooled and concentrated from 38 ml to 0. <RTI ID=0.0>8ml</RTI> using a 5000 Dalton molecular weight cutoff membrane spin concentrator (Millipore, Bedford, MA) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
To separate <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig-CEE</RTI> from aggregated material and any other contaminating co-purifying proteins, the pooled concentrated fractions were subjected
<Desc/Clms Page number 204>

to size exclusion chromatography on a 1.6 x 60 cm (120 <RTI ID=0.0>ml)</RTI> Superdex 75 (Pharmacia, Piscataway, NJ) column equilibrated and loaded in PBS at a flow rate of 1.0 ml/min using a BioCad Sprint. Three milliliter fractions were collected across the entire chromatography and the absorbance at 280 and 215 nM were monitored. The peak fractions were characterized via SDS-PAGE Silver staining, and only the most pure fractions were pooled. This material represented purified <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig-CEE</RTI> protein.

On Western blotted, Coomassie Blue and Silver stained SDS-PAGE gels, the <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig-CEE</RTI> was one major band. The protein concentration of the purified material was performed by BCA analysis (Pierce, Rockford, IL) and the protein was aliquoted, and stored <RTI ID=0.0>at-80 C</RTI> according to standard procedures.

To prepare PorosA50 anti-EE, a 65 ml bed volume of Poros A50 (PE Biosystems) was washed with 100 ml of water and then 0.1 M triethanolamine, pH 8.2 (TEA, ICN, Aurora, Ohio), <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> M <RTI ID=0.0>Na2S04,</RTI> pH 8.8 containing 0.02% sodium azide using a vacuum flask filter unit. The EE monoclonal antibody solution, at a concentration of 2 mg/ml in a volume of 300 <RTI ID=0.0>ml,</RTI> was mixed with the washed resin in a volume of 250 ml.

After an overnight incubation at room temperature, the unbound antibody was removed by washing the resin with 5 volumes of 200 mM TEA, 1 M <RTI ID=0.0>Na2S04,</RTI> pH 8.8 containing 0.02% sodium azide as described above. The resin was resuspended in 2 volumes of TEA, <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> M <RTI ID=0.0>Na2S04,</RTI> pH 8.8 containing 0.02% sodium azide and transferred to a suitable container. Three ml of 25 mg/ml (68mM) <RTI ID=0.0>Disuccinimidyl</RTI> suberate (in DMSO supplied by Pierce, Rockford, IL) is added and the solution is incubated for three hours at room temperature. Nonspecific sites on the resin were then blocked by incubating for 10 min at room temperature with 5 volumes of 20 mM ethanolamine (Sigma, St. Louis, MO) in 200 mM TEA, pH 8.8 using the vacuum flask filter unit. The resin is washed with PBS, pH 7.4, followed by 0.1 M Glycine, pH 3 and then neutralized with 10X PBS. After washing with distilled water, the final coupled anti-EE Poros-A 50 resin was stored at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> in 20% Ethanol.
Example <RTI ID=0.0>36</RTI> N-terminal sequencing of human and mouse Zcytorl 7lig <RTI ID=0.0>A.,</RTI> N-terminal sequencing of human Zcytorl lig
<Desc/Clms Page number 205>

Standard automated N-terminal polypeptide sequencing (Edman degradation) was performed using reagents from Applied Biosystems. N-terminal sequence analysis was performed on a Model 494 Protein Sequencer System (Applied Biosystems, Inc. , Foster City, CA). Data analysis was performed with Model 610A Data Analysis System for Protein Sequencing, version 2. 1a (Applied Biosystems).
A purified human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig-CEE</RTI> sample (Example 35) was supplied.
The sample was loaded onto a prepared glass fiber filter for n-terminal sequencing. The glass fiber filter was prepared by precycling it with Biobrene <RTI ID=0.0>.</RTI>

N-terminal sequence analysis of the secreted human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> polypeptide did not verify the predicted cleavage site of the signal sequence but resulted in a mature start at residue 27 (Leu) in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 2 of the human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> precursor sequence.

B. <RTI ID=0.0>N-terminal sequencing of human Zcytorl7lig</RTI> Standard automated N-terminal polypeptide sequencing (Edman degradation) was performed using reagents from Applied Biosystems. N-terminal sequence analysis was performed on a Model 494 Protein Sequencer System (Applied Biosystems, Inc. , Foster City, CA). Data analysis was performed with Model 610A Data Analysis System for Protein Sequencing, version 2. 1a (Applied Biosystems).

A purified mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig-CEE</RTI> sample was supplied as captured on Protein G Sepharose/anti-EE beads (Example 35). The beads were placed in reducing SDS PAGE sample buffer and on a boiling water bath before running on SDS PAGE, using a Novex SDS PAGE system (4-12% Bis-Tris MES NuPAGE ; Invitrogen) as per manufacturer's instructions. The gel was electrotransferred to a Novex PVDF membrane (Invitrogen), and Coomassie blue stained (Sigma, St. Louis, MO) using standard methods. Corresponding anti-EE Western blots were performed to identify the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> band for N-terminal protein sequencing. The mouse anti-EE IgG HRP conjugated antibody used was produced in house.

N-terminal sequence analysis of the secreted mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> polypeptide verified the predicted cleavage site of the signal sequence resulting in a mature start at 31 (Ala) in reference to SEQ ID NO : 11 and SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 91 of the mouse
<Desc/Clms Page number 206>
<RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig</RTI> precursor sequence.

Example 37 Cos cell binding assay A binding assay was used to test the binding of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> to receptors comprising zcytorl7 receptor, such as the zcytorl7 receptor or receptor heterodimers and trimers comprising zcytorl7 receptor (e. g. , zcytorl7/OSMR, zcytorl7/WSX-1, or <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7/OSMR/WSX-l,</RTI> or other Class I cytokine receptor subunits). Zcytorl7 receptor plasmid DNA was transfected into COS cells and transfected COS cells were used to assess binding of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> to receptors comprising zcytorl7 receptor as described below.

A. COS Cell Transfections The COS cell transfection was performed as follows: Mix 800 ng receptor plasmid DNA in the following combinations: pZp7pX/zcytorl7 alone; pZp7Z/WSX-1 alone; <RTI ID=0.0>pZp7NX/OSMR</RTI> alone; pZp7pX/zcytorl7 + pZp7NX/OSMR; pZp7pX/zcytorl7 + pZp7Z/WSX-1 ; pZp7NX/OSMR + <RTI ID=0.0>pZp7Z/WSX-1</RTI> ; pZp7pX/zcytorl7 + <RTI ID=0.0>pZp7NX/OSMR</RTI> + <RTI ID=0.0>pZp7Z/WSX-l)</RTI> and 4ul Lipofectamine in 80 Al serum free DMEM media <RTI ID=0.0>(55mg</RTI> sodium pyruvate, 146mg L-glutamine, 5mg transferrin, 2. 5mg insulin, <RTI ID=0.0>Igg</RTI> selenium and 5mg fetuin in 500ml DMEM), incubate at room temperature for 30 minutes and then add 320 <RTI ID=0.0>tl</RTI> serum free DMEM media. Add this 400ul mixture onto 2 xlO COS cells/well plated on 12-well tissue culture plate (fibronectin-coated) and incubate for 5 hours at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C.</RTI> Add 500ul 20% FBS DMEM media (100 ml FBS, 55 mg sodium pyruvate and 146mg L-glutamine in 500ml DMEM) and incubate overnight.

B. Binding Assay The binding assay was performed as follows: media was rinsed off cells with PBS <RTI ID=0.0>+ 0.</RTI> 1% BSA, and then cells were blocked for 60 minutes with the same solution. The cells were then incubated for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> hour in PBS <RTI ID=0.0>+ 0.</RTI> 1% BSA with 1.0 <RTI ID=0.0>g/ml</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71igCEE</RTI> purified protein. Cells were then washed with PBS <RTI ID=0.0>+ 0.</RTI> 1% BSA and
<Desc/Clms Page number 207>

incubated for another hour with 1: 1000 diluted mouse <RTI ID=0.0>anti-GluGlu</RTI> antibody. Again cells were washed with PBS <RTI ID=0.0>+ 0. 1%</RTI> BSA, then incubated for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> hour with 1: 200 diluted goat anti-mouse-HRP conjugated antibody.

Positive binding was detected with fluorescein tyramide reagent diluted 1: 50 in dilution buffer (NEN kit) and incubated for 4-6 minutes, and washed with PBS + 0. 1% BSA. Cells were fixed for 15 minutes with 1.8% Formaldehyde in PBS, then washed with PBS + <RTI ID=0.0>0.</RTI> 1% BSA. Cells were preserved with Vectashield Mounting Media (Vector Labs Burlingame, CA) diluted 1: 5 in PBS. Cells were visualized using a FITC filter on fluorescent microscope.

Positive binding was detected for cells transfected with zcytorl7 only, <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7+OSMRbeta,</RTI> zcytorl7+WSX-1, and <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7+OSMRbeta+WSX-1.</RTI> No binding was detected for cells transfected with WSX-1 + OSMRbeta, with OSMRbeta only, or with <RTI ID=0.0>WSX-1</RTI> only.

Example 38 Mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig activates mouse zcytorl7/OSMRbeta receptor-in luciferase assay</RTI> A. <RTI ID=0.0>Cloning offull-length mouse zcytorl 7 and mouse OSMRbeta for expression</RTI> A mouse testes cDNA library was screened for a full-length clone of mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytoR17.</RTI> The library was plated at 65,500 cfu/plate on 24 LB + Amp plates.

Filter lifts were prepared using Hybond N (Amersham-Pharmacia Biotech, Inc., Piscataway, NJ) on a total of approximately 1.6 million colonies. The filters were marked with a hot needle for orientation and then denatured for 6 minutes in 0.5 M NaOH and 1.5 M <RTI ID=0.0>Tris-HCI,</RTI> pH 7.2. The filters were then neutralized in 1.5 M NaCI and 0.5 M Tris-HCI, pH 7.2 for 6 minutes. The DNA was affixed to the filters using a UV crosslinker <RTI ID=0.0>(Stratalinker@, </RTI> Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) at 1200 joules. The filters were then left to dry overnight at room temperature.

The next day, the filters were pre-washed at <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> in pre-wash buffer consisting of 0.25X SSC, 0.25% SDS and ImM EDTA. Cell debris was manually removed using <RTI ID=0.0>Kimwipes (g) (Kimberly-Clark)</RTI> and the solution was changed 3 times over a period of 1 hour. Filters were air dried and stored at room temperature until needed. The filters were then prehybridized for approximately 3 hours at <RTI ID=0.0>63 C</RTI> in 20 ml
<Desc/Clms Page number 208>
of <RTI ID=0.0>ExpressHybHybridization</RTI> Solution (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA).

Probe B (Example 31) was generated by PCR from human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytoR17</RTI> template using oligonucleotide primers ZC27,895 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 20) and ZC28,917 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 83) and was radioactively labeled with 32p using a commercially available kit <RTI ID=0.0>(Megaprime</RTI> DNA Labeling System; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, Piscataway, NJ) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The probe was purified using a <RTI ID=0.0>StratageneT" push</RTI> column <RTI ID=0.0>(NucTrap@ </RTI> column; Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). The probe was denatured at <RTI ID=0.0>100 C</RTI> for 15 min and added to <RTI ID=0.0>ExpressHyb.</RTI> Filters were hybridized in <RTI ID=0.0>15</RTI> ml hybridizing solution containing 1.6 x 106 <RTI ID=0.0>cpm/ml</RTI> of probe at <RTI ID=0.0>63 C</RTI> overnight.

Filters were washed at <RTI ID=0.0>55 C</RTI> in 2X SSC, 0.1 <RTI ID=0.0>%</RTI> SDS and <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> mM EDTA and exposed to X-ray film <RTI ID=0.0>at-80 C</RTI> for 4 1/2 days. Thirteen positives were picked from the plates as plugs and placed in <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> ml LB +amp in 1.7 ml tubes. Tubes were placed at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> overnight. These 13 positives were subjected to two further rounds of purification. The tertiary plates were outgrown at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C</RTI> after filter lifts were taken and single colonies were picked and sent to sequencing. Three of these were determined to contain sequence of the mouse ortholog of zcytoR17.

In addition, a PCR product was generated using CTLL-2 cDNA as a template and oligonucleotides ZC38, 239 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 123) and ZC38,245 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 124) as primers. CTLL-2 is a mouse cytotoxic T lymphocyte cell line (ATCC No.

<RTI ID=0.0>TIB-214).</RTI> This PCR reaction was run as follows: <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> cycle at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 1 minute, 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 15 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> for 3 minutes, then <RTI ID=0.0>68 C</RTI> for 10 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> soak.

The PCR reaction used approximately 0.5 ng of <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA,</RTI> 20 pmoles of each oligonucleotide, and <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>tl</RTI> of Advantage <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> polymerase mix (ClonTech). About 6% of the PCR product was used as a template in a new PCR reaction, as above, except with oligonucleotides ZC38, 239 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 123) and ZC38, 238 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 125). This PCR reaction was run as follows: 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>94 C</RTI> for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>65 C</RTI> for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute, then <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>10 C</RTI> soak. Most of the PCR reaction was loaded on a 1.0% agarose gel and the predominant band at approximately 360 bp was excised, the DNA fragment was eluted, and DNA sequencing was performed.
The sequence of the mouse zcytorl7 polynucleotide is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI>
<Desc/Clms Page number 209>

NO : 126 and the corresponding amino acid sequence shown in SEQ ID NO : 127. In addition, a truncated soluble form of the mouse zcytorl7 polynucleotide is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 128 and the corresponding amino acid sequence shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 129.

To obtain a full-length mouse OSMRbeta <RTI ID=0.0>cDNA,</RTI> 5'and 3'PCR products were isolated and joined using an internal <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> site. The PCR primers were designed using the nucleotide sequence SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 134 and include EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI</RTI> restriction sites for cloning purposes. The genomic mouse OSMRbeta nucleic acid sequence is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 134, wherein the coding sequence encompasses residues 780 to 3692 encoding a mouse OSMRbeta 970 amino acid polypeptide, which is shown in SEQ ID NO : 135. A degenerate nucleic acid sequence which encodes the polypeptide of SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 135 is shown in SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 136.

A 5'PCR product was generated using an in-house 3T3-L1 (differentiated mouse adipocyte) cDNA library as a template and oligonucleotides ZC41, 764 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 130) and ZC41,598 (SEQ ID NO : <RTI ID=0.0>131)</RTI> as primers. This 5'PCR reaction was run as follows: 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>55 C</RTI> for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute 30 seconds, then <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> soak. The PCR reaction used approximately <RTI ID=0.0>3, ug</RTI> of plasmid prepared from the cDNA library, 20 pmoles of each oligonucleotide, and five units of Pwo DNA polymerase (Roche). About 90% of the 5'PCR product was digested with EcoRI and BamHI and gel purified on a 1.0% agarose gel. The approximately 1446 bp band was excised and used for ligation (see below).

A 3'PCR product was generated using a mouse placenta in-house cDNA library as a template and oligonucleotides ZC41, 948 (SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 132) and ZC41, 766 (SEQ ID NO : 133) as primers. This 3'PCR reaction was run as follows: 30 cycles at <RTI ID=0.0>95 C</RTI> for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>55 C</RTI> for 45 seconds, <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> minute 30 seconds, then <RTI ID=0.0>72 C</RTI> for 7 minutes; <RTI ID=0.0>4 C</RTI> soak. The PCR reaction used approximately <RTI ID=0.0>3 yg</RTI> of plasmid prepared from the cDNA library, 20 pmoles of each oligonucleotide, and five units of Pwo DNA polymerase (Roche). About 90% of the 3'PCR product was digested with BamHI and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI</RTI> and gel purified on a 1.0% agarose gel. The approximately 2200 bp band was excised and used for ligation along with the 5'PCR product (described above) to the
<Desc/Clms Page number 210>

expression vector <RTI ID=0.0>pZP-5Z</RTI> digested with EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI.</RTI> The three-part ligation was performed with the 5'EcoRI to <RTI ID=0.0>BamHI</RTI> fragment above, the <RTI ID=0.0>3'BamHI</RTI> to <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI</RTI> fragment, and the expression vector <RTI ID=0.0>pZP-5Z</RTI> digested with EcoRI and <RTI ID=0.0>XbaI.</RTI> This generated a <RTI ID=0.0>pZP-5Z</RTI> plasmid containing a full-length cDNA for mouse OSMRbeta (nucleotides 780 to 3692 of SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 134), designated <RTI ID=0.0>pZP-5Z/OSMRbeta.</RTI> The full length mouse OSMRbeta cDNA in <RTI ID=0.0>pZP5Z/OSMRbeta</RTI> has two amino acid insertions from SEQ <RTI ID=0.0>ID</RTI> NO : 135. There is a duplication of amino acid Glycine at position 370 and a duplication of amino acid Glutamic Acid at position 526. Plasmid <RTI ID=0.0>pZP-5Z</RTI> is a mammalian expression vector containing an expression cassette having the CMV promoter, multiple restriction sites for insertion of coding sequences, and a human growth hormone terminator. The plasmid also has an E. coli origin of replication, a mammalian selectable marker expression unit having an SV40 promoter, enhancer and origin of replication, a zeocin resistance gene and the SV40 terminator.
The resulting transformants were sequenced to confirm the mouse OSMRbeta cDNA sequence.

B. Construction of <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/KZ134/zcytorl7m, BaF3/KZ134/zcytorl7mlOSMRbetam,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>BHKlKZl34/zcytorl7m, and BHKlKZl 3/zcytorl7mlOSMRbetam cell lines</RTI> Stable <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/KZ134</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>BHK/KZ134</RTI> cell lines (Example 20) were transfected with an expression plasmid encoding full-length mouse zcytorl7, pZP- 7P/zcytorl7m (Example 38A), to create <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/KZ134/zcytorl7m</RTI> and BHK/KZ134/zcytorl7m cells, respectively. The results of this assay confirm the STAT reporter response of the <RTI ID=0.0>BaF3/KZ134/zcytorl7m/OSMRbetam</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>BHK/KZ134/zcytorl7m/OSMRbetam</RTI> cells to the mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> when compared to either the BaF3/KZ134/zcytorl7m cells, the BHK/KZ134/zcytorl7m cells or the untransfected BaF3/KZ134 or BHK/KZ134 control cells, and show that the response is mediated through the mouse zcytorl7/OSMRbeta receptors. The results also show that the human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> does not activate the STAT reporter assay through the mouse receptor complex.

To test the binding properties of human zcytorl7 ligand to different receptor combinations both BHK and BAF3 cells were transfected with expression plasmids using standard techniques well-known in the art. These plasmids were transfected into both cell lines in the following combinations: zcytorl7 alone, OSMRbeta alone, and both zcytorl7 and OSMRbeta. Transfection was performed as detailed above. Untransfected BHK and BAF3 cells were used as controls. Cells were stained by FACS as follows: 2E5 cells were stained with either: 2. 0 g/mL, 100ng/mL, <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/mL,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>l. Ong/mL, 100pg/mL, lOpg/mL, l. Opg/mL</RTI> of biotinylated zcytorl7L or left unstained for 30 minutes on ice in FACS buffer (PBS + 2% BSA + 2% NHS (Gemini) + 2% NGS). Cells were washed 1.5 times and then stained with SA-PE (Jackson Immune Laboratories) at 1: 250 for 30 minutes on ice. Cells were then washed 1.5 times with FACS buffer and resuspended in FACS buffer and analyzed by FACS on a BD FACSCaliber using <RTI ID=0.0>CellQuest</RTI> software (Becton Dickinson, Mountain View, CA).

Both BHK and BAF3 cells showed that zcytorl7 ligand bound to both zcytorl7 alone and in combination with OSMRbeta with the binding to the zcytorl7/OSMRbeta heterodimer being slightly stronger. No binding was seen in either cell lines expressing OSMRbeta alone. The zcytorl7 ligand bound in a concentration dependent manner. Example 40 Gene Expression Array Analysis of Human <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl7lig Treated Cells</RTI> RNA was isolated from human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> treated A549 cells, <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> treated <RTI ID=0.0>SK-LU-1</RTI> cells, and untreated control cells using a RNeasy Midi Kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA) according to the manufactures instructions.

Gene expression profiling of the cells treated with <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> and the respective control cells was carried out using GEArray Q series cDNA expression arrays (SuperArray Inc. , Bethesda, MD). The Q Series cDNA expression arrays contain up to 96 cDNA fragments associated with a specific biological pathway, or genes with similar functions or structural features. Comparison of arrays from treated and control cells allows for a determination of the up and down regulation of specific genes. Probe labeling, hybridization and detection were carried out according to the manufactures instructions. Chemiluminscent signal detection and data acquisition was carried out on a Lumi-Imager workstation (Roche, Indianapolis, IN). The resulting image data was analyzed using ImageQuant 5.2 (Amersham Biosciences, Inc. , Piscataway, NJ) and GEArray Analyzer 1.2 (SuperArray Inc. , Bethesda, MD) software.

Analysis of the results from the Human Interleukin and Receptor Q series HS-014N arrays, showed, after normalization, an approximate 4.7 fold increase of IL13RA2 signal in the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> treated human SK-LU-1 cells and an approximate 2.2 fold increase of the IL13RA2 signal in the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> treated human A549 cells.

These results indicate that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> significantly up regulated <RTI ID=0.0>IL13RA2</RTI> in the SK-LU-1 and A549 cells. Both of these are established cell lines derived from human lung carcinomas (Blobel et al., Virchows Arch B Cell Pathol Incl Mol Pathol., 1984; <RTI ID=0.0>45</RTI> (4): 407-29). More specifically, A549 is characterized as a human pulmonary epithelial cell line (Lin, et al., <RTI ID=0.0>J Pharm Pharmacol.,</RTI> 2002 Sep; 54 (9): 1271-8; Martinez et al., Toxicol <RTI ID=0.0>Sci.,</RTI> 2002 Oct; 69 (2): 409-23).

Interleukin-13 <RTI ID=0.0>(IL13),</RTI> a cytokine secreted by activated T lymphocytes, has been demonstrated to be both necessary and sufficient for the expression of allergic asthma and for use in experimental models of asthma, which include airway <RTI ID=0.0>hyperresponsiveness,</RTI> eosinophil recruitment, and mucus overproduction (Wills-Karp et
<Desc/Clms Page number 214>

<RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Science, 1998; 282 : 2258-2261). It has been shown, that selective neutralization of <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> will ameliorate the asthma phenotype (Grunig et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Science, 1998; 282 : 2261- 2263). It has also been reported that <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> is involved in the up regulation of mucin gene <RTI ID=0.0>MUC8</RTI> expression in human nasal polyp epithelium and cultured nasal epithelium <RTI ID=0.0>(Kimm</RTI> et al., Acta Otolaryngol., 2002; Sep; 122 (6): 638-643; Seong et al., Acta Otolaryngol., 2002; Jun; 122 (4): 401-407). <RTI ID=0.0>MUC8,</RTI> a major airway mucin glycoprotein, is implicated as playing a role in the pathogenesis of mucus hypersecretion in chronic sinusitis with polps (Seong et <RTI ID=0.0>al.,</RTI> Acta Otolaryngol., 2002; Jun; 122 (4): 401-407).

Functionally, <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> signals through a receptor complex consisting of the interleukin-13 receptor alpha-1 chain <RTI ID=0.0>(IL13RA1)</RTI> and <RTI ID=0.0>IL-4</RTI> receptor alpha (IL4RA) (Daines and Hershey, J Biol <RTI ID=0.0>Chem.,</RTI> 2002; 22 (12): 10387-10393). It has also been shown, that the interleukin-13 receptor alpha-2 <RTI ID=0.0>(IL13RA2)</RTI> binds <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> with high affinity, but by itself (Daines and Hershey, J Biol Chem., 2002; 22 (12): 10387-10393).

This receptor lacks, however, the cytoplasmic domain necessary for signaling and, therefore, is considered to be a decoy receptor. It has been shown that IL13RA2 is predominately an intracellular molecule that can be quickly mobilized from intracellular stores and surface expressed following cellular treatment with interferon (IFN)-gamma.

The surface expression of <RTI ID=0.0>IL13RA2</RTI> after IFN-gamma treatment does not involve protein synthesis and results in diminished <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> signaling (Daines and Hershey, J Biol <RTI ID=0.0>Chem.,</RTI> 2002; 22 (12): 10387-10393).

The results of the gene expression array analysis for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> indicate the action of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> to be novel to that of IFN-gamma in that the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> treatment of lung epithelial derived cell lines resulted in a significant increase of <RTI ID=0.0>IL13RA2</RTI> gene expression. It is conceivable, therefore, that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> treatment would be beneficial in cases where long-term up regulation of <RTI ID=0.0>IL13RA2</RTI> expression and down regulation of <RTI ID=0.0>IL13</RTI> is desired such as in asthma, airway hyperactivity <RTI ID=0.0>(AHR),</RTI> and mucin regulation, including chronic sinusitis with polps.
<RTI ID=0.0> Example 41</RTI> Murine <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 1ig Trangenic Mice</RTI>
<Desc/Clms Page number 215>

To evaluate the in vivo effects of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> overexpression, multiple founders of transgenic mice expressing the murine form of the gene were generated, driven by two different promoters: the lymphocyte-specific promoter <RTI ID=0.0>Eli/Ick,</RTI> and the ubiquitous promoter, EFIa (Example 22). Serum protein levels range from approximately 20-300 ng/ml. The <RTI ID=0.0>Eli/Ick</RTI> promoter generated mice with higher levels of serum protein than those in the <RTI ID=0.0>EFla-zcytorl7lig</RTI> transgenic mice.

The <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> transgenic mice developed a skin phenotype around 4-8 weeks of age. The fur of the transgenic mice became"ruffled, "with obvious piloerection and mild to severe hair loss, usually on their backs, sides of the torso, and around their eyes. This phenotype was consistently found in mice with detectable levels of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> protein in their serum. Among the founders, 100% incidence rate among the mice expressing the <RTI ID=0.0>Elt/Ick-driven</RTI> gene, and a 50% incidence in the EFla- <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> transgenic mice was noted, correlating well with the relative levels of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> that was detected in their serum. The transgenic skin appeared to be pruritic, as evidenced by the scratching behavior of the mice, sometimes excessive enough to induce excoriation and lesions of the skin, which usually became infected (with at least Staphylococcus aureus). The mice were originally identified with metal ear tags, but in most cases, the ear tags were forcibly removed by the mice themselves.

This often resulted in severe damage to the external ear. These wounded ears often did not heal properly, as reflected in the presence of long-lasting pustules and crusting, and a seeping, expanding wound would that developed in many of the animals, behind and between their ears. Some of the transgenic mice also developed scabby wounds on their shoulders and neck. Skin lesions were observed in a subset of the animals, generally evolving on areas of skin where hair loss had already been apparent, and were often exacerbated by the scratching behavior of the mice.

RealTime quantitative RT-PCR was used to detect <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> RNA transcripts in transgenic (but not non-transgenic) skin samples, with the <RTI ID=0.0>Ett/Ick</RTI> transgenic skin expressing more <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> RNA than skin from <RTI ID=0.0>EFla-zcytorl71ig</RTI> transgenic mice. The genes encoding the zcytorl7 receptor subunits, zcytorl7 and OSM-Rbeta, were expressed in the skin of both non-transgenic and <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7lig-</RTI> transgenic mice.
<Desc/Clms Page number 216>

An examination of the lymphoid tissues from a subset of the <RTI ID=0.0>Ell/lck-</RTI> transgenic founders by flow cytometry revealed a significant increase in the proportion of activated T cells in the spleen and lymph nodes of these mice. Two of the four mice analyzed had severely enlarged cervical lymph nodes, possibly due to the presence of lesions on their necks. A subtle increase in spleen weight and a slight increase in monocytes and neutrophils circulating in the blood of the transgenic mice was observed. There was no increase in a variety of cytokines tested, nor were there changes in the circulating serum amyloid A levels in these mice. The effects on the immune cells in the transgenic mice may be a direct or an indirect result of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig,</RTI> or are secondary effects of the skin lesions.

<RTI ID=0.0>Histopathology</RTI> was performed on many tissues other than skin, including liver, thymus, spleen, kidney, and testes, and no significant abnormalities in these organs were noted. Analysis of the transgenic skin, however, did reveal a number of alterations, which varied greatly depending upon the source and location of skin (e. g. , normal, hairless, or lesional). In many cases, the ears of the transgenic mice had a thickened epidermis as compared to the non-transgenic controls (e. g. , approximately 4 layers versus 2 layers), and the underlying tissues contained low to moderate numbers of inflammatory cells, which were primarily mononuclear with occasional neutrophils.

The epidermis over the abdomen appeared multifocally slightly thicker in the transgenic, but there was no apparent increase in inflammatory cells in the underlying dermis or subcutis. In the hairless portions of skin from these mice, there were dilated hair follicles that contained some debris but no hair shafts (e. g. , the hairs fell out by the roots). In the lesioned areas, there was severe thickening of the epidermis (acanthosis), increased keratin on the surface of the skin (hyperkeratosis), scattered ulcers of varying size and significant numbers of inflammatory cells in the dermis (mainly neutrophils, with varying numbers of macrophages and lymphocytes). The dermis also contained numerous mast cells bordering the lesions. Some of the hair shafts in the lesioned areas of the transgenic skin were in the active stage (anagen), in contrast to many of the hair shafts in"normal"areas which were in the involuting (catagen) to inactive (telogen) stage.
<Desc/Clms Page number 217>

The phenotype of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> transgenic mice strongly resembles that of atopic dermatitis (AD) patients, and mouse models of AD. AD is a common chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by hyperactivated cytokines of the helper T cell subset 2 (Th2). <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> is preferentially expressed by Th2 vs. <RTI ID=0.0>Thl</RTI> cells, which lends further credence to this comparison. Although the exact etiology of AD is unknown, multiple factors have been implicated, including hyperactive Th2 immune responses, autoimmunity, infection, allergens, and genetic predisposition. Key features of the disease include xerosis (dryness of the skin), pruritus (itchiness of the skin), conjunctivitis, inflammatory skin lesions, Staphylococcus aureus infection, elevated blood eosinophilia, elevation of serum IgE and <RTI ID=0.0>IgGI,</RTI> and chronic dermatitis with T cell, mast cell, macrophage and eosinophil infiltration. Colonization or infection with <RTI ID=0.0>S.</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>aureus</RTI> has been recognized to exacerbate AD and perpetuate chronicity of this skin disease.

AD is often found in patients with asthma and allergic rhinitis, and is frequently the initial manifestation of allergic disease. About <RTI ID=0.0>20%</RTI> of the population in Western countries suffer from these allergic diseases, and the incidence of AD in developed countries is rising for unknown reasons. AD typically begins in childhood and can often persist through adolescence into adulthood. Current treatments for AD include topical corticosteroids, oral cyclosporin A, non-corticosteroid immunosuppressants such as tacrolimus (FK506 in ointment form), and interferon- gamma. Despite the variety of treatments for AD, many patients'symptoms do not improve, or they have adverse reactions to medications, requiring the search for other, more effective therapeutic agents.

Epithelial cells, which express the heterodimeric receptor for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> (zcytoR17 and OSM-Rbeta), are located at the sites (e. g. , skin, gut, lung, etc. ) of allergen entry into the body and interact closely with dendritic cells (professional antigen presenting cells) in situ. Dendritic cells play an important role in the pathogenesis of allergic diseases, and it is possible that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> can interact with its receptor on epithelial cells in the skin and lung and influence immune responses in these organs. <RTI ID=0.0>Zcytorl71ig</RTI> and its receptor (s) may therefore contribute to the pathogenesis of allergic diseases such as AD and asthma. Furthermore, the phenotype
<Desc/Clms Page number 218>

of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> transgenic mice suggests that this ligand may play a role in wound healing, since the mice seem unable to repair damage to their ears, and often bear long- lasting lesions on their backs and sides. An antagonist of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> might therefore represent a viable therapeutic for these and other indications.

Example 42 Luciferase Assay on Human <RTI ID=0.0>Transformed Epithelial Cell Lines via Transient Infection</RTI> with an Adenoviral <RTI ID=0.0>STATlSRE Reporter Gene</RTI> A wide variety of human transformed epithelial cell lines (see Table 16 below) were seeded in 96-well flat-bottom plates at 10,000 cell/well in regular growth media as specified for each cell type. The following day, the cells were infected with an adenovirus reporter construct, KZ136, at a multiplicity of infection of 5000. The KZ136 reporter contains the STAT elements in addition to a serum response element.

The total volume was 100 ul/well using DMEM supplemented with 2 mM L-glutamine (GibcoBRL), <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> mM Sodium Pyruvate (GibcoBRL) and lx Insulin-Transferrin- Selenium supplement (GibcoBRL) (hereinafter referred to as serum-free media). Cells were cultured overnight.

The following day, the media was removed and replaced with <RTI ID=0.0>100 Al</RTI> of induction media. The induction media was human zcytorl7 ligand diluted in serum- free media at <RTI ID=0.0>100ng/ml,</RTI> 50 ng/ml, 25 ng/ml, 12.5 ng/ml, 6.25 ng/ml, 3.125 ng/ml and 1.56 ng/ml. A positive control of <RTI ID=0.0>20%</RTI> FBS was used to validate the assay and to ensure the infection by adenovirus was successful. The cells were induced for 5 hours at which time the media was aspirated. The cells were then washed in 50 <RTI ID=0.0>yI/well</RTI> of PBS, and subsequently <RTI ID=0.0>lysed</RTI> in <RTI ID=0.0>30</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>ul/well</RTI> of <RTI ID=0.0>1X</RTI> cell lysis buffer (Promega). After a 10- minute incubation at room temperature, 25 <RTI ID=0.0>itl/well</RTI> of <RTI ID=0.0>lysate</RTI> was transferred to opaque white 96-well plates. The plates were then read on the Luminometer using 5-second integration with 40 <RTI ID=0.0>yI/well</RTI> injection of luciferase substrate (Promega).
The results revealed the ability of multiple epithelial cell lines to respond to zcytorl7 ligand as shown in Table 16 below.

All cell lines tested produced GM-CSF and <RTI ID=0.0>IL-8</RTI> in response to stimulation with control cytokines IL-lb and TNFa. Most cell lines produced IL-6 and MCP-lin response to IL-lb and TNFa stimulation. Zcytorl7 ligand stimulated <RTI ID=0.0>IL-6</RTI> production in the DU145 cell line compared to control (193pg/mL vs. <RTI ID=0.0>71pg/mL).</RTI>

Zcytorl7 ligand stimulated 3 of 5 cell lines to produce <RTI ID=0.0>IL-8</RTI> with the greatest effect seen in A549 cells (5 fold), and reduced <RTI ID=0.0>IL-8</RTI> production in U20S cells by 2 fold. There was a slight effect on MCP-1 production by DU145 and U20S cells when cultured with zcytorl7 ligand.

Example 44 <RTI ID=0.0> Zcytorl7lig Effects on 3H-TdR Incorporation in DU145 Prostate Epithelial Carcinoma</RTI> Cells Cells were seeded in 96-well tissue clusters (Falcon) at a density of 25,000/well in MEM (Life Technologies) growth medium supplemented with glutamine, pyruvate, non-essential amino acids (Life Technologies) and 10% fetal bovine serum (Hyclone). At confluence (24 hours later), cells were switched to growth arrest media by substituting 0. 1% BSA (Life Technologies) for serum. After 48 hours to achieve cell synchronization, the growth-arrest medium was replaced with fresh medium. Then, human recombinant <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> (test reagent) was added at various
<Desc/Clms Page number 227>

concentrations (from 0.24 to 60 <RTI ID=0.0>ng/mL)</RTI> (see Table 16 below), to test for the effect of the protein on basal DNA replication. Some wells received 2.5% FBS (Hyclone) in addition to zcytorl7Ligand, in order to test effect of the protein on elevated levels of TdR incorporation. FBS <RTI ID=0.0>10%</RTI> and 20ng/ml Platelet Derived Growth Factor-BB (PDGF- BB) (R & D) were used as positive control.
Eighteen hours following addition of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl7Ligand</RTI> and the rest of the test reagents, cells were pulsed with 250 nCi/mL [3H]-thymidine (NEN) for 4 hours.

Following the 4-hour pulse, media were discarded and 100 <RTI ID=0.0>yL</RTI> trypsin solution (Life Technologies) was added in each well to dislodge the cells. The radioactivity incorporated by DU145 was determined by harvesting the cells with a Packard Filtermate 196 cell harvester and by counting the incorporated label using a Packard TopCount NXT microplate scintillation counter.
As can be seen in Table 20 below, <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> induced thymidine incorporation in quiescent cells (in 0.1% BSA) in a concentration-dependent manner.

This effect reached 2. 5-fold of the BSA control at the highest concentration used, 60 ng/mL. In addition, this effect of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> was also detectable when the baseline incorporation was elevated by the addition of 2. 5% FBS (in this series as potent a mitogen as 10% FBS). These results therefore indicate that under both basal and stimulated conditions <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> can act as a mitogenic factor for the DU145 carcinoma cells.

Table 16 shows the effects of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> on thymidine incorporation by DU145 cells. Results are expressed in cpm/well and numbers are the <RTI ID=0.0>meanst.</RTI> dev of triplicate wells.

Example 45 Expression of huzcytorl 7Ligand in E. coli A. Construction of expression vector pRPS01 that expresses huzcytor17Lig/MBP-6H fusion polypeptide An expression plasmid containing a polynucleotide encoding a <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl71ig</RTI> fused C-terminally to Maltose Binding Protein <RTI ID=0.0>(MBP)</RTI> was constructed via homologous recombination. The fusion polypeptide contains an N-terminal approximately 388 amino acid <RTI ID=0.0>MBP</RTI> portion fused to the huzcytorl7Lig described herein. A fragment of <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl71ig cDNA</RTI> was isolated using the PCR method as described herein. Two primers were used in the production of the <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> fragment in a standard PCR reaction: (1) one containing 40 bp of the vector flanking sequence and 20 bp corresponding to the amino terminus of the <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl71ig,</RTI> and (2) another containing 40 bp of the 3'end corresponding to the flanking vector sequence and 20 bp corresponding to the carboxyl terminus of the <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl71ig.</RTI> Two microliters of the 100 l PCR reaction was run on a 1. <RTI ID=0.0>0%</RTI> agarose gel with <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> x TBE buffer for analysis, and the expected molecular weight fragment was observed. The remaining PCR
<Desc/Clms Page number 229>

reaction was combined with the second PCR tube and precipitated with <RTI ID=0.0>400</RTI> Al of absolute ethanol. The precipitated DNA was used for recombination into the Smal cut recipient vector pTAP98 to produce the construct encoding the <RTI ID=0.0>MBP-huzcytorl71ig</RTI> fusion, as described below.

The vector pTAP98 was constructed using yeast homologous recombination. One hundred nanograms of EcoRl cut pMAL-c2 was recombined with <RTI ID=0.0>Itig</RTI> Pvul cut pRS316, <RTI ID=0.0>lung</RTI> linker, and <RTI ID=0.0>l. g Scal/EcoRl</RTI> cut pRS316 were combined in a PCR reaction. PCR products were concentrated via 100% ethanol precipitation. The competent yeast cell <RTI ID=0.0>(S.</RTI> cerevisiae) strain, <RTI ID=0.0>SF838-9Da,</RTI> was combined <RTI ID=0.0>withlO y1</RTI> of a mixture containing approximately <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>itg</RTI> of the <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl71ig</RTI> PCR product (above) and 100 ng of Smal digested pTAP98 vector, and electroporated at 0.75 kV, 25 <RTI ID=0.0>ZF and o</RTI> ohms. The resulting reaction mixture was plated onto URA-D plates and incubated at <RTI ID=0.0>30 C.</RTI>

Gels were run in 1XMES buffer.
The positive clones were designated pRPS01 and subjected to sequence analysis.

One microliter of sequencing DNA was used to transform electrocompetent E. coli cell strain MC1061. The cells were electropulsed at 2.0 kV, 25 <RTI ID=0.0>zuF</RTI> and 400 ohms. Following electroporation, cells were rescued 0.6 ml SOC and grown on LB+Amp plates at <RTI ID=0.0>37 C</RTI> overnight, with 100 mg/L Ampicillin. clones were expanded for protein purification of the <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl71ig/MBP-6H</RTI> fusion protein using standard techniques.

B. <RTI ID=0.0>Purification of huzcytorl 7Lig/MBP-6H from E. coli fermentation</RTI> Unless otherwise noted, all operations were carried out at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI> The following procedure was used to purify recombinant <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7Lig/MBP-6H</RTI> polypeptide. E. coli cells containing the <RTI ID=0.0>pRPS01</RTI> construct and expressing huzcytorl7Lig/MBP-6H, were constructed using standard molecular biology methods and cultured in 50.0 g/L SuperBroth <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> (12 g/L Casien, 24 g/L Yeast Extract, 11.4 g/L di-potassium phosphate, 1.7 g/L Mono-potassium phosphate; Becton Dickenson, Cockeysville, MD), 5 g/L glycerol and 5 mL/L 1M Magnesium Sulfate. Twenty grams of cells were harvested and frozen for protein purification.

The thawed cells were resuspended in 500 mL Amylose Equilibration buffer (20mM Tris, <RTI ID=0.0>100mM</RTI> NaCI, pH 8.0). A French Press cell breaking system (Constant Systems Ltd. , Warwick, UK) with a temperature setting <RTI ID=0.0>of-7 C</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>to-10 C</RTI> and 30K PSI was used to lyse the cells. The resuspended cells were assayed for breakage by A600 readings before and after cycling through the French Press. The processed cell suspension was pelleted at 10, <RTI ID=0.0>000G</RTI> for 30 minutes to remove the cellular debris and the supernatant was harvested for protein purification.

A 25 ml column of Amylose resin (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA) (prepared as described below) was poured into a Bio-Rad, 2.5 cm D x 10 cm H glass column. The column was packed and equilibrated by gravity with 10 column volumes (CVs) of Amylose Equilibration buffer. The processed cell supernatant was batch loaded to the Amylose resin overnight, with rocking. The resin was returned to the Bio- Rad column and washed with 10 CV's of Amylose Equilibration buffer by gravity. The column was eluted <RTI ID=0.0>with-2</RTI> CV of Amylose Elution buffer (Amylose Equilibration buffer + 10 mM Maltose, Fluka Biochemical, Switzerland) by gravity. Ten 5 mL fractions were collected over the elution profile and assayed for Absorbance at 280 and 320 nM. The Amylose resin was regenerated with <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> CV of distilled <RTI ID=0.0>H20,</RTI> 5 CVs of 0.1% (w/v) SDS (Sigma), 5 CVs of distilled <RTI ID=0.0>H20,</RTI> 5 CVs of Amylose Equilibration buffer and finally <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> CV of Amylose Storage buffer (Amylose Equilibration buffer +
<Desc/Clms Page number 231>
0.02% Sodium Azide). The regenerated column was stored at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI>

Elution profile fractions of interest were pooled and dialyzed in a <RTI ID=0.0>1 OK</RTI> dialysis chamber (Slide-A-Lyzer, Pierce <RTI ID=0.0>Immunochemicals)</RTI> against 4 x 4L PBS pH 7.4 (Sigma) over an 8 hour time period to remove low molecular weight contaminants, buffer exchange and desalt. Following dialysis, the material harvested represented the purified huzcytorl7Lig/MBP-6H polypeptide. The purified <RTI ID=0.0>huzcytorl7Lig/MBP-6H</RTI> polypeptide was filter sterilized and analyzed via SDS-PAGE Coomassie staining for an appropriate molecular weight product. The concentration of the huzcytorl7Lig/MBP- 6H polypeptide was determined by BCA analysis to be 1.28 mg/mL.

Example 46 Human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl 7lig Polyclonal Antibody</RTI> A. Preparation and Purification Polyclonal antibodies were prepared by immunizing 2 female New Zealand white rabbits with the purified recombinant protein <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7L/MBP-6H</RTI> (Example 45). The rabbits were each given an initial intraperitoneal (IP) injection of 200 <RTI ID=0.0>ttg</RTI> of purified protein in Complete Freund's Adjuvant followed by booster IP injections of 100 <RTI ID=0.0>jig</RTI> protein in Incomplete Freund's Adjuvant every three weeks.

Seven to ten days after the administration of the second booster injection (3 total injections), the animals were bled and the serum was collected. The animals were then boosted and bled every three weeks.

The <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7L/MBP-6H</RTI> specific rabbit serum was pre-adsorbed of anti-MBP antibodies using a <RTI ID=0.0>CNBr-SEPHAROSE</RTI> 4B protein column (Pharmacia LKB) that was prepared using 10 mg of non-specific purified recombinant MBP-fusion protein per gram of <RTI ID=0.0>CNBr-SEPHAROSE.</RTI> The <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7L/MBP-6H-specific</RTI> polyclonal antibodies were affinity purified from the pre-adsorbed rabbit serum using a <RTI ID=0.0>CNBr-SEPHAROSE</RTI> 4B protein column (Pharmacia LKB) that was prepared using 10 mg of the specific antigen purified recombinant protein <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7L/MBP-6H.</RTI>

Following purification, the polyclonal antibodies were dialyzed with 4 changes of 20 times the antibody volume of PBS over a time period of at least 8 hours. Hzcytorl7- Ligand-specific antibodies were characterized by ELISA using 500 ng/ml of the

purified recombinant proteins <RTI ID=0.0>hzcytorl7L/MBP-6H</RTI> or hzcytorl7L-CEE produced in a baculovirus expression system as antibody targets. SDS-PAGE and <RTI ID=0.0>Western blotting analysis of Rabbit Anti-human ZcytoRl7lig</RTI> MBP- 6H antibody Rabbit Anti-human ZcytoR171ig MBP-6H antibody was tested by SDS- PAGE (NuPage 4-12%, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) with coomassie staining method and Western blotting using goat anti-rabbit IgG-HRP. Human and mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> purified protein (200-25 ng) was electrophoresed using an Invitrogen Novex's Xcell <RTI ID=0.0>II</RTI> mini-cell, and transferred to nitrocellulose (0.2 mm; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) at room temperature using Novex's Xcell blot module with stirring according to directions provided in the instrument manual. The transfer was run at 300 mA for one hour in a buffer containing 25 mM Tris base, 200 mM glycine, and 20% methanol. The filter was then blocked with Western A buffer (in house, 50 mM Tris, pH 7.4, 5 mM EDTA, pH 8.0, 0. <RTI ID=0.0>05%</RTI> Igepal CA-630,150 mM NaCI, and 0. <RTI ID=0.0>25%</RTI> gelatin) overnight with gentle rocking at <RTI ID=0.0>4 C.</RTI> The nitrocellulose was quickly rinsed, then the rabbit anti-human zcytoR171ig <RTI ID=0.0>MBP-6H</RTI> (1: 1000) was added in Western A buffer. The blot was incubated for 1.5 hours at room temperature with gentle rocking. The blot was rinsed 3 times for 5 minutes each in Western A, then goat anti-rabbit IgG HRP antibody (1: 5000) was added in Western A buffer. The blot was incubated for <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> hour at room temperature with gentle rocking. The blot was rinsed 3 times for 5 minutes each in Western A, then quickly rinsed in <RTI ID=0.0>H20.</RTI> The blot was developed using commercially available chemiluminescent substrate reagents <RTI ID=0.0>(ECLWestern</RTI> blotting detection reagents <RTI ID=0.0>1</RTI> and 2 mixed 1: 1; reagents obtained from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, Buckinghamshire, England) and the blot was exposed to x-ray film for up to 5 minutes.

The purified human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> appeared as a large band at about 30 kDa and a smaller band at about 20 kDa under reduced conditions. The mouse <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> was not detected by the rabbit anti-human <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> antibody.

Example 47 <RTI ID=0.0> Zcytorl lig Effects on U937 Monocyte Adhesion</RTI> to Transformed Bone Marrow Endothelial Cell (TRBMEC) Monolayer Transformed Bone Marrow Endothelial Cells (TRBMEC) were seeded in <RTI ID=0.0>96-well</RTI> tissue clusters (Falcon) at a density of 25,000/well in medium M131 (Cascade Biologics) supplemented with Microvascular Growth Supplement (MVGS) (Cascade Biologics). At confluence (24 hours later), cells were switched to <RTI ID=0.0>M199</RTI> (Gibco-Life Technologies) supplemented with 1% Fetal Bovine Serum (Hyclone).

Human recombinant <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> (test reagent) was added at various concentrations (from 0.4 to 10 ng/mL) (see Table 21 below), to test for the effect of the protein on immune cell-endothelial cell interactions resulting in adhesion. Some wells received 0. <RTI ID=0.0>3ng/ml</RTI> Tumor Necrosis Factor (TNFalpha R & D Systems), a known pro- inflammatory cytokine, in addition to <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig,</RTI> to test an effect of the protein on endothelial cells under inflammatory conditions. TNFalpha at 0.3ng/ml alone was used as positive control and the concentration used represents approximately 70% of the maximal TNFalpha effect in this system, i. e. , it does not induce maximal adherence of U937 cells (a human monocyte-like cell line) to the endothelium. For this reason, this setup can detect both upregulation and downregulation of the TNFalpha effects. Basal levels of adhesion both with and without TNFalpha were used as baseline to assess effect of test reagents.

After overnight incubation of the endothelial cells with the test reagents <RTI ID=0.0>(zcytorl71igand</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0></RTI> TNFalpha), U937 cells, stained with <RTI ID=0.0>5, uM</RTI> Calcein-AM fluorescent marker (Molecular Probes), the cells were suspended in RPMI 1640 (no phenol-red) supplemented with 1% FBS and plated at 100,000 cells/well on the rinsed <RTI ID=0.0>TRBMEC</RTI> monolayer. Fluorescence levels at excitation/emission wavelengths of 485/538nm (Molecular Devices micro-plate reader, CytoFluor application) were measured 30 minutes later, before and after rinsing the well three times with warm RPMI 1640 (no phenol-red), to remove non-adherent U937. Pre-rinse (total) and post-rinse (adherence- specific) fluorescence levels were used to determine percent adherence (net
<Desc/Clms Page number 234>
adherent/net total x 100 = % adherence).

As can be seen in Table 21 below, <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> when added alone affected the basal adherence of U937 cells to the endothelial monolayers at the concentration range used (less than 2-fold increases, p < 0.01 by ANOVA test). By itself, the positive control, 0.3ng/mL TNFalpha, increased the adherence of U937 cells from a basal 5. 8% to 35% (6-fold). In the presence of TNFalpha, zcytor17lig synergized with TNFalpha and further enhanced U937 adhesion in a concentrationdependent manner between 0.4 and <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/mL</RTI> (p < 0.01 by ANOVA test). At <RTI ID=0.0>lOng/mL,</RTI> <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> enhanced the effect of TNFalpha by 62%. These results indicate that <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> may by itself be a pro-inflammatory agent. Zcytor17lig was able to synergize with sub-maximal concentrations of TNFalpha to increase monocyte adherence to endothelial cells. These results also show that endothelial cells, especially when exposed to pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNFalpha, are a likely target tissue of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> action. The consequence of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71igand</RTI> on endothelial cells may be to heighten monocyte or macrophage adhesion to a site of proinflammatory activity. Activated monocytes and macrophages are important in many inflammatory diseases. Therefore inhibition of monocyte/macrophage adhesions may provide a therapeutic rationale for <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71igand</RTI> antagonists. This data would support the use of zcytorl7 ligand antagonists for treatment lung diseases, vascular diseases, autoimmunity, tumor metastasis, disease involving allergic reactions, wound healing and diseases of the skin including contact, allergic or non-allergic <RTI ID=0.0>dermatistic</RTI> or psoriasis and inflammatory bowel disease. Table 21 shows the effects of <RTI ID=0.0>zcytorl71ig</RTI> on U937 monocyte adhesion to <RTI ID=0.0>TRBMEC</RTI> endothelial monolayers. Results are expressed in percent adhesion and numbers are the <RTI ID=0.0>meanst.</RTI> dev of triplicate wells.
